headline: Love everything about it!
pros:
A job is perfect for me when tone at the top, people, value, mission and culture are aligned. This is exactly the work environment at DocuSign. 

The core value of enabling businesses to be more agreeable and contributing to cutting down carbon footprint is very motivating to bear in mind as we go about day to day. What sweetens the deal even more is the collaborative and caring culture that we live and breathe everyday. People I work with are all smart, driven, warm and fun. The Management team are deeply committed to listen to feedback from employees, which shows from various measures they have implemented to help us work effectively and live happily. Truly enjoying my time here!
cons: None I can think of.

headline: Great company culture, still small enough to make impact
pros:
* Culture, culture, culture  - estaff leadership is outstanding and not only focused on building a great product and achieving its TAM potential but also cares about employee base (Dan Springer is the real deal, genuinely great and authentic CEO)
* One of the reasons why I decided to join DocuSign was that it still felt small enough that you can make an impact despite being more than 4k employee base.  Thus far, really enjoying the partnership with the business partners and even within my department, I feel I have the opportunity share my ideas and a platform to showcase my talents
* Product still has tons of runway.  Our biggest competitor is paper and as companies  accelerate the digital transformation, our product delivers solutions to drive productivity gains with a positive impact on the eco footprint
cons: None that you can't break through.  If you are a person that is passionate and have drive, I think anything is possible (assuming you are collaborative, solution oriented and willing to part hard work).  You can also coast by here....

headline: Very arrogant interview process
pros: The benefits are there and is industry standard. Some people are smart and you can learn from them
cons: The rest of the people are just parking there as a daytime job and not passionate abt wat they do at all. Also my interview process took very long, and they’re pretty arrogant by saying ‘oh we received many applications and found someone better than you to take this position’. Only later they came back and gave me an offer so I guess the ‘best candidate’ they had declined the offer. Whomp whomp now is my time to leave too after a short tenure here as I found a better position as well. Ciao!

headline: Work of your Life
pros:
- Tremendous Leadership
- Great work/life balance 
- Product that everyone loves
cons:
- Very little support for the sales team (Marketing)
- Cheap on technology and employee gear. Make your employees proud to work at DocuSign
- Give new employees technology that is going to make them more efficient and excited to work at DocuSign. You should not have to wait 12-months to get a decent computer as and entry-level employee.

headline: Great company, Great talent, Great culture, Customer success focus.
pros: In my 20+ years of software development, this is one of the best companies I have ever worked for. Focus on customers having a quality experience is outstanding. Management very supportive in providing any needs to assure development success. Benefit assistance is remarkable.
cons: To assure 5-nines uptime, be aware that making any changes requires patience to assure that all stakeholders throughly review all code, commits, tests, and multiple layers of deployment.

headline: Fantastic place to work in IT
pros: The work is challenging, there is room to improve yourself, and occasional travel is a nice perk.  My coworkers and the company culture are what keep me around.  Docusign has hired and retained extremely intelligent people, it is inclusive and becoming more diverse, as well as growing rapidly into the dominant platform for eSignature and CLM products.
cons: There is a tendency to work in a silo and not know what your coworkers are working on.  While we are a global company it is difficult to feel like you are part of a team if the leadership is in another office.

headline: Top products and services!
pros:
Best of colleagues
Top  management
Extremely good products
cons: I would like that all employees have the same level of understanding when it comes to our company goals. Same for the perks and benefits, this differs from region to region.

headline: Amazing employer, great product, and great colleagues
pros:
Lots of room for product ownership, and contribution to the company's bottom line. Even though its a large-ish public company, the hierarchy is relatively flat in the product org, and all levels of leadership will collaborate with even junior PMs to allow for the most flexible decision making to be made at the level which is best equipped.

Compensation is good, it's not going to be as high as FAANG, but you probably get more ownership of the product than in those megacorps.

It's an exciting time for docusign too, lots and lots of room to grow, and the product is growing in all these amazing ways to serve our customers. We have an agreement cloud suite of products, and the challenge will be to get all these components functioning in an integrated singular way, but that's a great problem to have, and the runway for the company is long and clear.
cons: None really.  Maybe compensation being lower than FAANG is a thing, but that's it. That said, our stock has a higher growth potential than some of those companies, so your stock grant growth is high.

headline: Nice company
pros: Nice culture and people. Working there is a blast
cons: Not much to out in here

headline: Unique  Culture - Very supportive company

cons: Nothing major I can think of

headline: Sales Associate

headline: Good culture & stable work

cons: Most of the dev work is done, it's largely maintenance work in most of the teams. Only a couple of teams are engaged in fresh dev.

headline: Great company
pros: Ability to work remote; flexible working hours; supportive leadership
cons: Can be a bit dysfunctional and unorganized; lacking support for new hires.  It's very much sink or swim mentality.

headline: Great place to work !
pros: Talented teams, Challenging work &  good pay !
cons: If you get an opportunity to join DS, just grab it !

headline: Fantastic and empathetic company focused on feedback, improvement, and growth.
pros:
- DocuSign cares deeply about ensuring employees do "the work of their lives" as they call it. They consistently ask their employees to complete pulse surveys and make tweaks based on what they hear. 

- The product suite is exciting and there is a ton of room for innovation and growth.

- The benefits are fantastic: insurance, 401k matching, gym stiped, and much more.

- DocuSign hires smart, all of my co-workers are empathetic deep thinkers dedicated to the mission.

- Large interest in giving back to the community. Opportunities abound for volunteering and days off are given to allow you to do so.
cons: - As much as I love giving feedback, it can occasionally be a bit of a brain drain to give so much. Possibly dial it back a little bit occasionally to avoid decision fatigue and to ensure that we have the energy to give good critical feedback.

headline: Amazing Company with an Amazing Culture
pros:
- People 
- Culture 
- Supportive Management 
- Learning Opportunity 
- Loads of room to grow 
- Benefits
cons: - Working hours are quite long

headline: Maintaining the status quo
pros:
-flexible WFH policy
-relaxed environment
cons: -specializes in not disrupting the status quo of who has power in the org and how decisions are made

headline: DocuSign is a one of a kind company
pros:
- opportunities career
- nice environment 
- nice benefits

The management is keen to listen to us and make a change if needed to improve the work environment. 
- Sports activities
cons: Need to be flexible with all the change we do due to our fast expansion.

headline: Walks the Talk
pros: Most ethical company I've ever worked for.  Customer AND Employee trust is built from the bottom up and from the top down.  Benefits are among the industries best, yet everyone works to keep costs reasonable.  Strong advocate for giving back to the community.
cons: Because of it's fast growth, new hire processes are not yet as polished as they could be.

headline: Love my job, the company, the people & the product!
pros:
At DocuSign you'll hear HQ say they want to to make DocuSign 'The work of your life'. At first, I thought it sounded a little cheesy for us Europeans - but 6 months in, I get it. DocuSign endeavours to give you everything you need to feel fulfilled and excited to come to work each day. It's a fast-paced environment which means each day is different and exciting, and there is lots of opportunity to progress! Though its a relatively large company (5k employees around the world), I feel I am directly impacting the Global vision, rather than just being a cog in a wheel.

The team are great, management is supportive, and they genuinely care how you are doing. There is also a real sense of accountability and integrity that comes from Dan (CEO) all the way down.

Such a great place to work, my only regret is having not joined years ago!
cons: It's a fast-paced environment which I personally love, but if you are someone who is resistant to change you will likely find it challenging. Definitely not an environment for coasting!

headline: Great place to work
pros: Potential for advancement, great culture
cons: Difficult to navigate corporate structure

headline: Enterprise business is in trouble
pros: Stock price is on a tear.  eSignature product is still the gold-standard.
cons: eSign product is already widely-adopted, so Enterprise AE's have to sell CLM which does not solve a big enough problem to generate large orders, and act as a reseller for small 3rd party software solutions.  All of these secondary products have long sales cycles and none are top of the line products.  OTE attainment is miserably low at less than 75%.  We are not making money or having fun.

headline: Doing the Best Work of my Career
pros:
- Employee friendly in every possible way
 - High caliber colleagues
 - Great Management Team
 - Great immediate supervisor and peers
 - Great work/life balance
 - Awesome peer group who support each and other 
 - innovative and ambitious goals
cons: - Sometimes change for changes sake is not always necessary.

headline: DocuSign listens to
pros:
Upper management and execs seem to absolutely care about their employees. There are plenty of opportunities to give feedback, whether it's within your team, about benefits, or onboarding. For instance, they recently increased the transit subsidy after receiving a lot of comments on it.  Our CEO  even makes the effort to visit non-West coast offices and talk to employees. 

I also appreciate that managers are required to go through training to ensure they are guiding and helping develop their team effectively. Benefits are excellent and the culture is welcoming and transparent. 

It's exciting to be here as the company grows in headcount and the product offering gets bigger and better. Personally my team is flexible about work hours and working from home. Managers trust their employees and value work life balance. Not to mention the array of snacks and stocked fridge is a good reason to come to the office!
cons: Can be difficult to keep up with frequent product changes. Only some teams get catered lunch weekly

headline: Really enjoyable place to work
pros: The GOTS organization is fun and the culture is positive.  As the company succeeds the rewards are distributed throughout the organization, and it's evident in the perks, benefits, and fun events (like the holiday party).  I also like that the CTO is a woman, which is rare in the tech industry.  It really feels like the company cares about the employees and is open to input.  Even the review process is multi-directional, including reviews from your peers, and you get to review your manager.  The leadership is also very transparent about what the future plans are and why we are doing certain things.  Lastly, the "give-back" positive culture of the business makes you feel really good.  We get to volunteer a lot and the company matches charitable donations.  They also have a big focus on saving trees through the DocuSign Forests initiative and are heavily focused on reducing the carbon footprint for the company.
cons:
I wish they had fertility benefits in their health insurance plan.  It's a benefit that a lot of tech companies are adding to help attract top talent, and DocuSign wants to compete at that level.
I also wish we had an East Bay office to make commuting easier.

headline: Still Awesome
pros: It's been a year now and it's just as great working here as it was then, if not better.  We're hiring like crazy but the caliber of people joining matches the culture and expected performance.  There's been a focus on employee experience and development which is important as the company grows.
cons: Office space is getting tight.

headline: We are just beginning
pros: DocuSign is a great place to work.  People are friendly and will try to help you out.  Senior Managers try to resolve interpersonal conflicts between people and groups.  It is a good environment with a great work/life balance.  Employees are passionate about what they are doing.
cons: Product Development is leaner than you would expect for a company of this size and growth (maybe that is part of the success), but we are thinly staffed in many areas.  It feels like N - 2 (N being the optimal number of employees).

headline: The place to be to do the work of your life!
pros:
People
Culture
Massive Growth (Current and Future Potential)
Competitive Compensation and Benefits
Leadership Transparency
Relatively Flat Organization
Opportunity To Help Define Your Role
Super Flexible Work Environment
Commitment to the greater community and environment
cons:
Cost of Parking (Downtown Seattle)
Undefined Career Trajectory
Unclear how future raises, promotions and bonuses are determined
Not quite a startup, and not quite a huge long term established company yet, processes and and other related support structures are still being defined and designed. While this provides lots of opportunity for some, I could see how this could make others feel a bit uneasy.

headline: Love everything!
pros: People are interested in doing the right thing and what's best for the company.  Leadership is extremely approachable and open to suggestions for improvements.  Growth opportunities abound.
cons: ... no free food?

headline: Incredible place to work
pros: Positive culture, great people, supportive environment
cons: Nothing really comes to mind!

headline: Best Place To Be
pros:
Work life balance is respected. 
Career advancement opportunities are abundant.
Great sales managers
Excellent comp and reasonable quotas.
cons: A few bad eggs can be found around the office. But who doesn't have them?

headline: Best company I have worked at so far.
pros:
1) Lots of room for professional growth as the company is growing fast and bringing in new (and good) ideas is encouraged.
2) Employees are smart, and willing to meet with you and help you. I feel like there is a lot I can learn from my manager and leadership.
3) Culture is awesome, very open. Great work life balance.
4) Benefits are amazing (health care, parental leave...)
cons: Working at such a fast growing company might be overwhelming for some since you have to carve out your path and take the initiative on many things.

headline: Brilliant place and excellent people
pros:
No micro management
Excellent benefits
Fantastic management
cons: Trying to pin people down for assistance can sometimes be a little challenging.

headline: Best job I ever had
pros: Loved the team, culture, product -- everything!
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Unstable & Toxic
pros: Great benefits and reasonably good remote work options. Learned a lot, and met some really great people, who unfortunately just ended up leaving because the techops/devops culture is so toxic. If you're highly-political, then this might be the place for you.
cons:
In the span of just over a year we have been re-org'd FOUR times. Very unstable. They are apparently under the erroneous impression that being good with technical matters is equal to being a good leader. 

My role was downgraded from salaried to hourly with no notice or recourse.  Seems like an attempt to offset budgets through attrition (better to have people just quit on you, right?).

Developer culture is exactly what you'd expect it to be--toxic--the same as some other publicly criticized tech companies (like Facebook or Microsoft). They've actually brought in a number of people from Microsoft, so that company's infamously toxic culture is now taking solid root at DocuSign and is widely unchecked (any behavior towards colleagues is permitted as long as you make the company money!). Cronyism is amok; everyone is a "Director" at DocuSign--it's laughable. Diversity in engineering is a joke, apparently only white and Asian people can do the job.

Company pretends like it cares about employees but it's just PR-- they are constantly asking people to review them favorably here on Glassdoor, especially if the person has been with the company under a year. 

Pay is too low as compared to other tech companies to deal with stuff like this.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Ranked third best place to work by Glassdoor
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Sound people, good job, great benefits & pay
pros: Interview process very straightforward and HR extremely helpful (unlike Stripe), management are extremely sound and positive, company is doing very well and reward people well, pay and benefits in Dublin office are excellent
cons: None so far --

headline: Great company with a fun, positive, collaborative culture

some industries are tougher than others and you don't necessarily get a choice which industry you are assigned
-could pay XDRs higher, livable bases

headline: Great product and Vision but odd culture
pros:
Great benefits they really look after you.
Full fridge of food Available whenever you like. Lots of tea and coffee pods which is great. 
CEO Is very nice bloke.
Trips to Seattle for training.
cons: Strange culture, very ‘lad’ oriented which management supports. As soon as I joined I heard countless amounts of other employees complain about this and it soon became very apparent to me. Unless you’re in the ‘boys club’ you’re a real outsider.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros:
- Plenty of opportunities to work on projects that you care about and that you are invested in
- Great perks and company culture
- Commonly solving interesting and difficult problems
cons: - Office space can be crowded, especially during intern season

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Established company with good benefits, stock options, competitive salaries, vacation 
opportunity for growth
cons: It can be complicated between levels of AEs competing for deals

headline: Onboarding Process
pros: Extremely impressed with the way I was welcomed and the onboarding process employed by DocuSign.  2 day session discussing all things Docusign capped with a community server event was so fantastic.  Couple that with meeting new associates from around the globe joining DocuSign was also a plus.  The training material is exceptional and extremely detailed.  So far the experience has been great.
cons: nothing to report really, all things positive.

headline: Account Executive
pros: The management team are really great.
cons: I can think of no Cons!

headline: Grow, compete and collaborate!
pros:
1) The people: Throughout the organization it is clear that DocuSign excels at hiring quality people. From Exec’s to my fellow SDR’s everyone treats each other with respect and empathy. 

2) The SDR role: As a young sales person learning the cycle effectively can be tedious and energy draining. At DocuSign, they don’t fire you if you’re underperforming or in a rut. They encourage you to make little improvements! Lead distribution, the Sandler method and potentially collaborating (see cons) with AE’s & fellow XDR’s are all huge benefits of being an SDR at DocuSign!

3) Benefits: Coming straight out of college a big fear of many young people today are the hidden cost of being an adult. Insurance, DocuSign has you covered! Commuting to work, DocuSign mitigates the cost! Wanting to make a healthy habit, DocuSign will pay for your gym membership!

Overall, get on LinkedIn and ask SDR’s currently at DocuSign there thoughts on these Pros. They’ll all agree!
cons:
27 month minimum to be an AE

Moving to an AM or making a lateral move in the company is very competitive

DocuSign under pays in the sales role compared to other Tech companies. Though it’s an easier sell, has better benefits than the majority and has stock plan/401k match that will help you retire. So take this point with a grain of salt!

headline: MDR
pros: great people and great multicultural environment
cons: nothing, they are growing fast and changes will done

headline: Best Company I've Worked For
pros:
-An executive leadership who cares, and are top performers.
-Compensation is on the upper end, now that salaries are being raised due to IPO.
-Work/life Balance is very real.
-Goal oriented career, if you don't like where you're at, DocuSign will make sure you get to where you want to be.
cons: Absolutely none, out of the 6 companies I've worked for I've never seen so much employee investment.

headline: Good culture, great trajectory
pros: DocuSign has been a great place to work, with a fast-paced environment that rewards individuals who take initiative. There are lots of opportunities to take on new responsibility, or setup the foundation for new areas of process and progress for the company.
cons: The company is growing so fast that priorities change quickly, which takes personalities that are open and adaptable.

headline: Not all it's cracked up to be
pros: They hire great people and have a high level of flexibility when it comes to understanding work/life balance.
cons:
Incredibly low pay for those in sales roles (probably the lowest I've heard of in the tech space) coupled with unrealistic quotas (20% of team is hitting - most of those people are on ramp).

DocuSign tends to promote managers that are consistently critiqued and disliked. It's almost as though the less you are liked, the more DocuSign wants to promote you. Culture is toxic, management feeds into this and has a blind kool-aid view as if we are the same company that we were in 2010. News flash - times have changed. Rip the bandaid off and get rid of poor leadership.

Literally no training. None. If you are not being promoted internally please do not waste your time interviewing here. If think that jumping into a sales career here is a good move, I promise you it is not. Go elsewhere (you'll absolutely be paid more, have more training, and can almost guarantee you'll have better management).

Favoritism, bro-culture.

headline: Fantastic Place To Work - Culture is everything here
pros: Customer Focus is key.  People are collaborative, supportive, very little politics.  Product is outstanding and results in very few customer sat issues.  Strong compensation package.
cons: Very few, benefits are getting better.  401k matching happened in last 12 months, medical benefits could improve some, especially for non-HQ employees

headline: na
pros: Awesome benefits, work space, and perks.
cons: There’s no cons to working here

headline: Doing the Work of my Life
pros: I've been here a year and it's the best move I've made.    The product is undeniably amazing and they continue to find ways to make it better and cater to the customers needs.  Leadership takes the time to hear you and get in the trenches with you as a team.  If you don't understand what the Work of your Life is, they'll sit down and help you thought it.  The people, culture and over-all values are spot on and based on that, I would retire here.
cons: There are growing pains as every company has but DocuSign tackles each one and puts their best foot forward.

headline: Best company to work for
pros: DocuSign is just amazing in every way! Great pay, benefits, culture, and leadership is great too!
cons: The commute into the office is horrible, that's the only con I can think of.

headline: Would not recommend to black people
pros: I met some decent people.
cons:
My manger only wanted yes men around and if you weren’t stroking her miserable ego she hated you. She tried to fire me for no reason and put me on a PIP. I reported her to HR and after they talked to her she found other ways to torture me piling on more work than anyone can handle etc. 

Eventually I couldn’t work there unless I was gonna fight her so I quit. Then I heard she got promoted after i left smh. 

Many black employees had similar experiences during this time and were basically forced to quit. 

Managers and CEO are personally aware of these issues but refuse to do implicit bias training because they say it’s “reverse racism”

headline: You want to work here
pros:
Exceptional leadership - you will learn quickly, be challenged, and be rewarded.
Plenty of growth so plenty of promotion/career growth opportunities
Fast moving - no boredom here, very dynamic
Great people culture - fair pay, bonuses, stock, and excellent (no cost) benefits package, plus they match your charitable giving and lots of paid time off opportunity to volunteer in your community
Global team - you will work with people from around the world
cons: There's been some growing pains as the company has more than quadrupled in size over the last five years, but nothing that won't be solved by the experienced leaders hired in the past few years

headline: Decent, but I have seen better

Great C level leadership, CEO seems to care about employees
Docusign brand
Decent benefits
Product engineering gets twice a week lunch, which is weird but nice
Opportunities to learn
Regular surveys/employee feedback
cons:
-Not all teams have good work culture. Being SDET in particular sucks. There are emails from release managers/on call person on every Saturday/Sunday asking you to investigate failures.  Work life balance is poor and lot of folks being in their first job or without family commitments seem to be fine with it. SDET management is political and condescending. There is favoritism, lack of transparency.  It seems that equally bad both Seattle and SF. 
-Tech stack is outdated.

headline: So far so good

cons: None yet but since I have to enter 5 words I will say that the amount of beef jerky in the FREE packages is pretty light,  one must have at least two packs to fulfill a jerky craving.

headline: Great benefits and supportive team

headline: Great company

pros:
RSUs, excellent customer success organization, amazing product.

Great career starter for anyone under 30.
cons:
If you are a seasoned Account Manager, think twice before choosing DocuSign.

Poor sales leadership, no training for managers, very young, very inexperienced. Toxic work culture for Account Managers. Management has created a shadow culture of favoritism, nepotism, and hostility against the rest. Management has no longitudinal view of their business. Everything is a scramble, everything is due yesterday. 

Account Managers have to smile, have "yes men" mentality, and are worked night and day. No real recognition or career pathing. Career discussions are merely a charade designed to target AMs who have low job satisfaction. 

Many AMs are treated poorly by their AE "partners", and AM leadership will not have your back. AMs are a "junk drawer" for the activities that AEs don't want to do. AEs and RVPs have all the power. AMs are not empowered, have responsibility for accounts/renewals/growth quota, but no authority, as the AEs are the relationship "owners". This creates an intrinsic conflict, and there are no ROEs or swim lanes.

No deal desk, unrealistic quotas, book shuffle ever few months, which makes relationship development a challenge. I was told I would be managing 40 accounts when I started, at one point I had over 90.

If you need help internally, good luck. "Everyone for themselves" mentality, instilled and reinforced by leadership.

Fyi: employees are instructed and pushed to give Glassdoor reviews right out of the gate, before they've even really start the job.

headline: Recruitment Process DocuSign in Dublin
pros: Great team and work atmosphere!
cons: There are no contras that I could think of

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great people, good benefits, and solid company
cons: Can be tough to move up

headline: Both positives and negatives across the board
pros:
The product is one that everyone can use. 
People. Many smart talented people that bring fresh ideas
cons:
Passive aggressive culture in particular on the Sales leadership side.  
Bro culture and frat mentality in the sales organization which makes it hard if you are not part of the "in" crowd.  Driven from the top. 
Favortism definitely is shown.
Favortism plays a part in decision making which is very frustrating.

headline: Great company! Much love.
pros: The benefits are insane. I moved from the other side of the country and I don’t believe people realize on the west coast how good they have it here. The team I’m on is fantastic and I feel I fit in great. Everyone is slightly nerdy which I absolutely love because that’s me too haha! It is software sales so it was what I was expecting. I’m so grateful for the opportunity to excel. The career path from SDR-MDR-AE looks tough but it’s definitely there. To be an AE you will have to work hard and become an actual professional which is how it should be. Everyone is super supportive and the CEO is funny and down to earth.
cons: The ramp up for the MDR role is craziness. I hate seeing other reviews on here of people complaining about unrealistic targets or whatever. It’s sales. Don’t be in sales if you can’t handle the heat! Besides, the targets were just lowered a bit for the MDRs and they’re definitely fair. You do have to work rly hard but you should already know  sales is like that. That’s not even a con because the commission is fair.

headline: Best place I have ever worked at!!
pros: Awesome place to work at. Makes me feel like I matter.
cons: Getting too big too soon!

headline: Sales Development Representative
pros: Great sales org, management strive to boost morale with new incentives frequently in the fast paced environment.  Mentoring to promote staff consistently
cons: Onboarding is great but the information provided at the beginning for learning and getting to know the company in the first few weeks is hefty so can be a little overwhelming

headline: Don't challenge just accept you are just à number
pros: Great product but every couple of years change what the focus is
cons: If you challenge you are targeted. Too much focus on numbers rather than people.  Senior management are not real people persons and they will soon lose the good ones.  It appears to be one rule for them and sales and others are just targets.

headline: Micromanagement - a case study in a startup
pros: Wonderful concept within the company of driving a new strategy for movement of important documents to the cloud
cons: Micromanagement. Lack of recognition, High stress, High pressure. Undermarket wages. Executive bickering and too much politicking.

headline: Sdr
pros:
Good people
Nice working environment 
Growing and interesting company
cons: Less and less flexibility

headline: Great place to work
pros: Positive culture, Transparency, Accessible execs
cons: Growing so fast that office space is running out

headline: Solution Consultant
pros: very interesting job so far
cons: no cons at the moment

headline: Chaos
pros: The people and the product
cons: Political shenanigans in the London office. Leadership micromanaging rather then leading. Culture in London office is being eroded by  poor executive leadership in certain areas, particularly the Customer Success Org.

headline: Good people, good product
pros:
- Great, simple, & popular product/brand, so it makes for a relatively easy sell when you're selling to the right market
- Great team of people. Fun. Down to Earth. Helpful. Kind. 
- Easy to achieve quota when in the right industry/geographic region (see cons)
cons:
- If you're not in the right vertical, sales can be extremely difficult hence makes it hard to hit quota. Alternatively, if you're in a good vertical (i.e. lucrative industry or wealthy/hi-tech city/state) you can make a lot of money. You have no control over this, so when it sucks it really sucks. When I worked here, quota wasn't adjusted for different verticals based on these factors , so it made for a very uneven playing field. 

- Very fratty environment. And while everyone is really nice, most people don't want to work in a frat house. 

- Not as many benefits offered when compared to other successful tech companies in SF (i.e. minimal rideshare credits, no every day lunch, etc...)

headline: Great place to work
pros: great work/life balance,  great perks, GREAT people, meaningful work
cons: nothing that other big companies don't have

headline: Warmth, Care for People & Environment, Family-Like Culture
pros: DocuSign is a company that exudes warmth, genuinely cares about its people and the environment, and has a family-like culture. Rounding out my second year at DocuSign, and I love working for an employer that wants to make a difference. There's a solid emphasis on manager development, a program that keeps growing and improving. At the company level, the CEO consistently listens to the workforce and outlines the groundwork for improvements based on employee survey feedback. Teams are high-performing and collaborative, although, this may vary slightly across the organization. Hyper growth is starting to encourage upgrades in infrastructure, tools, and processes. Looking forward to the next two years, DocuSign!
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Really fun
pros: Fun culture, good benefits, good snacks
cons: Extremely low pay, unorganized at times

headline: Best company I have ever worked for
pros: Generous compensation, great and brilliant people to work alongside, excellent benefits, the kitchen is so stocked you could literally live at the office, catered lunches a few times a week, etc.  One of the best parts for me is being challenged to build and improve our global network with very little restraint so long as the outcome is a better performing network for our customers.  I feel like I don't work a day in my life sometimes because I absolutely love what I do here.  Great family/work balance also.
cons: None.  While some would consider hard work, occasional long hours or a high level of commitment to success a "con", this is the work ethic you should have in any job.

headline: Great people
pros: enjoyed my time at DocuSign. worked with smart and nice people
cons: salary is low. and career advancement is slow

headline: 2+ Years in Sales Org
pros:
(all for Sales Org)
-clear path to promotion (went from SDR to MDR to AE in just over 2 years)
-transparent leadership
-managers are constantly given leadership-training opportunities 
-attainable quotas
-incredibly supportive and fun coworkers
-work/life balance is essential - able to make your own schedule for the most part, and when things come up, managers are understanding 
-from entry level sales position, have ability to move into BD, account management, sales ops, leadership roles
cons: -pay for entry level roles is fairly similar to other tech firms, but grows immensely with every promotion

headline: Software Engineer - bait and switch!
pros: Nice office, good snacks, good view depending on your floor (Seattle). Onboarding experience is mostly good.
cons:
I was told by recruiting that there is catered lunch Mon/Wed. This is only for the product team which I found out after I started.
Software engineering standards are antiquated at best, don't expect to see any current best practices. People here (except sales) are mostly not very social, and are pretty heads-down. Work hours are not flexible.

headline: For those who want to pledge a disorganized fraternity
pros: Good benefits, decent office, volunteer day is great, work life balance is pretty good
cons: No transparency from management, favoritism consumes the sales org, unhealthy and uninspiring competition, no opportunity for growth beyond a linear track, pay is lower than most SDR/BDR SaaS positions, questionable selling values

headline: UNBELIEVEABLE- this is the place to be
pros:
- Perks: snacks, food, 401K, ESPP, cell allowance, gym allowance.
- People: smart, creative, talented, collaborative people from other tech giants. 
- Opportunity:  across the board every gets promoted within >1-2 years here and everyone expects to keep moving up.
- Execution: this company gets it, their business execution is well thought out both internally and externally -from compensation, to rules of engagement, to go to market strategy,  promotion timelines, everything just makes sense- A WELL OILED MACHINE.
-  Product: we are the true market leader and the demand and brand recognition is tremendous.
cons:
- base salary could be a tad higher compared to other top tech companies but the RSU's provided and the aggressive commission plan does make up the difference.
- there is  somewhat of a divide between SpringCM and DocuSign employees.  The SpringCM side has more of a corporate feel while DocuSign has more of a start up feel.  There is a clash between the two cultures.

headline: Best place to work
pros:
Best work culture, people are genuine and nice, very willing to help each other
Fantastic executive staff and leadership team.  It’s has the least politics among Bay Area companies that I have observed.  This helps the organization stay aligned and transparent most of the times 
Bright people to work with who are fun and willing to go an extra miles
cons: Perks and benefits are still behind the Bay Area giant corporation

headline: Great experience!
pros: Awesome culture, support, and work!
cons: i don't have any cons

headline: Fun
pros: I have fun with the culture
cons: Pay is lower than most other companies

headline: Fun
pros: It is a really fun place to work.
cons: strange management at times, can be confusing.

headline: Great company made mediocre
pros:
- Autonomy on how you sell
- Great product and recognised brand
- Good pay and package
- Fun colleagues
cons:
- Pre-historic work from home policy. If you work at DocuSign UK in sales, you have an absolute 0% of working from home. 
- Paid late 3 times this year alone
- Company policy you can’t take holiday 2 weeks before end of quarter
- 0 career progression if you are based in London. Everything is being based out of Dublin (management roles). This has been confirmed by a Senior Manager.
- Feels like there is 0 trust from management in their AE’s

headline: Supportive Environment
pros:
-High energy and fun place to work
-Very supportive 
-Everyone wants you to succeed, even your peers
cons:
-Long hours 
-No flexibility with working from home

headline: Best place I've ever worked
pros: Great product, benefits, and company culture
cons: Growing pains - need more resources to train the more junior members of the team.

headline: Management is not transparent
pros: Really good co-workers, great location. Good for the environment
cons: Management wants you to drink the Kool Aid - do the work of your life - Bah if they didn’t pay us we wouldn’t  show up to work.  It’s just a job not a calling.

headline: Helping make companies more agreeable
pros: DocuSign is an incredible company. I've never been a part of a company where everyone is so genuinely supportive and willing to go out of there way to help others out. The culture and tone is set from the top down -- you truly feel empowered to do the best work of your life here. It's an extremely exciting time for the company as we are expanding our offerings and ability to help customers become more agreeable. Plenty of opportunity for growth, great benefits and compensation packages.
cons: Honestly, none come to mind. All positive experiences thus far.

headline: Good Company to work for but some managers need lessons in Ego Reduction
pros: Enjoy working at Docusign the atmosphere is excellent and the building is cool, events going on all the time and relaxed vibe.
cons: My experience is some managers have ego issues where they want to be better than you at everything. I've had managers want to show they are better at physical feats than me, others who have been disgruntled for a day because i came in nicer clothes than them on the day. Alot of do better but no direction or path of how to do that.  Career opportunties are not good.

headline: A little chaotic, but fun; Good people
pros:
Fun, intelligent people to work with. 

You fee like you are contributing to a product that is practical and useful, rather than the next tech fad that might be gone tomorrow. 

Lots of growth = lots of opportunity.
cons: There was a focus on growth, which made sense. To meet targets, we sometimes scrambled to do SOMETHING, which is better than nothing, but doesn't necessarily lead to a cohesive strategy. This can make it confusing to middle management and individual contributors why they are doing what they are doing, which makes it more difficult to be completely bought in.

headline: MDR Review
pros:
-Great benefits
-Great culture
-Always have fun team events/food
cons: -As an MDR - you work really hard for a low base, some of the verticals are a lot harder than others which creates a really stressful environment.

headline: One of the best places I have ever worked in my career
pros: Culture, amazing culture!  It starts from the top down and it is felt throughout.  I believe we have one of the best executive teams in the business from both a strategic vision and business perspective as well a culture perspective.  Very hard to do!   And they have!
cons: Simple and normal growing pains. Nothing unusual.

headline: Enjoying every working day
pros:
Great and innovative product/solution
Amazing team and management - very transparent and open
Always a way to be creative and develop
Very healthy environment
Good benefits
cons: As with any customer facing position you might deal with not very pleasant people sometimes on a customer end - nothing that can be done with it

headline: Quality People
pros: Primarily very quality, hard-working people that are fun to work with
cons: Can still feel like a start-up at times with how departments converse

headline: Toxic
pros: Cool office, some nice people... Dan Springer is a cool guy. Trip to Seattle for training.
cons: Management, massive egos, severely toxic environment. Don’t listen to concerns about bettering your work performance let alone concerns regarding workplace bullying / harassment. Massive boys club culture

headline: Has some areas for improvement
pros:
Smart, driven colleagues
Free snacks 
Fun events like happy hours and crafting 
Some teams really got along well and looked very happy working together
cons:
Lack of diversity and inclusion
Office space crammed 
My team was aloof to my joining and it continued throughout the time I was there. My direct manager was great but the other members were cold and uninviting. Hard to get things done that way. Other comments were right saying it’s a frat/sorority culture. 
Communication between departments needs improvement; everyone is worried about their agenda and definitely has an “I” attitude. 
You’re either going to fit into the culture and love it or feel unwelcomed and like an outsider. 
Not a fan of Docusign’s pushiness for current employees to review them on Glassdoor so that they can be on top.

headline: Solid foundation, still work to do
pros: Product and vision; enthusiastic customers; challenging work; intelligent colleagues ; flexible (but high workload)
cons: Ineffective middle management; unilateral decision making and lack of transparency fuel negativity; pay problems: not paid on time (last few months), plans/targets not provided for consecutive quarters for commission based role (since joining)

headline: Great Entry Sales Job
pros: There is a lot of team camaraderie . Everyone in the corporation is pushing you to succeed. From your fellow reps to management and the CEO. There is a "we are all in this together" mentality and that pushes everyone to do their best and work for not only their paycheck, but work for the well being of your team and leadership. If there are questions do not be afraid to ask, somene will always know the answer and there will always be a friendly person to help out.
cons: None at this point in time.

headline: Great people, great product, difficulties with pay
pros: The product is really good, customers love it. The roadmap is strong and the company is heading in a great direction. Colleagues are great, DocuSign hires highly intelligent people and there is a strong sense of teamwork across the different teams and departments.  Offices are well equiped. WFH policy is flexible and fair. DocuSign has a lot going for it
cons: For some reason, DocuSign struggles with paying, deciding how to pay and when to pay their employees. We have had multiple delays on salary payment. Compensation plans seem to be a struggle. One team has reached the halfway point of the year (consecutive years) without compensation plans which has had an effect on the surrounding teams. We have had issues with tax on more than one occasion. If it wasn't for these issues it would be a 4/5 but DocuSign can't seem to get the basics right. There are some other issues, internal communication isn't great, product and otherwise. We regularly find out people leave in EMEA when we try to email them, this applies at all levels. No clear structures for career path as far as I can tell in most roles.

headline: Nice place to work, great product lines
pros: Diverse company culture, and have been making positive business decisions benefiting both employees and product advancement
cons: Need to further streamline initial training

headline: Work or fall behind
pros:
-great management that provides boundaries but not necessarily rules
-satisfying job, if you don't like the constant winning and losing then get out of sales.
-when applied correctly, you naturally groom yourself for the next role. You can do the hard things now that make tomorrow easy, or you can take the easy road now and make tomorrow harder.
cons: -lower base salary than competitors (not complaining, just a fact)

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Flexibilty, benefits, healthcare, culture, good team events
cons: sales model isn't perfect, there are some egos in the office

headline: Drinking culture and low pay
pros: It is really easy to hit quota, great snacks, only have to work 8 hours a day, great PTO and benefits
cons: Manager might show up high or drunk on any given day (causes anxiety), extremely low compensation, micromanaging, only can move on in sales roles

headline: T2 Tech Support Dublin
pros:
- Amazing benefits: Life insurance, Pension matched at 7%, Health insurance paid by the company, shares, Employee stock purchase plan, Incentives for fitness, phone bill refunded, Volunteer time off...

- Free snacks and drinks on site plus other food to make sandwhiches provided.

- Salary very competitive compared to other similar positions

- Company is growing fast, meaning a lot of career opportunities, fast promotions if you are good. 

- The annual review process for your performance every year which often results in a raise of salary + more shares granted

- The product and the company are helping save the environment by reducing paper usage around the world, it is fulfilling to know your work drives this. 

- Senior leadership is listening to complaints and suggestion and applies improvements from one year to the next. 

- Direct managers are very good, quick to reply to your questions and asks, no micromanagement. I always feel like they listen to my complaints and act on them quickly.

- Good communication between management, senior leadership, and lower employees.

- 

- Great company culture, inclusive, supportive and great work-life balance. You feel like you are a part of the team.

- the eSignature market is a very big potential market, of which DocuSign is the leader.
cons:
- No canteen and meals as with other similar tech companies, although we are provided free snacks, drinks, fruits and enough to make sandwiches and salad.

- No games room in the office for casual fifa or street fighter matches with colleagues 

- Communication between some teams could be improved somewhat . Generally I feel like the Sales department has not enough training on the product, and as result support deals with some issues that could be resolved or answered at their level. Similarly, support often gets questions that pertain to the sales part of the job, and that sales should be able to answer, but as they are not trained enough on the product, it ends up with support which sometimes creates a back and forth.

- I don't really have other cons to be honest.

headline: Great energy
pros: Really good path here.  Clear expansion of products and direction from up top on where the company is headed and how we will get there.  There is a great amount of new things in pipeline to sell to and the amount of leads don't appear to be short.  People are good and care about their success.  Access to VPs and C Suite has never been easier for me.
cons: Sales managers can really get into the weeds on things, you essentially have two people running each deal.  Employees are all cordial and helpful but aren't necessarily friends or lasting relationships.

headline: Good people - Strong vision - Exciting opportunity
pros:
-Great culture, good people, solid management

-Product portfolio that Customer’s truly value

-Agreement Cloud strategy is spot on with a chance to define its own category. Plenty of growth and opportunity for employees and the business
cons: Minor growing pains but no true cons.

headline: Still very amazing company, some growing pains
pros: Great work environment/culture, great people, great perks, and still often feels like a small company
cons: Starting to get bogged down by too much red tape. Any hiring/hr process takes far too long and every department I know of is short staffed.

headline: Fantastic company at rapid growth, great people, great leadership and great products
pros:
A fantastic company at rapid growth (37% YoY in FY18
Great people - the culture is great. People have a sense of comradery and shared excitement
The leadership is top-notch with a clear vision and ability to execute
Great benefits and total comp is very comprehensive
Our products are great - I constantly get an "I LOVE DocuSign" reaction when I tell people where I work, because the product is so loved (how many B2B SW companies can say that?)
We're at an exciting time for our company, transitioning to a multi-product company, with all the opportunities, and challenges, that this brings
Plenty of room for continued growth - our total addressable market is $50B and this year we'll get to $1B in Revenue (so, being the biggest player out there in this space, this suggests plenty of room to grow)
Plenty of career growth opportunities - I have seen many upward, as well as lateral career moves in my 4 years at DocuSign, including my personal upward move from an individual contributor to a manager of a team, which is what I wanted to do
cons:
The company is large and getting things done does require navigating bureaucracy. 
With the rapid growth and all that we're trying to do, it can feel a bit chaotic at times. We're figuring things out as we go. To me, that's exciting but may not suit everyone. 
As solid of a company we are, our brand is not as "sexy" as some of the other Silocone Valley darlings (think Slack, Uber, etc.).

headline: Great Team, Great Company
pros: Tons of pros it's a great company!
cons: None that come to mind!

headline: If you are young and ambitious, do not work here!
pros: DocuSign is a big company. You get a lot of perks that most big companies support. They just added in a plan for gym memberships.
cons:
I have had multiple managers at DocuSign and have worked in quite a few roles. My last manager would talk down to me. Treat me (a female) different from the other male employees. When I brought this to HR, DocuSign was so interested in making sure there wasnt a lawsuit that no one really cared about how I felt. 
I was also once called entitled by a VP of a department for asking to be compensated the same as the rest of the team. Background, I am the youngest on the team. The response: I was called entitled. And even though this VP apologized, I will never forget the feeling of hating the fact that I was young and just wanted to be treated like everyone else. If you are young and you want to make money, just dont pick DocuSign. Or better yet, pick it and then leave after a year. I wish I left earlier.

headline: I "Hit the Jackpot" Getting Hired into the DocuSign Family
pros: Warm welcome, excellent on boarding support, a culture of support
cons: The company is bursting with growth so it can be difficult to help place new employees.

headline: Tier 2 Support
pros: Competitive salary, great benefits, stock options, great atmosphere, multicultural environment, flexible hours and good direct managers.
cons: Multiple languages not recognized, communication between Teams could be improved.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Open culture; respect for co-workers
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Great company culture
pros: Great benefits, and great people
cons: Work isnt easy, but it is rewarding

headline: Be Warned - Don't Recommend for Accounting Work
pros: DocuSign as a company has a great culture and benefits. Also, the CEO is down to earth and would like to know and improve employees and their wellness better.
cons:
Company-wide:
Executive-level politics and finger-pointing each other, rather than trying to do the right work, is somewhat pathetic. It's been >1 year since the company went on IPO and everyone still acts like a startup.

Accounting-Specific:
The great culture at DocuSign doesn't apply to the Accounting department. Accounting is still under the old-school ship who does not trust your professionalism.

If you like 90s management style, like micromanagement, no trust from your chief, and having your butt in the chair 9 am to 4 pm every day, this is the place.

headline: Couldn't be happier
pros: Culture. Pay. Leadership (top to bottom).  The product(s). Our Customers. My peers. Growth opportunities.  I honestly can't say enough about how amazing this company is to work for. Nothing is perfect, but if you're lucky enough to land here, you've found a home.
cons: Not much downside... with growth comes change, sometimes adjusting to that change can be daunting, but dust settles and things aren't done here just to do something, there is a method. 100% 401K match would be nice!

headline: Relationships Matter More Than Hard Work
pros: The people that work here are incredible. Great work/life balance and an inviting team environment.
cons: The Market Development Representative role is more dependent on your territory and relationship with your Account Executive than it is your actual sales ability. Promotions are given to those who manipulate the system and work half as hard, opposed to hard working individuals who work in difficult territories with difficult Account Executives.

headline: A Great Place To Work!
pros: A great company with a very fast-paced environment. There's a good atmosphere in the Dublin Office, everyone's very friendly, approachable and makes an effort to introduce themselves to new hires. Employee perks are great (snacks, health, and dental insurance), education assistance program, e-learning as well as the new wellness benefit!
cons:
- There are not enough office events to bring everyone together
- Coffee Machines in the Dublin Office are a disgrace! 
- Management seems to be very focused on the US office that they are overlooking certain needs in EMEA offices
- No work-life balance
- Underskilled managers that lack leadership and communication skills

headline: Market Developement Representative
pros: Very accurate training regarding DocuSign products and also the use of all the tools (Outreach, Salesforce, LinkedIn, SalesNavigator.
cons: Competitive environment which risks to be counter productive mentally speaking, when not reaching quota

headline: DocuSign is the only company I've loved enough to leave one of these reviews ;)
pros: Leadership, Product vision, Culture, Pay, Trust
cons: Culture should not be built around only the 20 something's... :)

headline: Amazing place to work
pros: Strong leadership, passionate employees who love what they do, great benefits and perks. Opportunities to continue to build on your skills and advance your career.
cons: Not so much a con but an opportunity for us to improve the way we work together and remove some of the internal silos that happen just with a growing company.

headline: Decent people, good market opportunity, lots of red tape for such a small company
pros: Plenty of of both intelligent and nice colleagues. Not too many underachievers, and everyone does seem to strive to do their best work.  The market opportunity for the company is huge, and they're the leader in the space, just a matter of execution. Compensation is relatively competitive (but do negotiate).  Starting to get some better enterprise collaboration tools, but those are still relatively immature in their implementation.
cons: Definitely feels more like a Seattle company than a SF Bay Area company. They'll tell you that they're HQ'd in SF, but a sizable chunk (maybe even half) are still in Seattle where they started, so don't expect to work face-to-face with a lot of colleagues. Video conferencing is in its infancy here, so it makes dealing with remote folks even more difficult, especially since the rooms aren't enabled for VC and nothing is integrated. Similarly, if you're expecting large, Silicon Valley company-like perks and benefits, look elsewhere. Healthcare is decent, but really for employee-only -- definitely gets more expensive if you try to add children or a spouse. Additionally, they don't provide any kind of meals so you'll be on your own for that. Likewise, they still use PTO instead of unlimited time off, and that includes your sick days. There are no company shutdowns either so expect to have to use all of your PTO and have a full inbox waiting for you when you return.  For a company as small as it is there's an incredible amount of red tape surrounding processes and technology -- to the point where it can make it very difficult to get actual business done. Definitely a squeaky wheel gets the grease/escalation culture, so be on the lookout for that.

headline: Transparent, open, horizontal, trusting culture at a company with a $50 billion dollar market opportunity
pros:
-People, product, potential
-Huge market opportunity
-Customers are happy with the product, prospects get the value proposition
-A tech company that does good in the world (DocuSign for Forests and Impact Committee) 
-Leadership that listens to employees (example: recently added Fitness benefit) 
-Great training
cons:
-Growing pains with growth and transitioning to Agreement Cloud sales methodology
-Sometimes doesn't change fast enough

headline: Best place I've ever worked
pros:
A group of well-qualified co-workers who put their heads together to find good solutions. Close work with Product, Testing and Development. 
Across the board compensation levels that say “we want to keep you around”.
cons: Nothing comes to mind now.

headline: Fantastic, Forwarding Thinking Company with High Value on Employee Success
pros: Employee focused, environmentally conscious company that promotes equal opportunities to those most qualified. This is a fast growing company with plenty of opportunity, executing on a vision that looks to change the landscape of business. Day to day benefits of free coffee and snacks, comfortable working hours and spaces and access to amenities like building gyms and musical equipment are all great benefits.
cons: None to speak of at this point.

headline: Love it!
pros: DocuSign really lives up to the expectations for company culture & work/life balance. I have been here for less than a year and each day brings a new opportunity to build and invest in your career.
cons: No cons for me so far!

headline: Best product and culture for a hungry sales professional!
pros:
Flexible work/life balance
Everyone knows DocuSign, which leads to amazing brand recognition
Market opportunity  - paper/pen is still status quo in 2019
Great leadership - they prefer to promote from within and most are easy to seek mentorship
cons: At times, there are growing pains, but that's consequence of a fast paced successful company.

headline: One of the top companies for a reason
pros:
* encouraging and inclusive culture
* interesting, reliable, and innovative product line
* great work life balance
* amazing company morale

Within the first day at DocuSign, I knew this company was going to a great fit. The culture is so warm, inviting, and inclusive while also hard working and driven. It is very obvious that the employees  want each other to succeed and do their best to propel this business.
cons: I have nothing to put here, literally.

headline: Everyone should apply here
pros: Excellent working environment, offer employees great benefits that keep everyone motivated. Train their employees to be consistently successful more than any other company I've worked for.
cons: The different offices all have different styles to them that some maybe friendlier than others.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Growing company, innovative products, small-company feel with large-company resources. Supportive and friendly workplace, collaboration with teams across the country.
cons: Diversity in hiring and leadership is still sub-par, but DocuSign is starting to put a bigger focus on a stronger inclusion program.

headline: DocuSign - Loving my new home
pros: Our CEO literally has his finger on the pulse of what our employees are  asking for/saying, and he openly addresses all feedback - good or constructive.  Our COO has our road map for success planned and is very transparent in where we are going in 1-3 years...  Executive Leadership team is approachable.
cons: Growing from 1 product to multiple has it's challenges - creates a new way of thinking for our product and sales teams.  While it's a great opportunity for most, it's harder for those who've been at the company longer to embrace the change that is needed to grow as a company.

headline: Love it!
pros: People at DocuSign are actually supportive, friendly, and caring. Such a great work environment where managers and co-workers want to see you succeed and help you - always.
cons: I would say the commute benefit

headline: First few months
pros: Everyone at DocuSign has been very helpful. They really care about your success and make that evident in the first few weeks of training. They reward hard work here with their commission structure and spiff incentives. I feel like I've already learned so much and I am excited for whats to come!
cons: Base salary could be higher. Sick days shouldn't be part of the 4 weeks pto.

headline: Look No Further
pros:
One of the best companies anyone could ever work for. 
They treat their employees fairly, are dedicated to the success of their employees, have great work life balance, and very responsive management.
Culture is outstanding, you feel welcome and at home starting day 1. Benefits are outstanding.
cons: Large sales organization makes for a more difficult promotion

headline: Leadership makes the difference
pros: Utmost confidence in the vision for the company and the people leading it. A very exciting place to work, growing like crazy.
cons: Growth always has its challenges.

headline: One of the best places to work in Seattle
pros: Fast paced fun work environment with ample opportunities to grow with the company
cons: New hire MDR's have no say as to what segment you are put into. Could create a disadvantage to new hires as they might not be put into the appropriate vertical e.g. Real Estate, Financial Services, Healthcare, Government

headline: Recruiting
pros: It's a great working atmosphere, really friendly people who want you to succeed an grow your career.  Somewhere you can be yourself and speak up, you will be heard by all levels of management. Have outgrown our current office so will be on the move to the hub of silicon docks.
cons:
We are running out of office space.
Need to have more office events to network with the whole office as we are divided into two floors. Want to be able to showcase our local culture across social channels.

headline: Awesome company with great leadership!
pros:
During the past 20 years I've worked for large and small tech companies like IBM, Salesforce. DocuSign is truly the best company I've worked for by far. 

I respect our leadership team's ability to align the company and execute on our visions. Our CEO is humble, kind and inspiring. 

Its great to see the company's transformation from an eSignature company to an Agreement Cloud Company, allowing tremendous opportunities for growth. 

People work hard here, but work life balance is real
cons: The company is growing at a rapid rate, and we don't have the right resources in Real Estate planning to scale the growth. Work space challenges can be  a major pain point for employees

headline: Taking it to the Next Level
pros:
DocuSign is a company with a self-improvement culture.   We're always asking, how can we take things to the next level. For example, in the last couple years, we've advanced from being a primarily one-product company to a cloud suite of offerings. Engineering is focused on learning from every incident, making sure it doesn't happen again, and actively educating on best practices. We're looking for people who care about our customers and care about the people they work with and want to make things better.
1. The people. We hire people who are smart, good communicators, skilled, experienced and have good strong fits for their positions; and also friendly, collaborative and pleasant. 
2. The product. DocuSign builds its own infrastructure to the standards of Banks and Governments. Our Document Transaction Management service is extremely flexible and customizable. The breadth of our integrations provides a rich pipeline of capabilities.  DocuSign's technology is so visionary that it becomes a system of systems, able to integrate across multiple dimensions.
3. The leadership. Dan Springer and his leadership team bring talent and experience, but also a best-in-class mindset that shows in our strategy and initiatives. Last year's acquisition of SpringCM was brilliant and is such a strong fit for our vision.  DocuSign's leadership really gets it. At every All Hands we talk about how to make DocuSign the place where you do the work of your life.
cons:
They run out of Diet Coke's on my floor all the time.
One challenge in Engineering is that we don't have enough Senior Directors, that is upper-middle hands-on technical leadership. We have solid VP's, and we have solid Managers and Directors, but we need more of those strong organizational leaders who can lead mid to large size teams though technical transitions. It's hard to find and hire  truely excellent upper-middle leaders because that role is so competitive. 
I'd say that our technology stack is not as agile as we'd like to modernize and decouple and adopt new technologies and platforms. Our ultrahigh reliability bar has a downside in that any change to the system must go through so many checks and balances that code velocity is a little disappointing.  The flip side of playing in so many regulated markets is that the compliance demands make change difficult.  Basically, even stronger leadership through technical evolution of a 7-10 year old code base will enable us leverage greater technical innovation.
Stock price can be volatile  but we're in it to win it and not focused on the short term.

headline: This place got it right
pros: I've been with DocuSign for about 9 months now, and enjoy coming to work just as much as when I started.  I feel supported through my manager and coworkers to come in and be successful day in and day out.  The office environment is especially notable and great to be in.  I am able to see my impact of my work each day  and truly have no complaints about this role, people, or company.  Clear job progression is evident as well, very few people leave the company after this role.  The CEO Dan Springer and upper management are leading this company to continue to do great things.
cons: I am happy to say that I cannot find any fault with this company or role at this time.

headline: Great Place To Make A Difference
pros: DocuSign's vision, people, and drive for excellence. Even more so, our passion for our customer's success persists long after the sale – something that is keenly important to me. Most memorable and enjoyable times are during pushes where I work with fellow DocuSign colleagues all over the world - virtual and/or in person. It’s a great feeling to look back and know that we built something great together that still stands, still makes a positive impact. Benefits & compensation are very competitive & comprehensive. For example, the only thing I worry about when I go to the dentist is the poking and prodding – no worries around the generous coverage and small co-pays. In short, this is a great place where one can do their best work and still have a good life outside of work.
cons: Still waiting for DocuSign to open an office in Hawaii.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
- Awesome benefits. Free health insurance for individuals, snacks, frequent food in the office, 3% 401k match, ESPP, and more!
- People are really nice and positive. I feel happy to come to work every day.
- Great work/life balance
- Leader in a strong, growing business
- Good communication and training
cons:
- Some problems were solved prior to better, open-source solutions being created so you have to work with weird, home-grown software
- Process and intra-team communication can sometimes get in the way of getting things done most efficiently.

headline: Fantastic First Job Out of College
pros: Great atmosphere, people, and opportunity. Management is fantastic. A lot of room for career progression and growth.
cons: Growing so fast that it's losing some of the unique & better qualities of a smaller company (as expected with .

headline: Love this company!
pros:
Fast paced 
Fair compensation 
Great management
High energy team atmosphere
cons: Faced pace means it can move to quickly as well.

headline: Good sales path
pros:
- Work freedom
- Team size 
- Team spirit 
- Career evolution 
- Management
cons: - Not a real culture

headline: A Truly Great Company
pros: Smart colleagues who are also great people and dedicated to driving excellence.  Great benefits and the company continues to improve the benefit offerings such as a very generous parental leave, educational assistance, Employee Stock Purchase Plan,  401(k) match, etc. Lots of efforts recently on developing people managers and enhancing our career opportunities.
cons: The company is expanding rapidly so some systems and processes have not caught up, although they recently introduced some technology tools to help communication and productivity.

headline: MDR
pros: Great Product, great strategic vision, great integrations
cons: Office politics are sometimes detrimental to the trust employees can have

headline: Modernizing the way Agreements are made in Japan while Respecting Culture
pros:
Investment and executive commitment form HQ to the Japanese market.  
Great office with the view of Tokyo bay and Tokyo  Tower.  Open work  environment.  We have the rare opportunity to change and modernize how Japanese companies and consumers  reach agreements by speeding up processes, reducing cost, and increasing compliance.
cons: It does take time to change business culture that has been around in Japan for centuries.  Some traditional companies/industries are not yet ready to move from paper based manual process to an all digital process, even though the younger employees and customers see the value of agreeing electronically.

headline: my review
pros: good working environment and salary
cons: no cons i just need to write something

headline: Absolutely Amazing Company
pros:
-Work life balance exists for those that need it, but they also recognize individuals who go above an beyond
-Amazing benefits, some of which are listed below
-Stock Options (they give RSUs which is amazing)/ ESPP Program and automatically vested match after a short period of time
-They invest in your career development with workshops and trainings on how you can become a better employee and map out your next 2-5 years.
-Company parties are always a great time and we have a fully stocked kitchen with snacks galore
-The work is challenging and different.   I don't feel as though I am repeating the same thing every day and there are new problems to solve
-Traveling is part of my job and docusign makes it easy and has a great expense policy
cons: -Billable hours can sometime seem hard to attain, but they make a lot of exceptions and want you to hit your goals.

headline: I LOVE DOCUSIGN
pros: I could not have picked a more perfect place to work. As someone fresh out of college, I didn't know what a full time job would be like. Working at DocuSign is a dream come true. I look forward to coming into work everyday, feeling respected, having the opportunity to interact with leaders, and loving the people I work with.
cons: There are zero cons at DocuSign.

headline: Work of my life
pros: People, Product & Impact. The people I work with every day are driven, passionate and innovative, the product we sell is best in breed and continues to change with the demands of our customers and finally the impact foundation that the company drives from the top down to help our environment and give back to the community.
cons: A challenge but not a con is the same for any global company, getting time with the other regions for best practice sharing due to time zone of Australia.

headline: BEST JOB EVER!!!!!
pros:
Smart, motivated people
Good Benefits
Flexible work schedule
in San Francisco!
cons: Some people are leaving since they are fully vested after the IPO.

headline: DocuSign puts its people first. Like really.
pros:
I'll keep it simple: This company is bad*ss. And if you want to work here, please do. We like good people. 

LEADERSHIP
Our CEO, Dan Springer has been quoted a few times this year saying that he wants “DocuSign to be the best place anybody ever works.” He means it. His executive team has taken several steps this year in making that aspiration a reality by way of increasing benefits, developing new programs, making strategic investments in both our product suite and portfolio of companies that we’ve now acquired. In turn, DocuSigners that work here have bought into Dan's idea and the culture has shifted. As a company, we’ve had a lot of wins these past 12 months. Few highlights:
- The company IPO’d and has performed consistently quarter over quarter to beat Wall Street expectations - Come on! 
- We acquired SpringCM - a contract lifecycle management company - very cool
- We invested lots of moneys into SEAL Software - #winning
- We launched "The DocuSign Agreement Cloud" - New products to sell! Yay!
- Dan kickstarted "DocuSign Forests", our foundation DocuSign IMPACT's key initiative to restores the world's forests - naturally, we highly dislike paper here. 

If you’re wondering how a CEO’s approval rating could possibly reach above 90%, it’s pretty simple, say what you mean and do what you say, which Dan and his team fulfill on frequently. 

CAREER GROWTH
Joan Burke, our CHRO, made a comment in an all-hands meeting this past year, “People don’t leave companies, they leave managers.” To me, that comment was so simple yet holds so much power in the development of a career. Since then, Joan and her team have rolled out an entire training/development program for managers at DocuSign. And as far as I know, we’ve seen some great results! Our retention rate is one of the best across tech companies (a rarity in SF/SEA) and I’d be hard pressed to find an employee who doesn’t love what they do and love working here. With the company growing at the rate we are, there will be more and more opportunities for people here to grow as a professional. Fortunately for us, our leadership team makes that easy, with lots of resources and support.

COMPENSATION
DocuSign operates on quarterly quotas. From my understanding, compensation packages are competitive across SAAS sales companies. And the benefits are 2nd to none. 

INNOVATION
This is the part that really lights me up. DocuSign has been known for “Signing” documents electronically for the better part of the last 16 years. More or less, we had 1 product that we did really really really well. When Dan joined the company a little over two years ago, one of the main things he pointed out was that we as a company needed to focus on product innovation quarter by quarter. 

This year, DocuSign announced the DocuSign Agreement Cloud. We now have 12 products that salespeople can sell. Why is this important? As a salesperson, imagine that you’re a giant iceberg in the Atlantic Ocean, just doing your thing, chillin’. There’s a large vessel (aka a customer) coming upon you. The people on the vessel say to themselves, “Oh it’s a little iceberg. We’ve seen little icebergs like this before.” What the people on the vessel couldn’t see, was the sheer mass of product underneath the surface ready to disrupt their entire path. If only they could see it, they’d be saved. Fortunately for all the vessels out there, we’re not icebergs. We’re business operations experts. 

Obviously, this is a super silly example though it proves a point. Our customers gain so much value from DocuSign and they’re only just scratching the surface of how they could leverage all the Agreement Cloud products to impact their business. If you've been watching the company stock price and reading analyst reports like me (Sorry, nerd alert here), you'll get a sense of why people outside this company are excited about this company. Lots and lots of upside.  S/O to Ron H, Scott O, Tom C for giving us all the tools! 

BENEFITS 
We’ve got all the good ones (health, vision, dental) Cool benefits we added this year were:
- 401k Matching
- Ripe avocados
- Health/Well-being reimbursement
- $5k/year/employee Education Stipend, air conditioning at your desk, and plants. Lots of new foliage keeps popping up around the office in SF. Its just really great. 
- Panini maker (12th floor in SF only) - Sorry everybody else :P
cons:
My two big gripes are really not even that big of gripes and are more about benefits and/or lack thereof:
