The first thing that comes to mind is my experience at Discovering DocuSign, which is a two day event that new hires attend within the first couple of months of employment. The biggest thing I took away from Discovering DocuSign is that this company does a great job of hiring people that are friendly, caring, and motivate to help others and the company's clients succeed. That was backed up as I got to know my team and others, who all fit that mold completely. I couldn't be happier with the people that I work with, and the company that I work for.

There are, of course, many other pros to working here. The work is interesting, they recently went public and have a great RSU plan, 401k matching will start soon, and the benefits are better than I've received at other top notch companies. But for me, it is the people and the work that stand out the most.
cons: The company is going through an agressive growth phase, recently went public, and is experiencing a significant amount of change. None of these are cons in and of themselves, but if you do not handle change or not knowing very well, I would think very hard about joining this company.

headline: Customer Success Manager
pros: Supportive happy coworkers, flexible, great opportunity to network within the company.
cons: the Customer Success Management department is new, so dealing with the growing pains can be tough sometimes

headline: MDR
pros: Active work environment and a friendly culture. Plenty of amenities from snacks and lunches, to fitness center access, to commuter benefits.
cons: Can't think of any yet!

headline: Senior HR manager
pros: Growing company, great opportunity for career growth, great compensation and benefits, investing in employee career by learning plans, team effort, a place where you can make a difference
cons: growing fast so the org structure is not so clear

headline: Company with an amazing product!
pros: Nice People, Great Learning, Career Growth, Open Culture, and Benefits.
cons: Can get better at cross-functional/cross-team project management.

headline: Highly Recommend Working for Them
pros: Great company! Young, fun and dynamic culture
cons: Growing pains but that happens at any tech company

headline: SDR
pros: - honestly the cons outweigh the pros, when you disregard diversity your whole company suffers there is no growth.
cons: There is no diversity at all. When you walk into Seattle Docusign you will see the lack of diversity right away, it’s really sad because other companies like Amazon are so diverse and like to hire people of multiple backgrounds but that does not go for Docusign.

headline: New Employee - Impressed with the talent, culture
pros: Extremely intelligent, hard working, motivated and skilled team at DocuSign.  They have built a great culture.  Going to be a very fun ride.
cons: A tad complicated in getting started

headline: Great company, benefits & perks; but road block to certain position for growth
pros: Great company,  great benefit & Perks.  401k  match and Educational assistance program coming soon.  Company is moving in the right direction for its employees.
cons: Just on for now, no communication in Finance dept for better growth opportunity and recognition.

headline: Strategic Account Executive - Financial Services
pros: DocuSign is amazingly on trend as large organizations realize they need to move to digital  to compete against younger born-digital competitors.  This secular trend gives DocuSign employees a tremendous opportunity to work and solve interesting problems.  Couple that with the fact that DocuSign has fantastic leadership all the way to the top, means we will continue to grow our share of the market.
cons: We have a lot of work to do..

headline: Year 2 even better than year 1
pros: Fulfilling project load, plenty of team support, great culture, getting quality training as a manager
cons: Office is downtown Seattle, my commute is long. Benefits are still behind, but catching up quickly post IPO.

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: Opportunity for Career Advancement, Collaborative Work Environment, Dedicated Leadership Team, The People - Smart, Fun, Driven, did I mention Fun?!
cons: Accelerated Growth Market which can impact personal time.  Internal operating procedures are slow to adapt to our ever changing sales landscape.

headline: Great place to develop your sales career.
pros:
Great team and great people overall, I was really surprised at how much effort people go through to introduce themselves when you're a new starter. I'm only here a short while but feel very comfortable.

As this was my first "proper" sales role, I needed as much training as I could get. The training didn't disappoint and the trip to Seattle definitely was a fantastic opportunity (my first trip to the US!)

Snacks and drinks are great, lots of healthy options if you want.

Senior management are really friendly and approachable.
cons:
As mentioned by others, some processes aren't clearly defined. But this is also an opportunity to help shape them.

More DocuSign merch; I don't have anything DocuSign branded whereas the new starters now have welcome packs!

headline: Blown Away!
pros:
Amazing work environment, great benefits, company is growing like crazy, top notch talent...
I really enjoy coming into work every day!
cons: Not much, but if I have to be picky, there is no 401k match yet...

headline: Sales
pros: Fun people and great work environment.
cons: Can get a little loud.

headline: Sales Perspective- This place just keeps getting better!!!!!!!!
pros:
Where to begin??
-Amazing culture and leadership
-Great benefits for single employees
-PTO, VTO, paid federal holidays 
-really enforces the necessity of a work-life balance
-continuing education program
-happy hours, team events, IMPACT Day
-stock options, 401k
-free food, catered end of quarters
-good amount of upward mobility (company works with you to identify your strongest fit in the org)
-continued training that is some of the best in the space
cons: -compensation not as high as some similar roles in the greater Seattle area; however, if you value a work-life balance and enjoying your job, this is it!!

headline: Proud to work here
pros:
-Competitive salary
-Benefits are great
-Pregnancy leave is extremely generous (6 months for primary caregiver, 8 weeks for secondary)
-The company is a rocket ship with a very bright future and lot of opportunities to still take advantage of
-It never gets old telling people where I work and hearing "I love DocuSign!"
-The people are great
-Dan Springer (CEO) really knows what he's doing and inspires confidence throughout the organization.
cons:
- No 401k match yet
- Engineering change request process can be painful

headline: Renewal Manager
pros: Great culture and amazing people. Good place to get your foot in the door in tech.
cons: Pay is way below market. Very inefficient internal process's.  Promotions are slow and not a lot of training/learning opportunities.  Management has no issues lying to keep the ship moving forward.

headline: Great place to build a career
pros:
CEO
Company vision
Benefits and parental leave program
cons: Manager development which is continuously improving

headline: Account Executive
pros: Excellent management team, strong values and a clear mission for the organization.
cons: There are growing pains at times but as is to be expected.

headline: Business Development Manager
pros: I would absolutely recommend DocuSign as a top company to work for. From a career development standpoint, the company invests in it's people. It's a great place to understand the SaaS world and solution selling, as well as working with a diverse group of customers. DocuSign is always looking for new and creative ways to approach the market, and will give you the platform to do so. I joined 4 years ago in Sales. After 2 years of success, I switched over to Business Development/partnerships to drive new business from the partner channel. After 2 years of helping grow the business, DocuSign gave me the opportunity to move internationally. My motto: what you put in is what you'll get out and this is a great company to put in your all with!
cons: DocuSign is growing quickly and with that comes some internal challenges. However, I take this as an opportunity to shine and help the company grow.

headline: sales development respresentative
pros: Amazing company culture and a great company to start out your sales career
cons: Promotional path is very strict if your performance is not there

headline: Still here Still loving it
pros: great life/job balance, company is growing and still pays very close attention to it's human side
cons: where the hell  is my DocuCoffee?

headline: A great place to work.
pros: There is a fun, energetic culture that makes it easier to go to work everyday. DocuSign invests in team building activities and makes sure you have a comfortable work environment. You get to meet some of the best people.
cons: Depending on the job, the timeline for promotions are unclear.

headline: Accounting Dept
pros: The company itself was a great place to work. Overall, the people were very nice and friendly. The onboard was great. As any tech company you have the free snacks, drinks, some time lunches, and of course the Friday Happy Hours. The flex hours and benefits were great. Orca and parking reimbursement. Can work from home if needed.
cons: After working with the team I noticed that they were friendly in front of your face but then they would talk behind your back. The team was divided into cliquish group. It was pretty childish. If you were not accepted into the any cliques then your life there was a hard one. You have one supervisor for a group of 3 people and not team leads. No growth available within the department since you have a superior to watch over 3 people. How silly is that? Then we wonder why the pay increase was little.

headline: Market Development Team
pros: I came in taking a step back from Account Executive at a toxic company to one that offered promise and career development. Management and leadership has not disappointing. My story isn't flawless, but as long as you show that you care, your leadership will set you up for success and give you every opportunity to grow and move towards the next step in your career, even if its a non traditional move. Hands down, this is the best job, culture, team, and leadership that I've ever been a part of. I haven't regretted a single moment. Those who complain about this role haven't experience what's out there and are spoiled because this place cares!
cons: Only complaint is pay, coming from a six figure salary to something a little less... but you have every opportunity to make money in your quota as well as your next step. It's worth the one year in seat as an MDR.

headline: By far the best place I've worked!
pros: Company culture, co-workers, Executive Leadership,  Opportunities for advancement
cons: No 401k match... yet. There are a handful of sub-par leaders who seemed to have been promoted for being in the right place at the right time. The good news is the company is investing heavily in management training.

headline: Super nice place to work!
pros:
- Supporting management
- Growing very fast
- Awesome team, all motivated people that want to grow with the company
- Customers love the product
- Cantine with all snacks/food you can dream of
- Flexible culture
- Lots of benefits!
cons:
No cons I can think of. 
Or maybe; the amount of food in cantine might make me gain weight...

headline: Great company, great culture
pros:
- There's great benefits that are getting better - 4 weeks of vacation, 3 days of volunteer time, 401k matching coming, 6mo maternity/paternity leave, $50 transit subsidy per mo, money to cover medical deductibles, etc.
- Work/life balance is great - in SF, people leave the office around 5 and almost no one is there after 6
- Smart people - Everyone is really sharp from great schools/backgrounds, but still really down to earth and excited to help even across functions when you email out of the blue
- Awesome product (40%+ share) that sells itself and is getting better with internal development, acquisition and fine tuning
- Budget to run great programs and do what needs to be done
- Stock is doing great at the moment
cons:
- Salary is competitive but not super high (stock helps that though)
- No catered lunches but very well stocked kitchens
- Org is still getting settled and there are some curiosities, but this should work itself out soon

headline: Best company to work
pros: DocuSign has a team of extremely talented individuals. Proud of the product we have created and all the love we receive from our customers.
cons: none that i can think of

headline: Market Development Representative
pros:
-Great work life balance
-Ability to make more income than OTE
-Great /fun culture with understanding management
-Training in Saas space with clear promotion
-Important sales skills that are applicable to any career path 
-Awesome benefits
cons: -Sometimes the job becomes mundane, but shouldn't be in the role longer than a year and a half

headline: Great place to work and excell
pros: Open and respectful, proactivity is valued
cons: needs investment in data tools, reporting

headline: This is *that* place
pros:
You almost never hear of a place where nearly everyone is happy -- where all three items are perfect: pay, job itself, and management. 

It is notoriously difficult to get hired here, but once in, you see why: Teams that get along incredibly well, management that acknowledges their own struggles and works towards commonly set goals, and pay/benefits that truly lead the industry. And we work at a verb.

Pros:
-Benefits are top notch like Aetna health plans at 100% paid, time off starting at 4 weeks, paid parental leave (SIX MONTHS!), flexible scheduling, and more
-Managers who genuinely care. Almost no one leaves due to a DocuSign issue.
-Advancement is likely if desired.
-Flexibility in scheduling.
-Our CEO is seriously inspirational. He is direct, honest, and passionate.
-Regular town hall meetings with both CEO and departmental SVP's, whom you can ask very blunt/direct questions and get thoughtful responses. I've been at places where these meetings were mostly for show - not here. They care and it shows.
cons:
-Work from home is common in most departments except for Account Management, where it is limited to one day a week after one year. This needs to be expanded to 3-5 days/week to keep in line with other companies. 
-Interdepartmental communication is tough, however this is par for the course for rapidly growing companies. Also, this has been directly acknowledged by our CEO, and this is being worked on.

headline: Great culture and working environment
pros: The engineering org has an open and collaborative culture and there's great focus on the customer.
cons: Some growing pains with release planning and execution. If done right this can also be seen as a pro as an area for employee growth.

headline: Best tech company I've ever worked at!
pros: Code base is in excellent condition. People are always happy and friendly. Great work/life balance. Tons of perks including catered lunches and beer on tap. You are genuinely appreciated and respected as an employee here.
cons: They don't provide an unlimited bus pass. Instead they give you about $56 each month to buy your own. No 401k yet, but I guess that will start later in 2018

headline: Excellent company to work for. Great people and exciting projects all the time.
pros: Just went public, looking to get into the future of Document Signing. Excellent team and leadership. Great work life balance and industry salaries.
cons: No cons. I believe that I will not change my work for a while.

headline: The best company I have worked for in 25+ years
pros:
+ Top-of-industry colleagues
+ Great work-life balance
+ Volunteer opportunities (we get paid time off to volunteer!!!)
+ Saving some trees, paper is so passé
+ Fun and flexible environment
+ Great benefits

I feel like I haven't worked a day in my life since I started at DocuSign, because I truly love what I do.  I have worked for many of the heavy hitters here in the PNW, including large book sellers and mobile phone companies, and DocuSign is hands down the best place I have ever been.  In my mind, in many years I will retire from this company because it is just that good.  If you get the chance to work here, TAKE IT.
cons: None that are worth complaining about

headline: Exactly what I was hoping for!
pros:
DocuSign treats there employees like adults and I just love that.  Not every company in the Bay Area does this. They are super flexible with you, if you need to work remotely for whatever reason you can.  

The management level here has been awesome and that's not again always the case for big companies. Transparency is key and they know how to respectfully be transparent while also helping you as individuals get to your next career goals. 

 The benefits are amazing as you can see from the reviews. They pay 100%  of medical and dental and vision, that's not heard of in most companies in the Bay Area. They stock the fridges with tasty healthy snacks, although I wish they had oatmeal like they do in Seattle (hint hint). They offer generous Maternity leave, 6 months which is honestly needed, 3 months is too short for any new mother. 

The overall vibe is a collaborative space and most people truly want to be here and that is what contributes to the great cultural. 

Our CEO Dan Springer is such a breath of fresh air! He truly cares about the employees here and you can tell because he's so open and honest. He doesn't sugar coat anything and listens.  Bravo!
cons: The commuter benefits (which they have) could be a little more, by an extra 20-30 dollars. The only benefit they are really missing is a gym allowance.  That would be great to have! Most companies offer anything between 70-100 dollars a gym to stay active and healthy. DocuSign is so committed to a balanced work life balance so I'm surprised they don't have this perk.

headline: Amazing product, Team, and Career Opportunities
pros:
+AMAZING people
+Great technology/product
+Work/Life balance
+Career Development
+Growth and Opportunities
cons: -Could have a more formalized enablement program

headline: Account Manager
pros: I love the culture at DocuSign.   Everyone is willing to help, the resources are phenomenal and it is truly a team oriented environment.
cons: The ratio of direct reports to management is stretched, but is temporary while they hire and promote more into management.

headline: Fast paced with awesome work culture
pros:
Competitive pay
Benefits and continue to introduce new ones such ESPP, 401K
Work culture
Quality of work
Passionate and smart employees
cons: Sometimes gets overwhelming since in hyper growth mode

headline: Great Company with Fantastic Culture
pros:
- Work-Life balance & family-first values that are actually reflected in behaviors, not just words
- Leadership Team that truly cares about employees
- Employees that are not OK with the status quo and willing to step in and make improvements
- Personal/professional development is top of mind for management team
- Exciting time to be a part of a growing company
cons:
Not many! :)
- Better tools (scalable solutions) should be implemented to keep up with organizational growth

headline: Account Manager
pros:
Collaborative Work Culture
Promote Internally
Take Time to Hire the Best People
Fun Team Events/Competitions
cons:
Inconsistent Career/Skill Development Opportunities 
Management Stretched to Juggle Responsibilities
Unclear Promotion Path

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: I've worked at a lot of tech companies and the culture here is so welcoming, supportive, and aligned. The leadership at DocuSign is really strong, there's a sense of warmth and passion for the work we do. My boss is super chill, but in a very good way. The benefits are really great. I think line-by-line, DocuSign offers more benefits and more compensation with the benefits package that most places. Ton's of perks and reasons to stay here.
cons: This may seem petty, and I am very thankful for what we have, AND the snacks could use a little upgrade / rotation.

headline: Market Development Rep
pros: Amazing culture, great benefits, and unlimited career potential!
cons: My 20 minute walk home is all uphill

headline: Great Company
pros:
- Supportive Management
- Teams always expanding -  opportunities to progress
- Monthly happy hours/Hot Breakfast
- Good snacks & canteen facilities
cons: - No major cons I can think of

headline: Culture and Growth is why i'll be here another 5 years
pros: actively listen to employee concerns, change happens at a quick rate. Compensated fairly and promotion opportunity is great. they give career advice for us and the team i work with are friends outside the office.
cons: salary is slightly below industry average, but company is young and quickly catching up

headline: Business Anlyst
pros: Collaborative environment, manageable pressure, a good place to learn and grow
cons: Could use more collaboration with outside teams.

headline: Fantastic Company All Around
pros: The most welcoming company I could have joined for a first job. All around fantastic, and an amazing environment as well. The work is engaging and the people are even better.
cons: The base pay for most people in sales is enough to get by, but with commission you can do very well. Not much of a con because you can move up very quickly.

headline: Meh
pros:
The job is extremely simple and decently paid
The food is getting there, slowly.
Cash bonus.
cons:
Dwarf or giant, everybody gets the same equipment. Zero Ergonomy.
It gets dirty in the afternoon, and after certain "people" have parties...
Poor training for few products, no training whatsoever for others.
No test accounts for certain products
Login after login after login after login after login...
Workload not evenly distributed
No real career path, the few positions available are restricted to chosen people which act like they own the company.
Important meetings cannot be attended because the headcount is never sufficient, so you do not get to enjoy the company's life like everybody else.
Food and appliances are systematically removed from the 3rd floor and sent to the fourth to keep the master race happy. Or simply there is no budget to give certain employees what all other employees get for free.
Very low salary rise.

headline: MDR
pros: Great team! Great opportunity! Great management!
cons: Can't think of any at this time

headline: Sales power over management
pros: Great technology and clearly loved by customers. A LOT of egos in high sales positions that have opinions far above their worth to the bottom line.
cons: As above the sales function holds too much power over other areas.

headline: Great Company, Great Folks
pros: The product, The vision and the teams
cons: managing the growth is challenging

headline: Poisonous Management Culture
pros: Great product, individual contributors and mid management
cons: Executive team dysfunctional culture, in-fighting, constantly changing strategies.  Drives image of inclusion, diversity but more of a marketing ploy than a practiced culture.

headline: Qa Engineer
pros:
A great place to work in. the managers are great and the company really care about her employees. 

The Working hours are pretty flexible so spare time with the family is never been passed
cons: No cons to say here. sorry :)

headline: Sr Account Executive
pros: Product, work environment, employees, atmosphere
cons: Limited options, comp plan, territory shifts

headline: AVP
pros: Best company I've ever worked for!
cons: None that come to mind.

headline: Remote Work Initiative
author_position: Senior Lead Rapid Adoption Consultant, Customer Success and Enablement
pros: DocuSign has an incredible culture, Leadership (C-Level) Team, and there are lots of benefits to being a full time employee. I have lovingly been with this company for a loyal 6.5 years, and have held roles in both Sales and Customer Success and Enablement.
cons: I have been with the Company for 6.5 years, and my current [new] Manager/Director will not be flexible on remote work, even though my role can very easily be done 100% remotely.

headline: Good money for a lot of work
pros: Still lot of opportunities in Europe
cons: Sometimes the hiring process is too fast

headline: MDR
pros: Great work life balance, Positive environment, Fast -paced Collaborative teams, upward mobility, stock options, free snacks,
cons: None that I can think of!

headline: Great Culture
pros:
Great atmosphere
Growing company that has the potential to do amazing things
cons:
Compensation is just fair
Lack of innovation has hurt them in certain markets

headline: Customer Care Representative Tier 1
pros:
Everyone is very friendly
Training is very informative and trainers are always willing to work with you
Great building layouts
Plenty of holiday/sick pay
cons: Not a single one I can think of.

headline: Solutions Engineer
pros: This is, by a wide margin, the best  company I have ever worked for.  The culture is outstanding. Business is conducted aggressively,  of course, but always ethically. Movement within the company is readily available. Benefits are good, pay is very competitive,  and employees are treated respectfully.  All in all, an excellent place to work.
cons: With such fast-paced growth, change has been fairly constant. So, buckle up!

headline: A great work environment with a lot of opportunities for career development
pros:
-Leadership encourages growth in employees
-Work life balance
-Hard-working team members who are happy to help each other
-Office is right across from the Transbay Bus Terminal for a more convenient commute for some like myself!
-I'm lucky to work for an industry leader like Docusign!
cons: -Would love to have some form of a cafeteria or catered lunches everyday!

headline: Company went from great to poor internally
pros:
- pioneers of the esign industry 
- modern platform and software 
- green company that makes a positive impact in the world
cons:
- no career development, management is extremely greedy and upward movement is VERY slow... especially in product management and engineering orgs
- major red tape, bureaucracy, and politics has inundated many departments even before DS went public recently. Definitely more of a Corporation now instead of a startup (I’ve been here 5+ years)
- the company has always been very top heavy (ie way too many Directors, VPs and higher compared to functional level etc) and as a result very few roll up theirs sleeves and actually get stuff done.  Def too many cooks in the kitchen on many projects.
- Absolutely zero accountability... people in other departments will completely drop the ball at times with no ramifications or consequences. I guess on the flip side it’s super hard to get fired at DS (if you’re not in sales)

headline: Great place to work and I’m lucky to be here
pros: After all these years, still the best place I’ve ever worked.  A large part of that is my manager, they are by far the best boss I’ve ever had.
cons:
Things that really haven’t improved over the years, but DS says they are working on it:

- racial diversity (Wilco concerts are more diverse than the Seattle office)
- career development - very few individual contributors become people managers (most are hired from the outside)

headline: An Excellent First Job!
pros: Great benefits. Free drinks and snacks. Lunch on Mondays and Wednesday (for engineers), and a happy hour once per month! DocuSign is unique in that people are both driven and generally happy-go-lucky at work.
cons: No 401(k) match (yet), and some annoying corporate process approvals, but I suppose it could be much worse.

headline: Enterprise Sales
pros: Great company, leadership, product, and vision
cons: Working in silo and independent

headline: A great place to work - delighted to be here!
pros:
- A great product many people know and love
- A great culture of energetic, enthusiastic and driven professionals who are also really helpful
- Questions are most welcome and you are never left on your own
- The Onboarding Bootcamp in the US enables you to network internally and to get into the grips with your job
- Funky office on the border of City/Shoreditch with fully stacked fridges
- You will NEVER STOP LEARNING - so make sure you're comfortable with that and like continuous development
cons:
- We're growing so fast there are some growing pains and constant change, which constantly keeps you on your feet
- We're still figuring out/reinventing some key go-to-market strategies, so make sure you're flexible and adaptable - these will be key character traits to succeed here!

headline: Onboarding and First Month
pros: Smooth interview process, great on-boarding and training and real team environment. 5* for first month. Also ramping on targets to take early pressure off.
cons: Some of the internal systems are a bit convoluted, like 2 HR systems, but this is part of growing pains of a company growing at such a fast rate.

headline: Near perfect, but improvements needed
pros: The culture, people, and future of this company are certainly reasons to join. I love my job and I love coming into the office each day. It’s a great environment to learn and grow. I would recommend working here to anybody, it’s a great opportunity to have fun and also develop skills.
cons: Compensation and benefits aren’t competitive. Account executives do not get paid what they should and there’s been talent that’s left the company due to that very reason. If docusign wants to keep hiring quality talent and retain the talent it already has, they need to fix compensation. Base salaries are very low compared to other companies within the industry, and there’s no 401k matching. This needs to get fixed ASAP.

headline: Flexibility and Care for Me as a Human
pros: I have found tremendous support for my personal life situation which frequently interferes with working on a 'regular' and 'normal' workday hours schedule. As long as I communicate and get my work done, it has been wonderful to work around daycare schedules and complications as a single mom without fear of losing my job. The benefits and the atmosphere rock in comparison to past positions and places I've worked and I am challenged by my work and am learning daily.
cons: We hate paper...I love to take notes and draw things out, on paper...and I'm working toward doing those things digitally, it's just not my style or learning preference. But other than that, I don't have any.

headline: SDET
pros: Amazing Culture, Good Package and Growing Fast
cons:
Not matching 401K
Average on technical advancement

headline: Strong Employee Empowerment and Respect
pros: I am given my tasks and then expected to do them with no micromanaging.  It's a good balanced style of management, where they treat their employees like responsible adults.  Also, they are very flexible about hours and working from home.
cons: Shared workspace makes noise and other distractions a common problem.

headline: DocuSign: It lives up to the (well deserved) hype
pros:
+ Competitive comp package
+ Great work life balance
+ Strong opportunity for career progression
+ Amazing Office and support team / resources
+ Category leading technology
cons:
- Scaling fast so some process growing pains
- EMEA market not as mature (so lots of opportunity, but slightly less brand recognition compared to US)

headline: Great place to work as a new hire
pros: Recently hired and really enjoying my time at the company so far. Great teammates, good office culture (transparent, collaborative), good tools used to get work done.  Project work is  interesting, and the company is large enough to have great resources and pay/benefits while also being small enough where things move quickly.
cons: None that I have so far

headline: Great work/life balance.  Interesting products.
pros: A great place to dig in,  if you like, but alternatively choose to keep a good work/life balance.   Friendly people work here.  DocuSign cares about its employees.
cons: Can be a very sales-oriented organization.  This can be a good thing, depending on your role.

headline: Best place to work for so far.
pros:
- Impressive product which has the huge potential to transform how the people/companies use the system of agreement.  Think about how easy is to sign a contract (which is legally binding) anywhere in the world.

- Smart people who are motivated to make the product better.
 
- DocuImpact: 3 days/year  to volunteer for non profit. 

- Catered lunches twice/week, Friday evening Pizza party and happy hours every other week. 
- RSU's
cons:
- It would be awesome if the company matched 410K contribution. 
- How about catered lunches and breakfast everyday ?

headline: Great company as long as you are not in support.
pros:
Steady paycheck
Looks good on a resume
cons:
Very low salary (50K starting in Seattle) for what they expect you to do at "entree level" Troubleshooting API calls, Integrations, etc

This is a customer support call center

headline: Account Executive
pros: DocuSign is by far the best place I've worked thus far in my career. The people and culture here is so unique and special. I wake up everyday excited to come into the office and learn from my peers. Our training sessions, happy hours, team events, and end of quarters are one of a kind and you can really feel a special buzz around the office at these times. I'm so happy I chose to join this wonderful company.
cons: Since we recently went public there are some changes happening slowly but surely. Not really any negatives to comment about but I feel flexibility is key in any sales role.

headline: Strongly Recommend - Great decision to join DocuSign
pros: Company culture that far surpasses just "bagel fridays". Down to earth and hardworking community from the top down (starting with our awesome CEO Dan Springer).  A ton of fun  Huge opportunity and clear pathways to promotion and career development. Well trained and supportive management. Pretty good benefits - transportation/cell phone help, plus can't beat 4 weeks of PTO. Genuinely responsive to feedback - you can bring up an idea and within weeks or months it has been acknowledged and a solution is being worked toward.
cons: No 401K match but it is confirmed to be in place by 2019. Not as much product knowledge for MDRs/SDRs but just implemented an admin training that has helped alot. Not as much collaboration between departments, but I feel like thats common for collaboration.

headline: Customer Support Representative
pros: Almost at my year finally. I finally feel like I can contribute here. I can say with certainty that the feeling I came away with after coming here to Glassdoor and reading everything I could before I interviewed, is spectacularly accurate. The sense that this is an amazing company, that people still enjoyed coming to work here, that feeling that you are supported in your role, that there is growth, and opportunity.  Great benefits to boot. This is all consistent with my understanding today. This is the first time, as someone in their mid-30's, that I can say I've felt support, felt heard, and felt like I'm able to grow and stay with a company happily. Of all my jobs this has not been my easiest, but definitely my most rewarding. This is the first company I've felt genuinely happy to be with. I will be staying as long as I can. Looking forward to the future here. Thank you for making this an enjoyable and rewarding place to begin my career, as I see it now. Dan I know you read each of these, you, as our CEO, I feel have made a large impact on DocuSign. Thank you for showing passion, caring, concern, and so much more. You inspired this one little runt in the workforce. Please keep it up!
cons:
As seen in other reviews that stated we were moving towards IPO. Those statements were well written and accurate. You did and do feel the belt tightening, but as was stated, that is expected at this stage.  It's hard to feel any negativity about that and I hesitate to even mention it here. It's been stated that the 401k matching will be brought in post-IPO, as long as that is made into reality as was promised, and we have no reason to believe that won't happen, it's really just being patient until the when comes to pass.

The only legitimate complaint I could speak to is:
The training I received at this job was the worst I've ever received. That being said, the colleagues I immediately found myself surround by thereafter, made it so that did not matter so much. They, as well as my manager, were a large part of the reasons I succeeded. The people at this company are, by and large, heads above the average employee at my previous companies. This failure also presented an opportunity and I have worked endlessly to provide quality & actionable feedback to our training team. My managers have assisted in getting that feedback heard within our Training department as well. I believe we can continue to make strides towards improvements there as we move towards scalability, etc.

headline: I would give more stars if I could!
pros:
DocuSign defines work life balance - work from home options & flexible work hours.
Excellent product - we truly make our customer's life easy.
Great pay package (base pay, bonus, RSU ) and benefits (free insurance, employee events, free food & beverages!)
Upper management have a very clear goal and are driven to achieve it.
Really smart and easy to work with colleagues.
DocuSign IMPACT is in everyone's DNA. They are always looking for ways to give back. 
Amazing Parental leave - 6 months paid leave for the primary caregiver & 2 months paid leave for the non-primary caregiver.
They really listen! This is the only company where the CEO reads every single survey feedback, and takes action based on inputs given directly by employees.
They take fixing the diversity and gender gap very seriously, and are actively working towards improving it across the industry and not just the company.
cons:
Needs more established leveling of roles within organizations.
Improve commuter benefits.

headline: Fantastic company and a great place to work
pros:
I'm fairly new to DocuSign and I have found everyone very helpful.  Many employees are very philanthropic and take time out to do work for non-profit organizations.  I've already been to three events in less than 6 months.

* Very helpful employees
* Very nice coworkers
* Great culture
cons: This is a tough one... they didn't have a matching 401(k) but that is being addressed now that we are a public company.  The San Francisco office has better goodies in the kitchenette(?)

headline: Great company, great atmosphere!
pros:
Smart teammates
Relaxed atmosphere
Fast growing, always new people to meet!
cons:
Collab across timezones is difficult, senior management need to do more.
Some politics at certain management levels, but this has improved massively

headline: Great company & people, too much politics
pros: We have  a smart and humble team, and the work life balance is very good. If you prove yourself, it is possible to change positions and make career progress, though it is not easy. Dan is a great CEO and the future of DocuSign is bright in my opinion.
cons: Politics is huge here - it's all about what relationships you have in the company. If you want to be successful, you have to play the politics game, make sure you're on a good team with good manager, etc. If you don't, you can easily make no progress and get no recognition even if you're great at your job.

headline: Sales Development Good Now, Concerned for later
pros:
Dan Springer CEO is great, super charismatic, and seems to be pushing company in great direction

Vibrant Workplace/Culture
cons:
New Product Direction lacks functionality - concerned about product outlook

Leadership is becoming more hawkish on sales development teams - limiting their ability to hit numbers 

Beginning to feel big/IPO - transitioning focus away from employees to bottom line, stock holders, etc - not optimistic about the old pace of promotions

headline: Industry Leading Company
pros:
DocuSign is the best at what it does in its market area. Its technical infrastructure is significant so its product is solid and, if used correctly, can make a difference to an organisation using it. While all this is technical , it has additional benefits in that it makes the product easy to support and sell. It also make the company easy to represent and be proud of.
Everyone I have come across is easy to work with. The atmosphere is very positive, fun, hardworking and polite.
cons: With a relatively young work force that is primarily sales oriented, with high growth, there can be challenges.

headline: Market Development Representative
pros: Great company and product, compensation, work life balance, awesome coworkers, fun culture, cool office with great perks, sales team is a team effort- lots of cohesion and collaboration.
cons: There really aren't that many. It's a great time to be at DocuSign!

headline: Exciting time to work at DocuSign
pros: Autonomy and empowerment. DocuSign is a company that is growing fast and needs people who are able to take responsibility and make decisions. Good working environment fun team activities. IMPACT events are a great opportunity to give back to the community.
cons: Some growing pains with collaboration among different teams and business units but management are willing to listen to feedback and adapt our approach.

headline: Fun Loving, Encouraging Company
pros: The SDR role is a great position right out of college! Definitely helps you to develop key sales skills, while working in a fun, positive environment. They provide extensive, hands on training and management is very helpful as well.
cons: Definitely I high paced environment, I wouldn't recommend to someone who isn't ready to put in the time and effort

headline: Excellent learning and culture
pros: Great facilities and working environment
cons: growing pains of growing business

headline: Good job but benefits are not competitive with other tech companies
pros: Employee stock purchasing program, 6 month maternity leave.
cons: Any promotion disqualifies you for your annual performance bonus. No 401k matching.

headline: Politically charged, non-merit based culture
pros:
- Brand name
- Long-lasting first-mover advantage
cons:
- Lack of meaningful product innovation
- Only competitive expert in the company left recently; no Go to Market strategy to combat increasingly competitive market, product commoditization, and pricing pressures
- Skills and output don’t matter
- Recognition is reserved for individuals not teams
- Merit is overlooked; quantity of work is celebrated, not quality; extra projects to stand out are viewed as either “not part of your job” if they don’t benefit your team and your team only OR if they benefit your team only, “not enough to make a difference, do more”
- Hiring processes are weak; undeserving/incompetent candidates acquire roles that they shouldn’t
- Middle-management is incompetent; micro-management, favoritism, emotional decision-making, lack of professionalism, over-promising, under-delivering, and credit-stealing are rampant
- NO room to grow or learn more; if you voluntarily work with another team to learn more, your manager will question your intent
- high employee turnover in multiple departments due to employee dissatisfaction and unhappiness
- mentorship outside of your direct manager is looked down upon; managers are highly territorial, self-driven, and rarely focused on the company’s best interest

Most emotionally-draining work experience I’ve ever had in my life.

headline: Account Executive
pros: The people and management are great
cons: The company grew very fast

headline: Great company to work for!
pros: Great product and great benefits!
cons: More talent management and training opportunities!

headline: Good in US, bad in Brazil
pros: The company pays well and for friends of the managers in Brazil, workload is very light.
cons: In Brazil, the Engineering team is plagued by mangers favoring friends. If you criticize your boss in surveys that are meant to be anonymous, you can get fired (that happened).

headline: 4/5 would start career here
pros: Genuinely collaborative engineering environment, managers understand and encourage work/life balance.
cons: Compensation was poorly managed for a long time.  Management is working on righting the ship but it'll take a while.

headline: Great product
pros: Product, culture, pre IPO
cons: Targets, flexible working, coaching, collaboration, marketing

headline: Constant change is a good thing...
pros: The company is always changing and reinventing how the products work and have positive impacts on the employees, customers and social foot print. This is a big change over the past two years from a historical sales focused company to one that is maturing into a more well rounded one.
cons: Training is sparse internally but commitments have been made that more is on the way . Work life balance is off in most of the departments in the company  and communication from higher ups is still not where it should be.

headline: Great company to work at.
pros: Great benefits and opportunity for promotion. I was an SDR then got promoted to MDR. Great food options and health benefits.
cons: Their positions offer less than competitors. That's why lots of employees left only due to to pay otherwise no reason to leave ever.

headline: Lacking process
pros: The snacks, the upward mobility
cons: Lack of process, project maturity

headline: Tremendous Company To Work For
pros: Team first. The roles are constantly evolving for the better. Leadership is top notch.
cons: Lack of explination behind new initiatives. It would be nice to get the buy-in from everyone.

headline: Avoid Working in Support Department
pros: Fast paced environment. Good career opportunities if you are not in the support department. Some good people are there, carrying the load for everyone else that is just counting the days until the IPO so they can leave. You can learn a lot from others if you know how to spot the good ones.
cons:
Awful culture - no respect for work/life balance at all. People will be emailing you any time, including when you are on PTO, expecting a response. 

Bureaucracy and office politics are key here. If you are into that stuff, you will thrive. For every mentor helping you on your path there are five colleagues with a knife, plotting your demise.

No one takes ownership of anything there. You can talk to ten different people before you get help if you need something from another department/team. 

The support department are treated like children by their managers and leadership, leading them to act the part. Pizza and ice cream are given out like training treats for dogs, when really everyone just wants an opportunity to do more than crunch tickets and be a call center robot. Good boy!

For every competent colleague interaction you will have ten with checked-out employees.

They internally promote primarily based on tenure, leading to a lot of people in roles they should not have. This also leads to talent walking out the door if they have any kind of sense of urgency for their career prospects.

DTM will be a commodity within a few years. Not sure long term this company will survive after going public.

Their customers are enterprise dinosaurs and ignorant realtors.

headline: Account Management.
pros: Amazing growth, constantly challenged, very rewarding, great product and the team is like extended family!
cons: You need to be adaptable to change; highly demanding and requires constant prioritization.

headline: Solid company, good people
pros: Solid people, improving culture, sound leadership now.
cons: Tick tock.. waiting for IPO.

headline: Upper Marketing Management is the worse - too political and too much favoritism
pros: The rest of the organization still are humane and have their hearts in the right place.  Free food is good but not if you’re choking on it from daily tears.
cons:
*its who you know not what your skills are
*treats loyal employees like dirt
*no career help, promoting or training
*pay raise and bonuses are a joke
*micromanagement hell
*too many directors that don’t belong in their roles
*brown nosers 
*lack of diversity and culture
*no real budgets to improve the lack of efficiency

headline: Great company to work for !
pros: Very fast pace, constant learning of new things. Very smart people.
cons: Long hours, benefits not yet on par with big tech companies.

headline: DocuSign is awesome.
pros:
At DocuSign, you won't be micromanaged. assigned busywork, or get tangled in a bunch of red tape when you want to get something done - we're too busy growing and accommodating that growth. Management trusts that the employees it hires hit the bar - and that bar is a very high one - so you deal with a high amount of responsibility and you are truly responsible for taking ownership of your results.

We have awesome benefits, plentiful PTO days, an amazing new mat/pat leave policy, work\life balance is good.

For the department/role I'm in, no complaints on compensation at all... Management has an eye for talent + work ethic and will make sure to recognize that by taking an active interest in developing your career.

We are located in the middle of downtown Seattle so no matter where you're coming from, public transportation is generally an option and not that bad. We also get a small transportation stipend (it won't cover all monthly commute costs, but hey, it's still money).                

As an employee of DocuSign, I can really see how the company lives by the phrase "happy workers are productive workers." We have nice perks; snacks, company happy hours, private zen rooms, catered lunches, swag, etc...But the most valuable perk here is the culture.  Dan Springer sets a very honest and down to earth tone within the company and you can tell he really cares about the quality of his employees' lives in and outside of work. People are friendly but if you're not super extroverted you won't feel obligated to be social. We have an entire day dedicated to volunteering and people really get into it. There is a place for every type of person at DocuSign.

I truly feel valued as an employee here and am proud of the tangible impact I've made within my department and the company during my employment at DocuSign. I've been able to develop my career and learn a lot, and learn it quickly, so I can learn more.
cons:
401k matching still hasn't been introduced, but I can imagine there might be changes down the road in terms of that policy.

You know what I said about growth in the pros section? Growing pains here are also real, but that is to be expected within a fast growing company (duh?). Sometimes processes are not defined and I've heard people complain of reorgs, but I honestly don't mind the minor frustrations that come with a fast growing company like DocuSign. I'd rather work at a company where you have to problem solve a lot to get a satisfying and tangible result, than work somewhere where everything is defined for you and you just feel like a "cog in the machine."

headline: Positive with room to grow
pros:
Great career growth opportunities. DocuSign puts a lot of emphasis on training and it shows. 

6 months paid maternity/paternity leave
cons:
Salaries are AT LEAST 20% below market value 
No 401k matching 
Recruits (what feels like) entirely from frats so the culture is VERY WHITE and VERY BRO-y

headline: Not enterprise ready
pros: great product, nice people, beautiful offices in SF and Seattle
cons: Lots of turnover in leadership, mid mgmt, sales and account mgmt.  Price erosion due to high competition.  Need to introduce a new sku. In less than 1 year my entire team turned over from SVP down to everyone in the group.

headline: Something to Ponder
pros: It can be a great place to work if you play your cards right.
cons: It can be a deceiving place and will drain you mentally and eventually physically.

headline: Great Company
pros:
Growing company about to go Public
Hard work is rewarded
cons:
Growing Pains
No 401k Matching 
Salary needs to be more competitive
Expect to be in the office M-F starting at 7am for the XDR positions - rarely can you work remote

headline: Gr8 company
pros: Vibrant culture with tons of work to do.
cons: Your ae really breaks or makes your appointments with prospects.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Positive and forwardlooking mindset; very very smart people; test and learn culture;  friendly atmosphere; everyone rows in the same direction and believe in what they do;  customers love the product and the brand; huge growth potential.
cons: Pains that come with a very rapid growth

headline: The vision keeps growing
pros: This is the most excited I've ever been here, with an enhanced vision for what we can do and an executive team poised to make it happen. Developing solutions to automate business processes is something so fundamental to the work I've done, I've only ever had high expectations since I came aboard in 2016, but looking at where we've gone in 2017 and where we're going next year, I can't help but feel like the best is yet to come.
cons:
Let's get more sparkling water back in SF!  Who is drinking the soda?!
Also, continue to consider your people for expanded roles within the company.  My team has brought on fantastic external candidates, but seeing such excellent career progression for internal ones is very encouraging, and also helps to stem younger employees from hopping off to other companies.

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: Great culture and a lot of opportunity to learn.
cons: This company is growing pretty fast so need to be flexible.

headline: Sales Development Representative - Great entry level job
pros:
Great management who constantly works with you to achieve your goals.
Fantastic benefits packages: Snacks, plenty of paid time off, and medical/insurance plans. 
You work for what you earn ethic. 
Cohesive sales teams, which are collaborative and supportive.
cons: Salary could be a bit more competitive.

headline: MDR
pros: Great team, great coaching, great training. Normal numbers of highs and lows.
cons: No real room for AE promotion if you're not a TOP performer. AM promotion is in the Seattle office only.

headline: Jr Business Analyst
pros: Good work culture, Interesting product, Employees have a voice
cons: workload expectation, work life balance, chances for advancement

headline: Market Development Representative- overall good experience
pros: Couldn’t be happier beginning at a company with such demonstrated success. Product speaks for itself in sales and ensures that we are truly helping our customers. Managers are always looking for ways to improve job experience. Work life balance is great. PTO is better than most. Full health, dental, and vision benefits. Everyone works hard and has a passion for the benefit that DocuSign can offer.
cons: Managers look to improve job experience but don’t take a lot of initiative into actually implementing. There are improvements that can be made with the distribution of territories. No 401k matching.

headline: Enterprise Business Representative
pros:
Fast paced company
Still in Start-up mode but with Enterprise structure and training
Promotion possibility
Target still reachable
cons: Market is not mature yet

headline: AE
pros:
Great product 
Great team 
Great pay
cons:
No 401k matching
No gym membership

headline: Market Development Representative
pros: Great product, some great people and management.
cons: Some awful management. No clear strategy. Need to work out a lot of kinks. Should have more processes in place for an organization of their size/maturity.

headline: Longest I've stayed at one company
pros:
Work on products that people love, and that actually help them in their day to day lives
Big enough that the company is stable, but small enough to still be very flexible
Constantly expanding opportunities and interesting problems
Great culture overall
cons:
Growing pains are a constant
Comp/benefits feel below-average
Culture clashes between the "Old Guard" and the "New Guard" (and increasingly the "New New Guard"

headline: Its ok
pros: Good pay, free trip to Seattle for a week, customer are usually nice
cons: micromanagement, loud offices, rude colleagues, very poor social game

headline: Great place to start sales career
pros: Huge investments in training reps, gives experience in warm, cold, and upselling customers, opportunity to work with virtually any company US and Canada wide to sell product. Managers make promotion path abundantly clear and actively care about your progression. Culture doesn't punish reps who struggle initially/at some point in their career.
cons: Compensation structure subject to change in growing company, compensation focuses on quantity over quality/depth of sales. Not everyone is part of same role on team so pay  varies.

headline: Work at DocuSign
pros: Smart and Professional team, pre-IPO
cons: Bureaucratic, not the best C&B

headline: Glassdoor Ratings are Padded
pros: I like my cowokers, but senior management (VP & SVP level) has a few completely incompetent people.
cons: Someone in the company is doing really good job at padding the glassdoor reviews. If you go look on any other site, you'll get a real picture of how employees feel about DocuSign. As of this review, the Comparably DocuSign review has a C- rating, bottom 30% compared to companies of a similar size in the US, bottom 20% compared to companies nearby in SF.  Gender score and diversity score are both D (bottom 20%). Leadership grade is a D (bottom 20%) and compensation is a C (bottom 35%).

headline: Customer Support Representative -Tier 2
pros: The colleagues are the best. We get along well and there is a real team mentality in the Customer Support area.
cons: I work a late shift.

headline: Amazing start in a super start up environment!
pros:
Very interesting challenges since we are growing massively in EMEA. 
Hard work = great results
Career opportunities!
Very collaborative environment and you can challenge the status quo
Executives and leadership team have an open door and are approachable
Fun and we almost have no paper in the office!
cons: If you are not open and willing to solve and go over operational obstacles, some of them can seem daunting for who never worked in a start up environment.

headline: DocuSign is Great
pros: Great culture of accountability, dedication and hard work. We say what we do and we do what we say. Relaxed vibe that also encourages and recognizes those who push themselves and others to succeed
cons: Pay isn't great compared to other tech companies, work from home policy could be more flexible

headline: A vision that yields happy customers and employees
pros:
In my role, I interview a lot of people who often ask the question, "What makes DocuSign culture special?" Short answer: the product and the people.

Long story: The problem that DocuSign resolves is one that everyone from a grandparent to the CEO of a large company understands, so whether you're talking to a customer who recently implemented the product or a person you've just met explaining what you do for a living, the response to DocuSign is a responding, "Wow! I love your company and the product!" Working for an organization that yields that emotional response is very validating. Our mission and our product change business culture, improve efficiencies, and truly make people's lives simpler and easier. Everyone can appreciate that, and I think that feeling extends into the second thing that makes DocuSign's culture special, the people. 

The people who work at DocuSign are smart, driven, and well-rounded. If you're looking for a place where you feel like a small fish in a big pond, surrounded by talent that will elevate your game, this is the spot. There are very few gaps in organizational effectiveness, and it's fun to interact with departments and orgs within the company, knowing that you're working with a truly best-in-class group.  But, the company is in no way done growing and evolving, so there are certainly problems that can be resolved and areas where smart people can make a meaningful impact.
cons: With so many interdependent departments and processes, evolving some of the areas of inefficiency can be arduous. Mature markets, such as NA, may consider engaging with consultancies to solve some of the bigger organizational challenges.

headline: DocuSign still a great place to work after 3 years!
pros:
-CEO is not only great on the vision and getting things done, he's truly committed to workplace diversity (race, gender, age,  sexual orientation), empowering employees at all levels.
-Smart, passionate & collaborative people.
-Nice physical workspace 
-Good flexibility and work/life balance
-Fair compensation
-Overall, managers are committed to employee development
-Innovative and growing 
-Company is very serious about making community impact globally with company matching and various community impact events.
-3 Volunteer Time Off Days annually
cons: -Would like to see better benefits (they have been continually improving and it's on the Exec Leadership radar so I think it will happen over time)

headline: Best place to work!
pros: Amazing company culture - the work/life balance is real and managers remind you to be balanced!  But what's also great is how fast-paced and productive my days are working here.  There's never a dull moment - it's stimulating, exciting and procedures and processes are clear and defined making the day to day super efficient.  I just love my job at DocuSign!
cons: I really can't think of any - there's a lot of work and hopefully that will lesson as we add more players to the team.  However, it's very manageable as long as you prioritize.

headline: A Noble Enterprise
pros:
1. State of the art technology 
2. Empowering, Collaborative,  Customer centric Culture
3. Visionary Leadership
4. Global vision
cons: Opportunity to improve talent development and engagement

headline: Probably the best company I worked for so far.
pros:
Good work conditions, great team members and coworkers.
Salary above average for similar roles. 
Central location for the office. 
Regular company or team events. 
Lots of career opportunities.
cons: There is a lot to learn so it will take time to become really autonomous.

headline: Great company
pros: Engaged CEO and executives.  Flexible work environment and schedule.  Pretty good perks.  Every one is very helpful.
cons: Salary a little low.  Less perks than other tech companies, food, gym or gym membership etc.

headline: Great  Work Environment for Software Engineer
pros: Great work life balance.  High degree of work autonomy.   Challenging and high visibility projects.   Relaxed culture.
cons: Open office format with lots of background noise even on engineering floors.  You'll be buying headphones on week 2.  Any internal process that requires signatures will require constant reminders and follow-ups to see it go through.  Like any enterprise software company that's been around for a decade, there are isolated pockets in the codebase that are unmaintainable, lack ownership, and you'll eventually have to cross your fingers and modify at some point.

headline: Honest review not curated by HR
pros: This is a good place to work relative to other similar tech companies. In my experience the emphasis is on good not great. Yes, the work life balance is great. The physical location was great for me.
cons: The pay is below market median by 10-15% in engineering, no 401k match, and no bonus. Basically you pay for that work life balance. That stock better do amazingly well one day. As a result there are lots of early career engineers and some of the more experienced folks have left.

headline: Good place to start career, as long as you are in the department you want to stay in.
pros:
- Strong pride in product and reputation.
- Great at hiring smart, driven people at all levels.
- Shared optimism about company's future.
- New CEO does regular town halls, listens to employee questions and answers genuinely.
cons:
- Departments work independently/in their best interest at times, confusing ownership of issues/problems.
- Some decisions/promotions still made politically or are prematurely "promised," though it seemed to be improving before I left.
- no 401k match

headline: Awesome employer with great potential
pros: DocuSign is a great company with an outstanding solution and approach to enable clients to successfully take the digital journey together. The working atmosphere and the team were great from the very start and feels like a mixture of family and professionals working towards the same goals. There is a good work-life balance as well as great company values and culture that make even the work time pleasant. The job is challenging, but very interesting as well. The DocuSign solution is very easy to use, but gets complex when you dive into the details to find a perfect fit for the client and his use-cases. The Management ist supportive and there is an open culture, which I personally enjoy to be a part of. As DocuSign is still comparably small in EMEA, I think the growth just started and will continue and with that it will be an even greater company to work for in the future.
cons: DocuSign needs more local teams to support growth in DACH, which are native speakers and have a deeper understanding of the clients and market environment to drive adoption and growth.

headline: Director
pros:
Very dynamic environment 
Fast Growing 
Leaders in the field
Bringing real value to customers' operation
cons: like with any fast growing company suffers from birth pains not all processes are in place which sometime creates frustration in driving processes

headline: Satisfied Software Developer
pros: It's amazing to work for a company that could be potentially used by everyone. It's a fantastic brand. The work/life balance here can't be beat. I'm constantly challenged in my role and have been provided plenty of opportunities to reach above and beyond it if I want to.
cons: I think we still suffer from knowing what exactly should be in our product portfolio but it seems like we making efforts to nail down our strategy. It'd be great if we had some educational programs offered here but those changes might be coming.

headline: Sales
pros: Great product that customers love, smart people, market is still evolving.
cons: Commuting from the peninsula can be a challenge

headline: I'm still motivated to develop new business in DocuSign
pros:
Can do anything what I want
Other team is very supportive
cons: Organization is complex and political

headline: Market Development Representative
pros: Great environment to learn and grow skills as a sales/marketing professional.  Everyone is super friendly and more than willing to help.  Good pay. Great benefits. Awesome office. Great product. Great company. Great leadership. They do a great job of hiring internally and the experience looks amazing on a resume so it is a win win.
cons: Not much, other than the job is a total grind sometimes and often requires overtime just to get through the week but it all pays off big time if you keep hitting your numbers and qualifying for SPIFs. It comes and goes in waves. Not your typical desk job. Much more exciting. Another potential con is being around so many smart, outgoing, positive people can get overwhelming and makes it hard to stand out at times but that's a good problem to have in my opinion.

headline: Best of both worlds:  an established start-up
pros:
All the excitement and product innovation of a start-up with grown-up company ideas on work/life balance such as generous paid parental leave.  

CEO Dan Springer has not been shy about talking about potential IPO timing with news outlets.
cons: There has been some much needed turnover, but having lots of new people can make launching initiatives slower that expected.

headline: Trending upward
pros:
After having spent years at a gigantic software company, I greatly cherish the influence and scope of work that I have now at DocuSign.  It's about "just right" size where you have support and a full set of corporate services like IT, HR, facilities, etc but small enough that when you see a problem that needs addressed, you can very often become a champion to solve that issue without having to check with 20 people first.  You end up solving the problem at many or every level in which it needs to be addressed, which is incredibly rewarding.

DocuSign is also a fairly flexible work environment for engineers, coming up with creative schedules, processes and locations for you to achieve your goals.

Finally, DocuSign is very exciting right now because our new CEO has been on board for just long enough to really have a grasp of everything and is starting to make the big moves we hoped the company would make for it's future.  Will we IPO soon? Don't ask me, but it sure seems like we've been closer than ever in the 3+ years I have worked here.

Finally, it is a company that cares about it's employees and the communities in which we live.  They have a matching gifts IMPACT program for non profits, plus continually add better and better benefits to support all sorts of workers with different abilities and life constraints.  Recent changes to family leave, for example , were very generous.  Diversity and gender equity are more than just checkboxes on a list here. They really seem to mean it.
cons: Split between Seattle and San Francisco headquarters still has some division in ways teams work, style, process and leadership.  I think with new leaders these things are starting to be ironed out, but it has caused a slow in delivery of some key things, IMHO.

headline: Brilliant company to work for
pros: Fun, cutting edge, team, young and energetic, world leaders
cons: no shower facilities, could be more sporty together, no proper education Pay or incentivised system

headline: Great Company to Grow in
pros: Docusign is an all around great company. The product is amazing, the people who work here are helpful and collaborative, and the culture in the office is fun and innovative. There is so much room for growth within the business and for employees that it makes coming to work exciting.
cons: The benefits could be a little more competitive for a software company.

headline: Great Year! Ready for another one
pros:
- a product that everyone loves
- a product that impacts lives and business
- great benefits
- incredible team/organization
- right mix of tribal knowledge and new thinking
- focusing on process improvement (things are never set in stone, always waiting to get better)
- open and transparent CEO and leadership team
cons:
With fast  growth: 
- resources are limited
- inter-org struggles (goals not aligned)
- processes still being built

and no 401k at this point

headline: Great culture and brand, mediocre structure and benefits.
pros: DocuSign overall has a great culture. In general, you can speak your mind, and even send Dan an email. DocuSign as a brand is amazing, when you tell people you work here, without fail they will tell you how much they love it.
cons: As DocuSign is still in startup mode, there is a lot of understaffing, and quite a few departments where the leaders have outgrown the small company it was 4-5 years ago. Benefits are not yet there, though there have been promises made to ramp those up after IPO.

headline: Market Development
pros:
Great team of professionals
Lots of leadership opportunities
Great options for mobility up and across company
Increased transparency with new leadership
Increased recognition with new leadership
cons:
Quick turnaround times 
Doesn't seem like leadership values integrity as much as they say they do

headline: A great place to work
pros: Opportunities for growth within, generous vacation, snacks and free food, smart coworkers
cons: Drama / politics / lack of resources can affect the ability to get things done quickly.

headline: IT Senior Business Analyst
pros:
Too many to be listed, here is a few...
- Organic fruits/healthy snacks & drinks all day
- Great company culture
- Work with many bright individuals 
- Lots of learning opportunity, fast growing
- Excellent work life balance (eg. allow IT employees to work from home on Fridays)
- Good office location, easy commute (1 min walk from the bus terminal & 8 mins walk from the Ferry building)
- Most importantly, we have a great product which everyone knows about and loves. The company has a bright future)
- excellent health benefits (employee does not pay for any health insurance(dental/health/vision) premium, it's all free)
cons:
- Lack of 401 k matching
- No clear process is in place for employees to request personal development/training/educational budget
- It will be nice to have a job rotation program

headline: Been here for about 4 years.. so glad I joined this family
pros:
The people here are great. Everyone is working toward a common goal and we work hard to create a collaborative atmosphere. We are working on bringing a more Diverse voice into this space and continue to expand on the best ideas to help our customers win. 

I love that we can take time to volunteer with our favorite charitable groups. That is important to me, to have an Impact outside of DocuSign. You can tell that everyone just wants the company to succeed. You get to be part of building that success and it is exciting .
cons: Management training is needed. Also advancement focus is needed. We are just beginning to scratch the surface of this issue and steps are being taken to make it better.  No  401k Match yet.

headline: Account Executive
pros: Inbound leads, healthy account base, partner leads, stable product, a product every organization needs, fun to sell the DocuSign solution
cons: Territories always shrink, pricing is difficult to grasp

headline: DocuSign
pros: I love the laid back culture of DocuSign. I feel like I can structure my day as I need to in order to be successful. I truly enjoy my colleagues and feel supported by my manager.
cons: No 401k match, lower base salary than some other market development positions in the area

headline: Full of Opportunity
pros:
- Surrounded by hard working and motivated individuals who all share a common goal
- Working for a Pre-IPO tech Company
- Excellent management that generally cares about your personal advancement
- Great work/life balance
cons: - No matching 401k and some technology restraints

headline: Sales Development Representative
pros:
High volume/fast pace
Excellent potential for growth. 
Collaborative environment. 
Great work/life balance
cons:
-Not great pay. 
-Commission structure does not reward overachieving 
-Inconsistancy amongst different teams

headline: Account Manager
pros: The executive leadership team truly cares about creating a collaborative culture to foster employee growth.  There is an open door policy from everyone I have interacted with so far.  Everyone wants to help out and see you succeed.  As a new hire, this is invaluable and helps you get up to speed and become effective much quicker.  I definitely joined an amazing company and feel very positive about the future of DocuSign and my career trajectory.
cons: No 401k match, but leadership is aware that this is the #1 employee request and it will be a top priority in 2018.  Differences in quotas among the various sales teams drives differing priorities and thus behavior.  However management seems to be open to working through discrepancies.

headline: Great place and continuing to get better!
pros: Exciting, changing the world, compassionate management that cares about employees as people, they provide good benefits, give us paid time to work on charities, keep us feed and healthy; overall, great place to work.
cons: Still many processes needing to be worked out, so it can still be confusing and frustrating on who owns what; my point is we are still not good about cross-departmental commitments and communicating about our dependencies upon each other.

headline: Great company with some growing pains and visions towards IPO
pros: Good culture, somewhat flexible working environments, striving to be similar to other modern tech companies with office snacks.  Continue to push towards new and better employee benefits.
cons: Strong push for IPO is leaving a lot of issues unresolved.  Sales can be extra stressful as a result.  Standard corporate culture and policies of upper management keeping rest of company in the dark regardless of attempts of "Town Halls" or other transparency.

headline: SDR
pros: Fun team, free snacks, nice offices
cons: seems to be slow on progression to AE and AM from SDR

headline: Strong direction + leadership
pros:
- C-Suite is taking the company in the right direction and I've never been so optimistic about our future
- Good opportunities to advance if you are proactive about managing your career and are a strong relationship builder
- Diversity programs and IMPACT initiative have helped provide employees with more opportunities to network and give back
cons:
- Still significant politics and layers to navigate
- Not always possible to be entrepreneurial and move quickly given need to socialize and convince big egos
- Poor performers often kept around too long, including managers who are better at managing up than managing their teams

headline: Great place to work for a engineer
pros:
The engineering culture is among the best I've ever worked in.  The people are smart, fun to work with and passionate about doing the right thing.  

There are many technical spaces to work in with lots of interesting challenges.  Leadership is good at aligning peoples interests and kills with problems and then letting them run with the solution and implementation.

The product management folks I work with are great at what they do.  They know the product, what we need to do next and how to help engineering get there.

Flex schedules are a real thing.  People work from home and/or work schedules that fit their life so long as they are available in the office or online during core hours for collaboration.  

Pay isn't as competitive as some other large tech companies, but the trade off is that you work with an engineering team where you know everyone.   There's a lot to be said for that, especially when it comes time to get things done quickly

Aside from being good at the core things that I value at an employer, there are are nice perks you would find at a startup.  Free food and beverages, donuts and bagels on Friday, beer on tap, very nice facilities with great collaboration spaces, scooters, team outings, etc.
cons:
Very high work tempo from time-to-time can get you a little burned out, but that's true for any companies doing great things.  

401K match would be nice

IPO has been on the horizon for years

Some places in engineering, PMO is imposed and it doesn't always work.

headline: Love this company
pros: I am a remote employee 3000 miles away from the Corporate HQs but still feel like a part of the team.  They do a great job with enablement and keeping even remote staff involved.  I love working for an organization where they provide ample opportunity (i.e. 2 VTO days) to get out in my community and volunteer and even provide an amazing employee match program for contributions to my favorite charities.
