Their recent addition of 6 mo maternity leave is fantastic.  The leadership here is excellent and I feel like I am in wonderful hands with the direction of where we are going.  I also feel like they have a very strong work life balance culture here, which is very important to me.  It makes me WANT to give back to the company even more -works out very well.
cons: No 401K match.  Not as easy as I would like to refer great candidates to the organization.

headline: Great Culture & Success Driven
pros:
Admittedly, I've been with the organization for under a year however DocuSign is the only company I've worked for that seems to truly craft an innovative strategy while putting their employees first.  They offer a great work life balance, good growth opportunities, strong benefits, and awesome team members to collaborate with.  

Also, I find great satisfaction working a company that changes the way people interact and do business.  It's hard to go back to thinking about printing loads of paper to throw a signature on it.
cons: One of the downsides to date is there is no 401k match which is a benefit that I've come to expect.

headline: Friendliest Most Welcoming Wonderful Company!!!
pros:
I have nothing but positive things to say about this Company. I meet somebody new every day, and am always greeted with a smile. I feel so welcome here, and appreciated for the hard work that I do! The quality of the people at this company are like no other. 


The aesthetics... The building is in a great location, the snacks and drinks are fantastic (especially the fruit and veggies!) 

The management style is open and again, welcoming... I feel comfortable sharing my opinion, and at the risk of sounding like a broken record, I feel valued. I am thankful to work for such a wonderful company.
cons: I have nothing negative to say.

headline: Great Team and Energy
pros:
-Great benefits
-High energy, growth environment
-It feels good to be part of helping companies get away from paper process and onto a modern digital platform
-Great team of people to work with - lots of smart people
-My team in the Customer Success group:
---has remote work with flexibility
--- is organized to be very self-directed
---Has a lot of room to make the job your own, in terms of how you structure your day and what kinds of verticals or projects you can take on
cons:
-Some people will find a high growth company environment like this, where there is a lot of fast-paced change, to be stressful or frustrating
-Some people might want my team's work in Customer Success to be more structured and well-defined

headline: Analyst
pros: Great atmosphere - rapidly growing company.
cons: Drawn out recruiting process - recruiters took a long time to get back each round.

headline: DocuFamily
pros: Have been here for only a month so far and have made great friends and have significantly expanded my network. Everyone is friendly, helpful and genuinely want you to succeed at work. Management is approachable and care about their team's well-being on a business and personal level. I felt like they were invested in me during onboarding as a new hire and appreciate the consistent efforts to check in with my learning progression.
cons: I have no cons so far

headline: DocuSign is a great place to work. Great team of people who will lead company.
pros: Great team of people who know what they are doing. DocuSign finally has a plan that should help them evolve for the next 3-5 years. Very flexible job and great opportunities for career advancement and flexible with transfers from team to team or even position switch.
cons: No 401K matching. DocuSign tends to be slow to adopt new innovative technology or features until competitors beat them to it.

headline: Easily the Best Place I've Ever Worked
pros:
- Talented people working towards a clear goal.
- Competitive salary.
- Leadership is approachable, open, and in-touch.
cons: - With a growing remote workforce, more energy needs to be spent reaching out and bringing the culture to them.

headline: Sales Analyst
pros: Management support and pursue innovative ways to improve
cons: The marketing team and the sales team could be better aligned

headline: Love it!
pros: Great product and even better culture.
cons: Could have better benefits like 401k match.

headline: Another year, another review!
pros:
Let's see, it's been a bit over two years for me. A lot has changed in that time, and I'd easily say most of it for the better. 

The company continues to grow, but the neck-breaking pace of my first 1-2 years has slowed. It feels more sustainable (we're definitely still growing) and that the focus is on maturity. 

We have a new CEO that seems to know what he's doing, or at least what he wants to do. He's been very consistent, very open, and prioritizes communication and answers the hard questions. 

The goals for the company are well outlined and the future is in sight. There are still more changes to be made for all the orgs within the company to align, but those changes are well on their way and so far they seem well thought out and appropriate.

There continues to be an abundance of opportunity to serve in our local communities through IMPACT events. And while the internal socializing (happy hour) has been cut back, when we do have them, they seem to be higher quality and worth while. 

Personally, I've been given a lot of opportunity to grow and succeed here. I am proud of what we do as a company, and blessed to be apart of it with. I look forward to many more years of learning, being challenged, and ultimately, growing.
cons:
With our IPO around the corner, you feel the belt tightening. More scrutiny for travel and money expenditure in general, but I'd say it's both a good thing and to be expected. 

Our benefits are slowly, but surely, expanding with the most recent being 6 months of leave for a new child, which is incredible. But, this is the con section, so I'll say that I hope our benefits in the area of 401k matching materialize after our IPO. 

There's still some inter-org struggles in terms of communication and usage of resources, but the silver lining is that our leadership is aware and directly working on it now. I feel it will be addressed by the end of this year and we'll be able to move forward better united.

headline: Honest review
pros:
Solid product
Training on product is fantastic.
They hire the right people.  Makes it easy to work here
Culture is by far the most positive without being corny
Direct supervisors give:
 constructive feedback , 
decisions that shape us positively, 
fight hard to keep the culture positive
They have done the job before and are directly impacted by our performance, they have  a huge stake
cons:
More independence- don't treat everyone the same if we are performing well with early stand ups and working from home should be a more open option as often as we'd like.
Training needs to be more specific, organized and with intent for AM's.  
Better spiffs for over stretching goals, not gifts but maybe days off, parking pass,

headline: Market Development Representative
pros: Fast growth company that has continues to keep a great company culture.
cons: Miscommunication because of the fast growth is common

headline: Consultant
pros: Great Benefits - just announced 6 months mat leave! Amazing company culture, flexible work hours and wfh. Love the 3 days VTO (volunteer time off) as well. Incredibly generous with food/snacks and lunches from time to time. Wonderful job for a great work-life balance.
cons: Opportunities in advancement and work load is highly reliant on who your manager is. Seems promotions are not a direct result of skill-set and ability, more of who you know which can be deflating. Still fall back on a "start-up" culture, but have had enough years to get more structure in place already.

headline: Great place to work, if you can keep up
pros: DocuSign is the best company I have ever worked for.  The pay, benefits and work life balance are all better than at most companies.  What I like best is the people and the culture.  Its great to work for a company that has so much potential, and with people who share a common goal.
cons: The pace of change can be challenging.  DocuSign has grown so fast that it has gone through 10 years worth of growing pains in the past 2 years.  Sometimes these changes aren't communicated very well, or happen at the last minute.

headline: A Company I'm Proud to Work For
pros: As with any company that you would want to work for the best thing is the people.  Management is genuinely dedicated to building a great company not just in terms of the software we build.  The amount of work that we do with charities and non-profits gives a sense of higher purpose while still reaping the benefits that come with working for a for-profit institution.  DocuSign treats employees very, very well.  The benefits are great and stocked kitchens are a perk that is extremely nice to have.
cons: As with any company there are resource constraints that can be frustrating.  There are also communication issues sometimes between departments.

headline: Happy here, hoping to move higher!
pros: Great pay and benefits, no subject is taboo, casual atmosphere, we're all a team here. Lots of career improvement opportunities and on-site resources.
cons: Software development moves fast and it can be difficult to keep everyone up to date on the most recent changes or plans.

headline: Fantastic experience
pros: I've been at DocuSign just a few months and it's been an absolute pleasure and a truly eye-opening experience as to how great a work atmosphere can be.  The level of enablement is outstanding and the employees here are always extremely helpful and willing to assist with any questions/concerns I've had.  I have yet to meet a disgruntled co-worker which, in my experience, is an anomaly.  The benefits are great as well.
cons: Can't come up with any cons as of yet.

headline: "Awesome first job!"
pros: Great culture, awesome benefits, work life balance. This is my first job out of college and I absolutely love it. The management and culture is amazing.
cons: I do not have any cons.

headline: Still having fun, and you're still the one
pros: 5+ years in, and the culture in engineering hasn't really suffered from all the growth.  Great people to work with; smart, fun, kind, helpful.  Lots of great projects in the pipeline.  Good work/life balance.
cons: Compensation could be better (if you start low, hard to increase to industry levels).

headline: Excellent Opportunities for Impact
pros: You have the opportunity to make a real impact, and to grow your career here - regardless of what level you're at now.   As a Canadian employee, benefits and salary are competitive for similar tech roles, with considerable upside opportunity for growth.
cons: Still a relatively young company, and there are some growing pains as we continue to expand, including needed maturity of processes, increasing global perspectives and employee engagement outside of main office hubs / locations.  As a whole, we need to get better at engaging with a global workforce.   These are normal maturation steps, and ones that are clearly being considered and acted upon.

headline: Great Framework for Success
pros:
Highly supportive leadership - Managers genuinely want you to succeed and give you the tools you need to do so. 
Sales enablement training program allows continuous improvement.
Flexible with schedules and occiasional WFH, leadership realizes we have lives and commitments outside of work too, and respects work/life boundaries.
Awesome people - The best team I have ever worked with. Highly capable and motivated group. DocuSign hires the best and expects the best, and it shows. Colleagues always willing to help and share knowledge.
Great benefits - PTO, Volunteer time off, excellent medical
cons:
Rapid Growth sometimes leaves ambiguity in priorities and direction
No 401k Match (yet)

headline: Giant Company with a Small Company Feel
pros: The level of interest DocuSign has in my well-being is unparalleled. The training is thorough and detail oriented, the benefits are amazing, and everyone on the team is available to help at any given moment.
cons: The number of phone calls a day is revisited every day. If you're timid of getting on the phones, this isn't the position for you.

headline: Great Place To Work
pros: Great Product. Good culture and benefits. Excellent team.
cons: Can't think of any cons

headline: SDR @ DocuSign = Great 1st Job out of College
pros: The onboarding/training process is extremely thorough and helpful (especially in the SDR role). In addition, the more tenured reps are more than willing to go out of their way to help newer reps. Managers encourage a healthy work/life balance and no one is punished for taking full advantage of their PTO. Great company culture - the Impact team does a lot of charity/volunteer work and every employee feels like part of a bigger team!
cons: There isn't any 401K matching.

headline: I wasn't impressed
pros: Great snacks and the majority of my co-workers were genuinely great people.
cons: As long as you are not in Support, DocuSign can be a great place to work. If you decide to work for DS support be prepared to be micro-managed to the extreme while being told by upper-management "this isn't a Call Center" because we don't black-out (block) the windows .... Really???

headline: DocuSign Rocks!
pros: DocuSign as a company and a product, offers continual innovation and growth. However, the best part for me is the culture. My team has great chemistry and we all have each other's backs. I have been with the company over three years and couldn't be happier to work here.
cons: There aren't many for me personally, but I would like to have more insight on the overall roadmap for the company.

headline: Remote Sales
pros: Excellent immediate management, impressive executive leadership and extremely helpful culture between teams and functional areas of the company.
cons: Very busy pace but not an issue for me personally.

headline: Really exceptional
pros:
DocuSign is highly unusual.  Talented team.  Great customers.  Superb technology. 
A management team that gets it.  Smart colleagues that you genuinely like.  Cool offices in SF & Seattle.  And a market where it's not all done.  Truly a fun place to make an impact.
cons: For the right person & role, there are very few cons.  We have many more teams and people onboard than we did a few years ago.    It's hard to get to know people from different departments and stay connected everywhere.  You catch up with folks when you can....

headline: Great place to work
pros: Diversity, communication, good salary, open ears, exciting work environment, work with the best set of brains around the world, great work/life balance, excellent management of urgencies.
cons: Hard to think of any.

headline: Great company with loads of opportunity!
pros:
Wonderful Coworkers who are supportive.
Great Product that is easily supported
Nice office space in the city
Snacks and beverages
Nice desk and work spaces(standing/sitting desks are a plus)
Benefits are really great - 4 weeks PTO 3 VTO days, great medical, dental and vision. Really cant beat it.
Lots of volunteer opportunists
cons: There is not much to say here. I would like to see a 401K matching, but I think this will come in a little more time.

headline: Startup energy with a (surprisingly) mature culture
pros: Management genuinely cares about workers and their career advancement--for which there are many opportunities. There's a healthy blend of young, energized newbies as well as more experienced tech professionals that makes for a great work-a-day culture. It's a great combination--plenty of new ideas and enough practical experience to achieve them.  During my last review, my manager said she was more interested in building upon my strengths than obsessing over my weaknesses. After 20+ years in tech, that seemed to me a profound statement.
cons: Communication between departments is not as free-flowing as it could be.

headline: Great work/life balance.
author_position: Software Development Engineer In Test III
pros: Management is very flexible with respect to working remotely. Also work/life balance is good since we account for development/testing/incident-handling on a biweekly planning meeting.
cons: Getting to senior involves having visibility like giving out talks, or organizing general meetings, etc., sometimes without providing much value. I would prefer if technical expertise and consistent execution were rewarded instead.

headline: Exciting company with some growing pains
pros: Great product that everyone needs. Excellent team mates. Competitive pay.
cons: Company continues to grow quickly, and processes and management don't always keep up.

headline: Energetic, focused and fast-paced
pros:
- Energetic
- Fast-paced
- Focused on upcoming IPO
- Great vibe
- Possibilities of progression 
- Good salary
cons: - No marketing support for non-core markets

headline: I love DocuSign!
pros: Great product, people, leadership and work life balance.
cons: For the size of the company there have been challenges with internal processes however slowly getting better.

headline: Exciting time to be at DocuSign!
pros:
Great work life balance
Solid product that people love
Nimble mentality, able to propose and implement change
cons:
Silos do exist between some departments
There's a sense of "group" with your team, but not really with the rest of the company, but this doesn't necessarily impact your day to day
Career growth paths are not always laid out or available

headline: Awesome sales org!
pros: I love being an Account Executive here. Management takes care of their teams. It's a casual environment and everyone keeps it real. There are learning opportunities everywhere - whether you're junior trying to learn from the best or if you're senior and want the opportunity to coach your teammates. Very collaborative. I've referred two close friends here.
cons: The sales team and company is growing, so territories are changing often.

headline: Best job I've ever had
pros: Great culture, leadership and diversity.  Everyone is willing to listen and collaborate, without putting themselves first.
cons: Commute to Seattle is rough, bus system helps.

headline: Super impressed with hiring and on boarding so far
pros:
I am on week 1 but from the moment I began interviewing, it was clear that Docusign employees are down-to-earth, fun and passionate group of people. The on boarding process has been fantastic so far with everyone willing to help out and answer questions. - 
Amazing group pf people. Products people love. Great office locations. Work for The leader in digital transformation, great benefits and work autonomy.
cons: None so far. It's fast moving so there might be processes that need ironing out. Systems could get streamlined but all of this is growing pains.

headline: Software Engineering at DocuSign
pros:
- Clearly communicated vision for developing future opportunities while maintaining current strengths
- Culture of helpfulness
- Easy to adjust work hours to accommodate life needs
- Dedication to diversity and service to the community
- Promising equity benefits
cons:
- Commute distance (to downtown Seattle from far suburbs)
- Medical coverage provides fewer Chiropractic and Naturopathic visits than my last employer

headline: Account Executive
pros: Great product and sales team.  Lots of innovation and customers love the product. Great CEO and Chairman of the Board
cons: Need to invest more in marketing the solution

headline: Great place to work and to evolve !
pros:
Independance 
Acitivity management 
Atmosphere
Team spirit 
Challenging
cons: I really don't know what to say...

headline: Ideal Work Life Balance
pros: It sounds trite, but the people make DocuSign an amazing place to work.  Everyone I have met during my time at DocuSign has been kind, considerate, and generally happy people, which makes it a pleasure to come into work each day.
cons:
-Not a high-intensity work environment (could be a pro for some) 
-Many remaining inefficiencies from the start-up phase

headline: Lots of change, but good change
pros: Fun culture, great management, good people all around!
cons: Frequent changes and startup culture can be difficult to adjust to for some.

headline: Working Mom Not Only Survives But Thrives at DocuSign
pros: As a mom of 2 boys under the age of 10, I have to use my work hours and team resources wisely. DocuSign has a great policy of allowing employees to work remotely and it helps cut down on commute times and parking costs. Plus, it allows the kind of flexibility needed for being a working parent of a child with medical conditions that require many doctor visits through out the year. Additionally, there is lots of surface area for growing and expanding one's professional path. There is great opportunity for career growth and ample ways to learn new skills with many leaders who are willing to mentor and sponsor -- so long as I clearly map out what I'm trying to grow in to and where I could use support.
cons: The company doesn't offer a 401K match yet but I hope to see that change in the near future.

headline: spectacular workplace with a successful global brand and a bit of growing pains
pros:
- great people, stability, the product is a golden goose
- mobility is high as long as proficiency and exposure is achieved
- wide range of opportunities and disciplines
- massive data sets for reporting
- standard technology with marketable value
- always something important to work on and the support to do it
- a lot of good thought to global expansion and the future
- global brand and array of offices facilitates travel
cons:
- maturity level of a lot of developing processes can be frustrating
- poor management of internal tooling for the most part (independent of product)
- the conflict between corporate culture and startup culture can be jarring
- a lot of attributes of the company will vary widely between roles
- employees that express gross incompetence tend to remain employed indefinitely

headline: Incredible Benefits, Solid People, Dynamic Product
pros:
-As a young sales professional, this is one of the most supportive environments I could imagine
-Incredible benefits
-Feeling of making a positive impact every day with our product
cons:
-Salaries are below market value
-Still experiencing some growing pains, people stepping on each other's toes
-Turnover in sales that impacts other teams

headline: An awesome place to work
pros:
Really pleasant, collaborative environment
Workplace services and IT rock
Interesting work on a variety of projects
Very diverse which is GREAT
cons:
Banking level security makes business processes cumbersome
We're working on more professional development opportunities

headline: Great Company to Develop Your Skills
pros:
-Training, training, training! Always helping you prepare for the next role.
-Never gets boring working here - you get to do business with every kind of company
cons: -The company is growing fast, and there's a bottleneck in some "next level" positions

headline: 4 stars
pros:
Excellent Product
Global Reach 
Smart and Great Teams
cons:
Benefits - paternity and 401K
Changes often/change management
Internal system structure

headline: One of the best work places for a software engineer
pros:
Work with highly skilled, capable software engineers and product managers
Good compensation and benefits package
Work on innovative technology that changes how people operate business transactions
Medium-size company, not yet public, with a open minded and modern culture
cons: Downtown Seattle can be expensive to drive and park

headline: Pre-Sales Group at DocuSign
pros: DocuSign has a super talented group of employees that also have a strong work ethic, it is a very powerful combination.  This is also true for the Pre-Sales team, we have a team with a wide array of talent from deep business experience as well as a team of technical folks that know all aspects of the API.  The team is always willing to lend a hand and help each other.  We are empowered thru to help mange and contribute thru all aspects of our opportunities by a fantastic VP.  I have been doing pre-sales work for more than 20 years and this is my most rewarding stop over my career.
cons: More products to sell.  Good news here is this is quickly change since the VP in change of product was switched out about 18 months ago.  One other issue is the fact that there still is no matching in the 401K.

headline: Excellent Company With Growth Potential
pros: Product, Platform, Industry Leader, Work/Life Balance, Employees
cons: High Targets, Territory Alignment, End of Quarter Stress

headline: Freedom+Support
pros: You'll be presented with opportunity to grow and expand in a huge number of ways. If you find something that is interesting to you, you'll be encouraged to pursue it. If Infosec is your thing I couldn't recommend another company more highly, we have world class leaders in Infosec brought together from across the globe. The Seattle office has a great view, good snacks, and beer on tap.
cons: Everyone is busy, if you're stuck on something it's easy to feel a "hurry up and wait" mentality as you get input from others.

headline: Immense Opportunities with Great Culture!!!
pros: There's immense opportunity to grow within the company and try many different roles. The company also invests in its employees, which is a great feeling to feel valued. I have been promoted multiple times during my 3 years at DocuSign, and it's thanks to management's desire to continue helping people grow. Not to mention that the people are terrific here!
cons: They still don't match 401k. Everything else is great.

headline: Sales
pros: Collaborative culture, Strong Leadership, Market Leader, High Energy, Fast Growth, and an overall FUN place to be right now!  DS is coming out with more and more products and continuing to build a solid strategy to gain more share - it is all about the PEOPLE and they have a great team!
cons: DS is stil operating a little like a start-up - which is part of the reason its a great place to be - but we still need to focus on growing out process and approach to business.

headline: Fun at First
pros: The company culture is good, and they make sure that it's a pleasant place to work in terms of co-workers.
cons: Advancement opportunities are difficult to come by, particularly if you are a woman.

headline: Great company to work for!
pros: Great culture, good communication from senior management, flexible wfh policy, good benefits, nice people!
cons: No catered lunches, not sure of career opportunities for advancement, but maybe i'm not looking hard enough

headline: Techincal Customer Success Manager
pros: Great benefits, excellent working environment, wonderful co-workers. I've been at quite a few start-ups and tech companies in the Northwest and this has been by far the best one. I get to have a life outside of work and actually get to take PTO.
cons: Not anything that I can say is actually a con at DocuSign.

headline: Love DocuSign
pros:
- Great Managers
- Fantastic colleagues
- Exciting product
- Free food
cons: - the salary can be a bit lower than industry standard (only reason I would have docked a star)

headline: Flexibility in work and helpful colleagues
pros: Managers give  time and importance to each individual which makes the person believe in the company and work hard in their positions.
cons: No 401K is offered as of now

headline: It's good now, but it should be the best.
pros:
Great environment. Good opportunities are on the road.
The benefits are good.
cons:
No career opportunities. The career program just exists in paper.
Company wants to do higher growth but do not have focus in marketing. Sales need to focus in new areas.

headline: Culture still old-school compared to many companies in the Bay Area
pros:
1. Culture is very flexible 
2. Managers aren't micro-micromanaging.  Employees are friendly 
4. office is in a great location - right down the street from Bart/Muni/ Transbay Terminal 
5. Interviewing here was good, because it felt more like they were trying to get to know you rather than judge you based only on your skills
cons:
1. They don't offer a great deal of perks such as gym reimbursement, parking, educational class allowance. Their transportation allowance barely makes a dent. 
2. Administrative professionals are under-appreciated and lack fair pay
3. Teams/ departments feel separated. (if you go to a company event you'll feel like everyone is a stranger besides the few people you work with)
4. Their payables, purchasing teams and processes can use a great deal of improvement - simple tasks can take months/weeks. lack of response and unclear procedures are rampant. 
5. on-boarding new employees process should be more professional. (i.e. give a tour of the office, encourage managers to setup a lunch with their new employee on the first day instead of making them sit through orientation, introduce them to key people, and make them feel more  welcomed) 
6. better pay raises and career grown for any administrative professional

headline: Great Product, Lack of Accountability and Focus on Customer Success
pros: Great product, customers love the ease of use, flexibility.  The potential is significant!
cons:
Not the best talent, people lack accountability, management does not hold people accountable.  Many customer facing account managers lack fundamentals in account management and customer adoption.

Lack of true focus on customer success and adoption.  Customers see a revolving door.

Lack of focus of product direction.  Product releases do not move the needle (drive more revenue), lack of focus in building out the solution to address enterprise standards.

headline: Best place I've worked
pros: Amazing culture where you are supported, feel like you're part of a team, and have a voice. Too many perks to list. By far the best environment I've ever worked in. Everyone works hard, has fun, and helps one another.
cons: There are redundant meetings at times, but it's a difficult balance between keeping all teams/locations in tight communication while also allowing them to be empowered to move forward quickly. I think every company that is growing as quickly as we are would be faced with the same thing.

headline: This is a good place to work.
pros: We going to IPO and we have here Amazing peoples.
cons:
The office is disgusting (very old building !!!)
The promotion here is slow and may not happen at all.

headline: Great benefits!
pros: Besides the obvious, great place to work, great team and management.  What I've found over my four years at DocuSign is they care about making the world a better place and care for their employees.  This includes giving back to the community, to matching donations to charities, and for me (and most importantly) are the employee benefits.  I was diagnosed with Cancer this past year and I've had very little out of pocket expenses.   Which has allowed me to focus on getting better vs worrying about how to pay medical expenses.  Again, DocuSign CARES and I feel fortunate to work for such a great company!
cons: DocuSign is continually evolving, which is fun to be a part of.

headline: Great place to grow a career in Marketing
pros: DocuSign has a positive, energetic culture that's completely authentic. People across the company, in every role and region, go out of their way to share information, best practices, successes, and help each other. There's a real sense of belonging to one company and being in it together.
cons: Being in Australia, we don't always get to connect into all company-wide meetings and sessions. That said, DocuSign does a good job of repeating the important ones in our time zone and also recording and sharing them quickly.

headline: Market Development Representive
pros:
The people I work with are amazing. We have a good culture in the Australian office, and when we do well, we get recognised. 

Management is very supportive as well as fellow team mates. We have a very collaborative team and as we are all in the same building it is easy to walk to someone when we need help with something. 

Office location is the best as it's in the city and close to Circular Quay. Sometimes I'll go for a walk on my lunch break and soak up the sun. 

The Kitchen is well stocked and supplied. And there's always a drink on hand come Friday afternoons.
cons:
Probably the long commute to the city. But that's because I live so far away.

No ping pong table, but we're not an overly big office so that's understandable.

headline: Great placeto work - heaps of opportunities!
pros: DocuSign is growing rapidly and making positive changes along the way - listening to its staff and customers.
cons: Keeping connected in a growing global business is challenging and needs work..

headline: Employees are Valued
pros: All employees are valued and their ideas and feedback are listened to by upper management. The work/life balance is valued and DocuSign does it's part to give back to the community.
cons: Growth can outpace the staffing, but the situation is improving

headline: DocuLove
pros: Great energy with new leadership team, cool office, fun activities, good benefits
cons: Fast-growing company comes with growing pains, pay is below market value

headline: Good company with great potential
pros:
* Large enough to have resources, small enough that employees can still make an impact (you're not a cog in the wheel)
* Great product-market fit with current product with plenty of opportunity for future growth given the right strategic direction and execution
* New-ish management setting clear direction and reinforcing values to get us there
* Overall good people, pockets of excellence and great culture
* Good commitment to diversity (women can do well despite not yet being on the e-staff), non-profits, mentorship
cons:
* Product, systems infrastructure challenges created by growth over the years with little investment in rationalization (being addressed)
* Definitely in transition (for the right candidate, this is actually an area of opportunity)
* Missing some connective tissue in cross-functional projects (also being addressed - and again, for the right candidate, an area of opportunity)

headline: Great place to work
pros: I have worked at a few tech companies and DocuSign has proven itself my favorite.  While some pre (and post) IPO organizations can seem extraordinarily young and immature, DocuSign has been able to maintain a fun culture yet still provide a stable and professional work environment.
cons: There are still some process issues as we continue to grow.  Some processes seem to come a little too late.

headline: Growing Company - Great place to work
pros: Good benefits, product, and mission. Company is growing and everyday is a new challenge, decent work-life balance. Good locations (at least in Seattle and San Francisco)
cons: Lower than market salaries, no 401k matching yet, with growth comes change, some of which is moving towards a much more corporate style of bureaucracy.

headline: SDR
pros: Great training and support from management, they really want you to succeed.  everyone truly works as a team and are always up to answer any and all questions whether it be about the job or your future within the company.
cons: not the best paying within the SDR role

headline: Working Together
pros: At DocuSign I feel like we all work together and support each other. I've worked at a lot of places and never felt that everyone was working towards the same goal until DocuSign.
cons: Some internal processes need to be formalized and service levels established.

headline: Great company culture
pros: I love working with smart, professional and mature co-workers.  We are all here for the same goal, make our customer's successful. Everyone is willing to help each other and share. Benefits are amazing - everything you could ask for and more. The only thing they don't have is match, but instead they give stock to all employees which is more valuable to me anyway.
cons: Communication and access between departments is difficult. It is often hard to figure out who can help something, or how to access information on things outside of your organization.

headline: Account Executive
pros: Leadership, people, benefits (100% covered), culture, great work perks (commuter benefits, catered breakfast and lunches, happy hours, great snacks), very collaborative team environment, great training and onboarding, modern work space, good working hours, committed group of people  wanting the best for the company
cons: None that I've seen so far

headline: Unicorn company with unlimited upside potential
pros: Every big business is looking for digital transformation opportunities and DocuSign is the only eSignature provider that can operate at scale.  There is limitless potential for the growth of the company if strategic plans to scale product offering and internal infrastructure is executed well.
cons: DocuSign is a one-trick pony.  Need more products, which management is aware of an investing in.  There are several mid-sized eSignature providers successfully competing for Commercial-sized organizations' business.

headline: Happy with my DocuSquad
pros: DocuSign is a great place to be. The culture is amazing and extremely supportive. Management constantly shows appreciation of their team's hard work, which is key to keeping people moving in an upwards projection. There is catering all the time, a kitchen stocked with snacks, and comfortable working environments. We do team events around Seattle all the time which are great as well.
cons: They took away the ramp period when you are internally promoted from SDR to MDR, meaning you are on full quota from day 1 in your new position. This will severely affect my annual attainment number, and my income took a dip for the first 2 months which was extremely discouraging. I think this was a poor choice on the company.

headline: Best Job in my Career (so far)
pros:
The people, the people, the people. You'll get an opportunity to work with a bunch of   intelligent, capable, and fun people. The start-up energy is still there although there's a layer of seriousness on top of it now.

Another major plus is the opportunity to step up and take ownership there - as a quickly growing company there are plenty of places that improvements can be made.
cons: Fair amount of change as a growing company - can be a bit much if you're not accustomed to it.

headline: Manager
pros:
DocuSign has many Pros to list, but here are a few: 

Free Food 
Free Drinks 
Safe and Clean work-space
Open work-space 
New CEO Dan is doing a tremendous job at providing direction and cleaning up broken processes.
cons: Only thing I would say, is that there are a few broken processes and areas to improve on.  Really, DocuSigns success has been overwhelming and the company went from small to 2k+ employees overnight. So these are just opportunities to improve, rather than Cons.

headline: Good workplace
pros: Really good people, collaborative environment, great mission, positive product story - everyone knows DocuSign
cons: Siloed, management needs more direction

headline: Sales Development Representative
pros: Lively culture, genuinely want to help, opportunities for growth, take care of their employees, etc
cons: I've experienced nothing negative thus far

headline: Manager
pros: The people here are the BEST - DocuSign does an amazing job recruiting top talent and creating an easy atmosphere for great collaboration to occur.
cons: The pay - out of all the tech companies out there the compensation is the lowest I have heard of.

headline: An amazing opportunity!
pros:
Game changing technology for Pharma, Bio Tech, and Med Device industries. 
And, a dynamic and collaborative culture!
cons: Hiring process was a bit slow.

headline: Friendly & Rewarding Work Environment
pros:
- Easy, quick onboarding process.  From initial phone interview to start date took 1.5 months, this was fast in comparison to recruiting processes I have gone through with other employers.  I was sent to Discovering DocuSign in Seattle and fully on-boarded with dashboards/tools/training within 4 weeks.

- Recurring company-wide, large team, and small team meetings/happy hours and lunches.  Strong sense of connection to the larger organization.

- Communication and open dialogue with employees about future visions and planning for the company.  CEO, CMO, Head of Sales, and Chief Product Officer host town hall meetings and open Q&A for employees worldwide to ask about the proposed direction for the product.

- Periodic rewards and call-outs for high performers on teams

- Great offices!  Fun places to work in convenient, beautiful locations.
cons:
- As the company grows larger, teams struggle to define roles and responsibilities clearly as well as understand who to work with cross-functionally.

- Syncing the third-party communication platforms used internally can be a challenge.

headline: I couldn't ask for a better place to work...
pros:
I've worked at DocuSign for the past 3 years and have found myself again and again reflecting on how thankful I am that this is where I wound up working out of college. I've been blow away by the continual career growth opportunities I've been given and leadership's continued willingness and flexibility to work me to ensure a long and fruitful relationship.

The work/life balance is great. The people I work with are great. Compensation is highly competitive and the company is on a fantastic trajectory.

DocuSign's also recently approved an employee-match program for charitable donations which I think is a very cool illustration of senior leadership's commitment to social impact and supporting employee's personal and professional passions.
cons: Very high expectations and a lot of pressure/stress in the sales org. It is a very quarterly-driven environment and the last 2 weeks of every quarter are intense. This is something I personally appreciate -- but would not be ideal for all personality types.

headline: Great company that continues to experience strong growth
pros:
- Exciting company that continues to innovate across industries and geographies 
- Leadership does a good job communicating with all employees 
- Flexible work environment
cons: - Remote employees can sometimes feel less engaged/connected with west coast mothership

headline: Great Company with talented people and interesting tech challenges
pros:
- Docusign is the leading online e-signature company with many interesting and technical challenges. 
- They have really amazing products and features with new ones coming in all the time.
- Its a great place to work with great benefits and really nice office locations in San Francisco and Seattle
- Work/Life balance is really good with flexible hours as well as allow to work from home when needed. Best I've seen in most companies I've worked for
- What makes DocuSign standout from the rest are the people who work there. I have been here for less than a year and I was impressed with how I was treated and continue to be treated as a valued coworker.
cons:
- Very few cons to working here
- Technical stack to learn for an engineer can be overwhelming but the on-boarding  experience is really good and they are very patient allowing you to learn at your own pace.
- Communication between teams can be lacking but they are working on this.

headline: Best Place to Work
pros: Small company allows for everyone to pitch in their own ideas. There are no glass ceilings as the company is always hungry for hard workers with great ideas! When I am ill, or a family is, I can work from home instead of having to use my PTO. They are more than willing to accommodate my schedule so I can go to doctors appointments or receive packages at home as well
cons: Feels there could be better communication between different departments

headline: Business Developement
pros: DocuSign has an amazing culture and truly the best employees! I love coming in to work every day - management is stellar as well.  We have great benefits and I know that everyone is looking forward to an IPO! :)
cons: No cons - DocuSign is genuinely an amazing company to work for.

headline: Solid Place to Work
pros:
DocuSign is a place where there are unsolved problems that you'll be able to tackle. One of the best things about DocuSign is that nearly everyone around you is motivated to do a good job.

Dan (new-ish CEO) has been doing a good job of transitioning the company from a very sales driven culture to one that has more balance in how things are prioritized.
cons: If you are at all involved in trying to improve back end processes, you will eventually run into the frustration of trying the get anything done with our Enterprise Apps or Business Intelligence teams, who have a backlog so large that nearly nothing but what top level leadership has their eyes on gets done.

headline: Lots of opportunity for individuals and the company
pros: Great Product and good people.  DocuSign is  open to new ideas, you really can make a difference.  Total compensation is on-par with other high tech companies.  In addition, there is paid time off for volunteerism!  Wow - so impressive!  On-boarding was so easy, including a complete up-to-date checklist for me to follow to get myself set up.  Good work life balance.
cons: Currently no 401k match, discussed as a future goal

headline: Great place to learn and grow
pros:
Transformational technology - it's awesome to be a part of such a shift in how people come to agreement
Lots of opportunity - There's a lot of space to make a mark at the company at any level
cons:
Lack of 401k match, though the options in plan are solid
Parking in the city is expensive

headline: Excellent work culture, Good Benefits
pros:
1. Good pay
2. Health insurance - free, if you are single. For family, still the overall premiums are low
3. Excellent work culture
4. Frequent happy hours
5. Lunch for engineering twice a week
6. Being in startup mode, overall bureaucracy at a very low level
cons: 1. No 401K match yet.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros:
- Flexible Hours and Time off 
- Good work culture 
- Good benefits 
- Great Product
cons:
- Product Managers are disorganized and lack priority skills 
- No clear job role for Program Management org
- Scrum/Agile practices/processes not clear across org

headline: Best Company I've Ever Worked For!
pros: Best in class leadership / Best in class culture / Best in class compensation /
cons: Such an amazing company, everyone wants to work here!

headline: A great choice.
pros:
Simply a great company.  Focused on making a difference and transforming business.  
Cares about and respects its mission, people, customers, and partners!
cons: Sometimes hard to unplug from work.  There's always more to do but we're not bored!

headline: Communication and direction at scale
pros:
For as large a company as it is, Dan and the DocuSign leadership team does a great job communicating on goals. They share the big picture and don't hesitate to answer questions on the specifics. 
Very bright co-workers who are always willing to help doesn't hurt either.
cons: Large companies tend to have some people focus on very specific areas. This can leave you with a lack of generalists. DocuSign suffers from this in certain capacities - people that are wonderful in one capacity but can't help you if you're even remotely outside that boundary.

headline: Grateful to Work at DocuSign!
pros:
Lots of Pros in no particular order:

Great product! It’s been years since I’ve worked at a company with such positive brand recognition.

Excellent location for commuting on public transit.

Generous time off  policy. We get 20 days plus an extra PTO day for our birthday.

Terrific people who are smart, dedicated and very capable. Great leadership.

Competitive benefits - medical, dental, vision, commuter subsidy, 401k, and a free personal DocuSign account.

Socially conscious with matching gifts for non-profit donations and other opportunities to make a difference through the Impact program. Paid volunteer time off.

Very nice working conditions - comfortable office building in SOMA, up to date hardware and software, a well-stock kitchens on every floor.

Wonderful orientation program that really makes you feel a part of the DocuFamily.
cons:
I can find very few Cons:

I dislike the PTO policy that includes sick days. I would like to have a set amount of sick days separate from PTO. It’s a drag to use PTO when you’re sick and it encourages people to come to work sick to conserve PTO.

There are some politics but I feel this is unavoidable in any company - even those who claim to have no politics. It’s just the nature of business.

headline: Passionate, intelligent and driven people with an incessant drive to change the world... work here.
pros:
At the time of writing, I've been here two months. 

Culture
There is a real sense of 'we', 'us' and togetherness at DocuSign that I've never experienced at other SaaS companies, and likely never will again. Sure, we have our branded t-shirts, beer on a Friday, quiz nights but culture means so much more here. 

From the outset at the interview, you sense you are working with a company who carefully considers their Employee experience. Timely, well planned updates and sincere communication, show you how much DocuSign genuinely cares.

Structured on-boarding, coupled with clear objectives at Company and team level ensure everyone is pulling in the same direction. I'm in no doubt of what my team are here to achieve and personally never felt so empowered to drive change - it builds palpable confidence which ultimately benefits our customers in the long run. 

Effective Execution
We own problems. We are accountable. We execute. Every. Single. Damn. Time.  Kind of sums it up.

Born Problem Solvers & Creative People
Solutions, solutions, solutions. It is all you hear in the: canteen, hallways, kitchen, desks, water cooler. Very refreshing to be part of a company that has found their 'why' and sense of identity.

Civil disagreement is welcomed, however, admiring the problem, is not. What kind of work environment does this create? Well rounded, humble human beings who leave their egos at the door and genuinely want to solve real world problems.
cons:
Rapid growth and scale. We are growing rapidly and this creates challenges with regards process.

Having said that, this challenge is why I am here. How do we increase revenue growth YoY, improve Customer experience and develop processes for scale with a smile on our face? (I should put this in Pro).

The faint of heart or adverse to change need not apply.

headline: A great place to grow.
pros: I joined DocuSign 6 months ago and so far my experience has been mostly great. The people here are smart, take their jobs seriously, and aren't afraid to ask questions. In fact, from the leadership team down, people are encouraged to be curious and find new ways to do things. Also, my manager is incredible. I've never worked at a company where I feel my manager truly has my best interest in mind and is very transparent with me. I will grow so much from being under her guidance.
cons: With a new CEO and some management changes, attrition has grown. It would be nice if more people rode it out to see what happens. Change isn't always a bad thing.

headline: Fantastic product and team
pros:
Fast paced environment. New challenges all the time. Friendly colleagues, good HR policy (France).
Awesome product and amazing interface that convicts customers on itself.
A great company to grow up.
cons:
Politics. Never seen so many political decisions that are not helping the company's growth.
American company which needs to reinvent itself to conquer Europe

headline: Excellent Place to Grow
pros: Colleagues are so eager to share best practices, and experiment with new strategies. It makes it a constant hive of learning and collaboration that management is very supportive of.
cons: There can be significant burn out within this role, and since the company has been growing substantially it can sometimes feel like there is a bottleneck in terms of career advancement.

headline: Good people, good products
pros:
The product is changing the way business is done.
The company is growing, which presents career opportunities for development and advancement.
Great opportunities to give back through your work with a volunteer time-off benefit, a matching gifts benefit, and the ability to donate DocuSign to small charities.
Nice offices to work in, good snacks, good views, close to transportation in downtown SF.
cons: Can be very silo-ed, especially in the go-to-market area, with marketing, sales and product/engineering not always in lock step.

headline: Great place to work - if you can handle the stress
pros:
Great people
Decent pay
Good office perks
cons:
Expectations are not set or measured correctly
Company already gave out most of its shares to it's VC firms,  not much to go around to the employees
Questionable senior level decisions / people

headline: Remote Worker
pros: Positive growth, decent benefits, pay is pretty good
cons: if you are remote you can sometimes be forgotten, but that happens anywhere.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros:
- Great location
- Smart & friendly people
- Growing rapidly 
- Great opportunities to learn & grow with the company
cons:
- As the company gets larger roles & responsibilities become more specialized 
- Lots of change in management

headline: Very unbalanced workload - most underpaid, some overworked
pros: Work-life balance is only existent if you happen to land on the right team. Colleagues are generally very supportive of each other (management is not).  Everyone I see works hard - there are no slackers here. Snacks are pretty good. 20 days of vacation time is not bad either.
cons: Sales operations and finance in San Francisco are understaffed and overworked. Management hears complaints, makes promises to change, but does not actually act. There is no room for career advancement and there is no time for professional development. There are too many managers for a company this size. Sometimes managers do not even have direct reports. Management rarely promotes from within. They would rather hire someone from the outside with more experience than develop their existing employees. A path to promotion is extremely unclear- criteria seems to be based on tenure and office politics rather than merit. Accounting does not believe in promotions and raises outside of the annual focal cycle, so if you may have to wait almost 2 years to be considered for promotion if you time it wrong. This policy is grossly unfair since other departments do not enforce this rule and many people in other departments get promoted outside of the annual focal. DocuSign claims to pay at the 50th percentile, but it's low for San Francisco. Since salary is so low, everyone is counting on a successful IPO to make it worth it to stay.

headline: Director
pros:
1. The product/service itself. DocuSign is so much more than a web site. It's a business to business platform. And also a grand unification of security, trust and signature technologies. It's flexible and powerful.
2. The people. Everyone here wants to work and is good at what they do. The people here are genuinely nice - and hard working! We hire unusually excellent people who are great fits for the DocuSign culture. We have a virtuous cycle here - experienced, mature, nice people refer more experienced, intelligent, nice people.
3. Working at a small company means you have much more opportunity, more impact, more visibility into corporate development and access to senior leadership. How often do you have regular conversations with senior vice presidents in the kitchen and hallways?
cons: Growing pains. Having to prioritize among many important objectives. Having to live within a budget of limited resources when our ambitious and potential are so great.

headline: Great so far
pros:
From the day i started I have felt like a part of my team right away.  The company is fairly transparent with goals and expectations, onboarding process was smooth and the perks of working here are great (many team outings, diverse personalities on the team, stocked kitchen, great health benefits).  

the company is growing which leaves a lot to aspire to.

the product is very sound and customers overall see the value very quickly which is more than half the battle.  

i have never worked somewhere where so many people genuinely seem to want you to succeed and are helpful, from fellow account managers to AE's to technical teams- i really do feel supported and all i have to do is take everything in, give it my all and ramp up fast.  its truly an amazing culture that i had not seen before.
cons: nothing out of the ordinary for a sales role, sometimes things can be stressful but thats the nature of the beast.

headline: Improving Company, Terrible Department
pros:
- Good Work Life Balance
- Generous Benefits
cons:
- Low Balled on Salary, a new hire on my team with the same role makes 15% more than me and I was not offered any level-setting
- Management did not listen to constructive criticism of existing processes 
-Department Leadership has driven away talented persons
-Culture of Claim Credit when times are good but shirking responsibility when times are bad

headline: Highest Caliber People!
pros: The PEOPLE!   The talent at DocuSign is great to work with and helps build a great long lasting network while learning from people who are the best at what they do.  It is also great selling and supporting a good product that you know is helping people.
cons: Growing competition, but you can't expect to be the only player in a multi-billion dollar space forever!

headline: Great potential, great product, lot of work to be done
pros: Best product in the market, great brand recognition, good balance of work/life, lots of flexibility in your day to day work.
cons: It's an operational mess, still running the day to day like a small startup, seemingly a lot of confusion about how to get the company to the next level.

headline: Account Executive
pros: Company culture.  I truly enjoy the people that I get to work with everyday.  DocuSign has an industry leading product with limitless potential.  For the most part, we have management teams that are invested in your success and are great to work for.
cons: Sales Ops, for a lot of reasons.

headline: Account Manager
pros: Great culture, great product, and high growth company. Consistent internal promotion opportunities.
cons: High growth organizations can have some challenges that come along with constant change.

headline: Commercial Account Manager
pros: Great team, great company! Love working here.
cons: Under a lot of transitions. Teams and territory changes etc.

headline: Now that the Enterprise Sales Swamp has been drained, it could be a great place to work!
pros: Great, intuitive product.  Customers definitely see value in the solution
cons: Salaries were far too low, quotas were far too high forcing many good people to leave the business.  This may have changed with the new Enterprise Sales regime change early February, 2017.

headline: Market Development Representative
pros:
Brilliant Company to work for.
Fast progression 
Strong Managers
cons:
Little  disorganized at times 
No clear rules for prospecting

headline: Uneven experience
pros:
- Some really great people and lifelong friendships were made
- Fully stocked kitchen
- Work-life balance (i.e. Work from home)
- Location of SF office is really easy to get to via transit
cons:
- A very obvious lack of diversity starting from the C-level and in pretty much every department
- Terrible maternity/paternity policy - it's the bare minimum for a tech company. It's actually pretty embarrassing when talking to other people in tech
- Very political and lack of transparency from mid-level managers
- Some very inappropriate behavior and comments from both female and male senior management to employees (and very little is done about it when reported)
- In my experience - managers don't grow and mentor their staff to senior positions and instead hire in senior managers (that bring their own people)

headline: Never boring!
pros: Great culture, constant innovation, really smart people and the benefits are really good.    The engineering team stayed together and killed it even during the tumultuous year before the new CEO started.    The new CEO is great - the company is getting more focused.
cons: Too many great ideas without quite enough people to deliver.

headline: SDR department great to place your career in sales
pros: The SDR department at DocuSign is great chance for young professionals to launch their career in sales. Management gives everyone ample amount of training and resources.
cons: DocuSign is still relatively young company that experiences a lot of fast changes

headline: High performing teams, great work culture
pros:
- Leadership - Takes suggestions and feedback seriously as part of the CEO's commitment to having DocuSign be a great place to work. 
- Innovation - Product team is constantly improving the core offering while coming up with more intuitive technology to help businesses move quicker, more efficiently and effectively.
- Talent - Smart, driven, experienced, high-performing people work at DocuSign. Everyday, I find that I learn something new from somebody here. 
- Benefits are solid. Great health, dental, vision. The snacks stands, refrigerators and kitchen are always stocked with enough fuel foods to get us through the day. Also, the employee stock plan is generous. 
- Focused on performance.  I appreciate DocuSign's focus on consistently over-performing. As a sales organization, there's a powerful focus on becoming a predictable revenue generating SAAS machine. If you like performing at a high level in a sales organization, you'll do well here.
- Opportunity. DocuSign's mission is to rid the world of paper. A tall stand for sure. Yet, I've noticed an innate confidence that the company will reach that objective. What's more is our customers LOVE DocuSign. They literally say that. On the phone. In texts. In emails. In person. It's fun selling a product that people love.
cons: - Benefits missing - no 401k matching and health/wellness programming isn't a focus i.e. Gym membership reimbursement isn't impressive.

headline: Great introduction
pros: Fantastic team and great business.  I am new and have had a tremendous welcome into this neat culture.  Proud to be at DocuSign.
cons: Managing growth is hard.  Some bureaucracy has slipped into the business.

headline: Fun place to work!
pros: The people here in Engineering are really good at caring about the customer, caring about their work, and having fun at the same time - there are a lot of smiles and laughter every day.
cons: We don't have a 401k match.

headline: DocuSign is a great place to work!
pros:
Opportunity to grow
Leadership  genuinely cares about your success at the company
Competitive Compensation
Flexible schedule
Great people
Innovation: creating some great programs to make our company stronger, especially internally.
New parental leave program that serves dads too.
Good culture, but there are efforts to make it even better.
CEO is authentic, not about a bunch of lip service. 
Great internal intranet for employees
Some great groups at the company like LGBT Pride, Women at DocuSign, etc.
Place where you can be yourself and feel accepted
cons:
In the past, it has been hard to move up level wise. You will often see the company bring people outside the organization into leadership positions. (To be fair, they are working on some programs internally to move people up, so this starting to change.) 
It is rare to see  Women or People of Color in leadership positions.

headline: 1 year in and still 5 Stars
pros: Great career advancement.  Opportunity to make a huge impact both in department and in the industry.  All departments have a passion for innovation and it's exciting to set the stage for the upcoming IPO.
cons: IT staff is amazing, but current PC equipment is awful.  Have been through 3 machines in as many months.

headline: CAM
pros: Great culture, people and energy.
cons: 401K match needed once we go public

headline: Great Direction from New Leadership - Positive, Focused & Inspiring
pros: We announce a new CEO in January and a new Chief Strategy & Marketing Officer in April. Both are super impressive.  They are focused on making DocuSign each employee's best place to work (ever), and doing so by engaging, empowering and inspiring. Both have dug deep into the business, are asking all the right questions, and moving the company forward...fast. They have big, inspiring visions, are data driven, and already proving to be the right choices for our business. As excited as ever for our future.
cons: Working through change is never immediately comfortable, until you start to see the positive impact. I believe we are starting to see it across the business.

headline: Grow your career here
pros:
Fair pay and benefits.
Abundant leadership opportunities for the smart & motivated.
Opportunity to represent/sell the undisputed top product in this tech segment.
cons: All the challenges that come with fast growth... always recruiting & training, frequent leadership changes and re-orgs, each person has to cover a lot of activity/territory.

headline: Sales Development Representative
pros: Amazing culture. Imagine working for a company that actually excites you. DocuSign, though it is a relatively young company, is full of brilliant, bright-eyed people who really want you to succeed. I am blown away by how much this company has invested into its employees.
cons: Decent amount of overtime. If you want to get ahead, expect to get in early and put in some extra hours.

headline: Doesn't feel like a start up- well organized with highly motivated individuals who are super helpful across the board
pros: Great down town location, people and culture. They give you all the necessary tools and environment to do your best work.
cons: Might be hard to attract super talent from your Googlers or Facebookers. Total compensation can be more competitive when compared to the "elites"

headline: Account Executive
pros: Fast-paced, challenging environment that cultivates success driven teams
cons: Required to be in the office

headline: A Great Company to Work For!
pros:
- Really nice new office 
- Great people, great managers
- Fun work environment
cons:
- Company keeps growing
- Hasn't gone public...yet
- Turnover rates is getting higher

headline: Director of Operations
pros:
Good product.
Good and motivated people.
Global company and present around the globe.
cons:
A lot of politics.
many changes in management team reflects lack of direction

headline: Chaotic Mess
pros: Docusign should theoretically be a fun/cool pre-IPO start-up but they're not. The best thing about the company is the product which is obviously very recognizable and well liked but that doesn't make the workload or office environment worth it.
cons: Senior management (VPs and above) are not allocating resources appropriately which is resulting in obscene amounts of work for many teams. Workload can be offset, to an extent, with compensation, but even on that front, Docusign falls well short of similarly sized companies. On top of that, lower level employees are borderline disrespected in how they are treated and communicated to. Rather than address any of the structural issues, many senior leaders simply plug their ears and tell their employees to work more. As if 10-12 hours days aren't enough. HR doesn't help matters as I witnessed numerous occasions where employee confidentiality was not respected.

headline: Good culture, old-guard decision making
pros: bright young people, passionate, driven
cons: Old guard is insular and plays office.  Markteting is weak.

headline: Say "Yes" to DocuSign if you get a job offer!
pros:
1. Great product and amazing growth. DocuSign is the founder and leader in the Digital Transaction Management category.
2. Work-life balance is a reality in this company.
3. They are committed to give back to society. The company has a very active IMPACT program and encourages everyone to participate in it.
4. You get to work with smart people who are all team players. Most of the employees are nice to each other and are always ready to help.
5. Go Green! The product not just makes life easy for every customer by reducing paperwork but has a huge positive environmental impact.
6. Free food! The kitchens are always stocked with food and beverages. They also host many lunches and events in the company. 
7. Free health insurance, dental insurance and VSP for every employee.You also get HRA, Travel, FSA benefits.
8. You get to work with a lot of new technologies which makes it very interesting.
9. PTO is good and you also get a day off for your Birthday. 
10. DocuSign customers love the product and you will hear about it all the time. So get used to everyone talking about their experience.
cons:
1. It is in some ways like a startup with gaps in internal processes. Many times you need to know people from different teams to get the job done.
2. Better parental leave policy is a must. What DocuSign offers isn't competitive to what other technology companies offer.
3. No 401k matching at this time.

headline: A great company that listens to all employees
pros: flexible, great management, amazing peers, highly collaborative, listens to all levels
cons:
-pace of change (expected as DS is growing fast)
-benefits are not the best

headline: SDR
pros: Great people, leadership and a great learning opportunity. They make you want to work hard everyday.
cons: Payment Structure, Incentives as a SDR, It's hard to take vacation....

headline: Positive career experience lacks diversity
pros: Growing company, new and exciting technology. Many groups have great managers that really work with you to help further your career. If you get into the right group you have lots of flexibility and support. Good benefits.
cons:
Work life balance and diversity issues. 
Still very male dominated culture. 
Struggle to get fair compensation 
Need a more family friendly environment throughout the company and not department specific

headline: Great company and people!
pros:
* Great transparent
* Smart co-workers
cons: * Seems like there is more red tape than there should be for a company this size

headline: Fantastic company to work for
pros: This is an excellent place to work. Great management. Strong culture. Very professional. Solid strategy. This is an exceedingly well-run company.
cons: Nothing worth mentioning, to be honest.

headline: A great company to work for!
pros:
This is a very dynamic environment and everything is moving all the time. It is very motivating to work in this kind of environment. 
The people are passionate about the product which creates a positive environment to work in and makes you more motivated. 
The careers opportunities are huge because everything is in development and you have your chance to do something different if you want to as people will listen to you.
cons: Because the company is still quite new (especially in EMEA), most of the time the processes don't exist and you have to create them from scratch. This is at the same time a good opportunity but it can make things a bit messy.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros:
Travel - USA & Dublin several times in a year.
flexible working automy
cons: Lots of change  in process

headline: Great Place
pros: Awesome culture, really up incoming.
cons: Moving really fast so promotion may be hard to attain.

headline: Great Company
pros:
A lot of opportunity. 
Great atmosphere
Office location and perks are really good
cons: I do not have any negative point so far

headline: Fast moving fun company
pros: Docusign is by far one of the best companies I have ever worked for.  The Company atmosphere, culture and people are amazing.   They hire young, energetic, fun, talented and generally awesome people so making friends will come easily.  In addition, the Seattle Office is beautiful, sleek and modern with a view of the Puget Sound and Mt. Rainier.   There’s always a company event happening or group you can join.  It’s an exciting and fun company to work for.
cons:
Being an MDR is a grind
Be prepared “to be caffeinated, in seat and ready to rock-n-roll” at 8 am sharp!
This is a high energy, telemarketing job.  Your day will be spent making cold calls and responding to emails all day.   It’s pretty mindless. 
It’s an entry level, high stress, high pressure, low paying job.
Do not take this job unless you are fresh out of college or have very little work experience.  

Micromanaged
It’s a Big Brother type of atmosphere on the MDR Team. By that I mean the Director and Managers watch things like your time in office and out, when you went to lunch, how many calls and emails you make, etc.  I think this is due to a couple different factors. The first being the team has tripled within a year and micromanaging is the only way they feel they have control over results.  The second being, we’re pre-IPO with a new CEO on the “path to profitability” and there’s more pressure coming down on the Director/Managers to produce said results.
Your day is planned for you.  There are call blocks in the mornings and afternoons which are mandatory.  There is also a call minimum of 30+ calls a day which the Director and Managers check daily.  You will get praised or reprimanded on your call volume.
So if you like being an autonomous worker, this job is not for you.

Competition - “Building your Brand”
The competition to move up and get promoted is fierce.
Your reputation and likability are more important than your results.
To get promoted you need to make the right connections and "play the game” to move up. 
Do not rock the boat or speak up about things you do not agree with.  Dissent is not allowed, will be remembered and not tolerated.
More men are promoted than women.  (This may be due to an imbalance in the gender makeup of the sales force but still, it’s noticeable.)

headline: Account Executive
pros: Good product, good field people
cons: Middle management more focused on numbers rather than helping staff, team-building or satisfaction of the customer.  Weakest area is post-sales account management.

headline: VP
pros: Great CEO, Great Market Opportunity
cons: Maturity of Market and Use cases

headline: Great place to work
pros: Everyone loves the product. They hire top caliber individuals from some of the top companies around the globe.
cons: The company is ready for some product innovation.

headline: SDR Role
pros: great culture and training provided
cons:
the SDR position is paid significantly lower than the average SDR in Seattle. 
Can be mundane and repetitive

headline: Market Development
pros: Fast paced work environment and a great company to work for. You will get great sales experience as an MDR at DocuSign and there is plenty of room for growth and career progression.
cons: Becoming very corporate, which is understandable for a company of this size. Strict activity requirements for certain positions that must be met daily/weekly/monthly, regardless of performance.

headline: Sales Development Representative
pros:
- dreamy onboarding experience (Seattle bootcamp)
- efficient manangement 
- excellent team
cons: - more preparation and training for the job

headline: Uneven Experience
pros:
- The product has a lot of use cases for businesses and individuals. 
- There are a lot of smart people at DocuSign and most want to do the right thing for customers. 
- If you work in the right group (or for the right manager), things are usually smooth and easy.
cons:
- If you aren't in the right group, things might not be very smooth and it is easy for your group to get lost in the general shuffle. 
- Plans are often abandoned or not followed through with little or no explanation, rather than being adjusted or examined. 
- Other Glassdoor reviews have comments about communication or cooperation issues being caused by "growing pains" or rapid growth, and having statements like that consistently show up for more than a couple years usually means that they aren't just growth issues but real cultural problems.

headline: Amazing experience!
pros:
-Best Management I have ever had. Great training on how to sell the Sandler way. 
-Fun and young environment, fun work events/happy hours/ competitions
-friendly, competitive environment.
-Snack room with beers on tap! 
-Great benefits- vacation time etc.
cons: Not the highest paying job, but more of a gateway job to break into a sales career.

headline: Inching closer to greatness
pros: Been here for some time now, and our core value proposition has not changed - we still deliver amazing value to our customers.  Always bumps along the way, but feel like we are right at the tipping point.
cons: As we have gotten larger, we've gotten more process heavy, there are more conflicting priorities, and it's just generally harder to navigate the organization.

headline: Intern
pros: Great environment people are friendly
cons: Pay is not very competitive

headline: Great place to be at!
pros:
Nice company with a great vision (get rid of paper) and a very emotional product (got to love it).
Management, co-workers and colleagues are well selected to make sure to also fit into the companies culture besides technical/professional skills. 
Nice customer base. Investing into new markets e.g. EU/EMEA, APAC
cons: Nothing I can think of in particular at the moment.

headline: Fairly transparent work environment
pros: People, People, People.. People are awesome and so willing to collaborate.. In last 6 mos, hardly came across any one who is not willing to collaborate.. Fun loving environment. Management is seasoned, honest and approachable from tech industry per se but not matured enough from overall perspective.
cons: Surprise to see no strategy department.. Probably the first company i have ever worked in my 17 year work career that has no strategy department. Although its a good thing that environment is focused on execution but as the old saying goes, "Strategy without tactics is the slowest route to the victory. Tactics without strategy is the noise before defeat”.. So dont perceive as hard cons but still feel company needs strategy and one which is aligned from ground till top.

headline: Fast paced, great people, great product
pros: Fantastic coworkers, everyone is helpful and friendly. For a sales environment there is very little "back stabbing" or people being unfair to their colleagues.
cons: The company is growing very fast which leads to rapid changes in policy at times. Sometimes rules change before a written policy is released which can be frustrating.

headline: Great company, great culture
pros:
- Structured, thorough training that allows you to jump into your role with ease.
- Consistent support and check in's in your first months to make sure you are doing ok and keeping up with the pace.
- Great perks (dental, health, snack, monthly beer/pizza evenings).
- Intelligent employees who are helpful and push you to meet the standard that the company maintains. 
-The company is growing at a rapid rate, and there is opportunity to advance your career at a much rapid rate than at other companies.
cons: -As of yet, I have nothing negative to say about DS.

headline: Sales
