pros: CEO, Product Works,  good people and good clients
cons: disorganized, limited product set, client attrition, not a good customer success plan or strategy, hard to grow the relationships with clients,  very competitive market. compensation low, and no marketing.

headline: Great Place to work
pros: DocuSign has a great work culture and even in competitive settings people will still go out of their way to help you out.
cons: The pay could be a little better and it is starting to move away from the startup feeling.

headline: Dysfunctional management
pros: Great brand recognition; some great people in pockets; relatively stable company (size and revenue growth); potential to disrupt paper workflow
cons: Lack of clear vision; no clear decision-making; limited focus on career development; high level of bureacracy

headline: Startup turning midsize
pros: This is a great company to work for whether you are entry or senior level.  There is always something to improve, a new project to work on, or technology to experiment with.  Coworkers are fun and the office has a startup feel despite being several hundred people.  There is opportunity for travel as well, depending on your role.
cons: Company is going through midsize business growing pains at the moment.

headline: Product Management
pros: Very talented peers across disciplines
cons: Leadership lacks vision, there is not equal opportunity for both men and women. Leadership is fraught with politics and is draconian.

headline: Sales Intern
pros: great location, snack room, "start up" atmosphere, people are friendly. This is a great company to work for if you are breaking into software sales, lots of entry level opportunities
cons: lack of direction, strategy is not well defined, ability to move vertically is slightly hazy, besides sales there are very few ground floor opportunities to enter the company

headline: AVP
pros: Great technology and easy to use
cons: Fast pace environment requiring to learn on the job

headline: bittersweet
pros:
Great Pay 
Flexible hours 
Ton of resources - to help you be successful 
lots of vacation hours 
available travel 
A lot of growth opportunity
cons:
Work-life balance 
Stressful 
Difficult to take vacation 
no coverage if you're out of the office 
Lack of accountability on other teams 
Long hours towards end of quarter

headline: N/A
pros: Culture is fantastic, there are opportunities
cons: Usually look external for higher positions but are trying to change.

headline: Trust = Growth
pros:
As someone who has been a career Sales Engineer, I figured going to DocuSign would be a great experience due to the momentum of the product and the strength of their sales org.  I wasn't wrong on those assumptions, but that's not really why this has been such an amazing experience.  

The real deal is far simpler: this is a company that only hires people it believes in.  When you get started here, there isn't a lot of hand-holding in the on-boarding process, not because they're lacking the resources, but because they trust that you're going to ask questions, be a part of the team, and involve others in your work.  This is a company culture that is built around growing a happy customer base by first developing happy, successful, and confident employees.

What that means for SEs is that you're going to be handed responsibilities off the bat that will immediately take you to another level.  This is the kind of trust that is usually developed over months or even years of repetitive discos and demos at other companies (paying dues), but here they hire on trust, and then allow you to grow into a role that might initially be bigger than what you anticipated.  So if what you're looking for is something that can help you grow out of a role that is starting to become routine, and allow you to start tackling real problems that test your ingenuity and resourcefulness, and do it at a place that doesn't make you feel small or dirty when you speak with customers, then start reaching out to people here and learn more.  It's not a fit for everyone, but, if it is, it's going to feel right in a way that I've never felt before in my career, and that's a tremendous feeling.
cons:
There's not much to complain about with the job, I just wish we had 401k matching.  I've heard rumors it's in the works, possibly around the time or after we IPO, but there's nothing set in stone.  I also wish we had a gym stipend, but that might also come down the pike in the future.

I also hope we continue to partner up fast with emerging technologies.  I can't complain about this because we have a very well-documented API, but we should be top of the list for other emerging and growth companies when they think of integration partners, and sometimes we don't advertise enough and the end result requires revisions.  Be proactive, trust the channels, and this won't be a problem down the line.

headline: MDR - great team, leadership & culture
pros: From senior leadership down, they've set the bar for an incredible culture. As an MDR, you'll receive extensive sales and prospecting training, you'll be empowered to own your own book-of-business and you'll love the people you work with. Added plus that there's great growth and promotion opportunities.
cons: Some growing pains - but that comes with the territory for a tech company rapidly increasing headcount.

headline: Worst company culture
pros: The company offers private health cover and sales training.
cons: The environment is excluding and unwelcoming with a judgemental culture. There are numerous office bullies.

headline: Faced paced work environment with the most supportive peers and management team I have worked with.
pros:
- Product
- Employees
- Competitive Salaries
- Campus
- but most of all customers that love us and our technology
cons: We are growing so fast the workload can be overwhelming. Must be a self starter, self sufficient and have impeccable time management skills to survive. Growth is a good problem to have but it's easy to get burnt out.

headline: Great products, but management is aweful
pros:
Awesome product and definitely one of the market leaders for esign and document transaction management. Product integrates with many CRM and contract management solutions. 
Benefits are ok, but most positions paid below market average, especially in sales.
cons:
There are several, but need to mention that there is no leadership and no internal communication. You learn of news by accident. 
Employees and their work is only acknowledged if reporting into a certain organization. Many folks are very dedicated and put a lot of hours in, without ever being appreciated. 
The company works with unreliable data which makes sales reports useless.

headline: Awesome company making a true difference in the world
pros: Great company with a great mission -- to get rid of paper and help people get to agreements faster. The company is doing very well and growing fast. Very good benefits and lots of perks. Colleagues are great, very smart and engaged people. Docusign foundation also gives back 1% of company's profits / equity to the community. Great place to work - I highly recommend it.
cons: Usual challenges for fast growth companies - lots of change, sometimes clarity is lacking.

headline: Intern Experience
pros: Really great environment and fun people. Good Sales experience.
cons: Program could have more structure. More opportunities to do things outside of sales.

headline: 5 Star Company!
pros: Friendly work environment, great benefits, clear opportunity for career advancement and very approachable and helpful management. The comprehensive, hands-on training had me ready to go in less than 2 weeks!
cons: No matching 401k plan, but other than that no complaints!

headline: Senior Software Engineer
pros: Highly collaborative and fun environment
cons: Product management does not have a clear vision

headline: Senior Developer
pros: Energy, expanding business, good direction, challenging projects, some cool technologies, lots of areas to make a contribution, evolving APIs, solid back-end components, great coworkers, different approaches to projects, mostly Microsoft stack, some pretty neat side benefits like 2-3 lunches per week, snacks, drinks, kegs, occasional group outings
cons: Trust in the team sometimes vanishes when the stakes and risks elevate.  Pay raises are abysmal or just don't exist.  The company has been pre-IPO for what seems like an eternity, you'll tire telling your friends.  I sometimes hear more inter-departmental feuding than I'd care for, feels unprofessional.

headline: DocuSign: my favorite company!
pros:
I work in the Sales Operations group in Seattle, WA and have experienced the growth from less than 100 employees to where we are now. The company has stayed true to its roots and core values. As an employee, there are always new challenges and opportunities to grow, work on new projects, meet new people, etc.

I've been in the software/technology industry for 30+ years, and DocuSign is my favorite company to be a part of and experience.
cons: As we have grown, processes and resources have not always kept up. The challenge as an employee is to help identify those needs and offer solutions. A side affect can be work and life getting out of balance.

headline: Great Company!
pros: Competitive Pay within industry, great leadership, flexible work/life balance, excellent benefits.
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Great Rewards for Hard Work
pros:
-Provide ample guidance to new hires through extensive training and one-on-one mentorship.
-Great benefits and company culture, especially with an emphasis on work-life balance.
-Plenty of opportunities for professional growth as the company itself is growing.
-Open communication is actively encouraged.
cons:
-No 401(k) matching.
-As was mentioned previously, the company's going through growing pains. A lot of internal processes are still being defined as teams scale to meet market demand. Working hard and learning to prioritize my work has helped me adapt.

headline: Marketing specialist
pros: DocuSign respects its docufamily members and goes to great lengths to ensure that the people that make it up are happy, challenged, and balanced.
cons: While new opportunities to challenge yourself while increasing skills and knowledge are easily accessible at DocuSign, progressing in title and salary is a slow process.

headline: Sales Intern
pros: This internship not only provides you with an immense amount of foundational sales knowledge, through initial on-boarding and continual training, but it also gives you a chance to contribute meaningful work. The projects we worked on mirrored what the actual sales team was doing and we were able to see actual monetary contribution to the company by the end of the program. While there was structure, after a task was given there was autonomy to figure out and work on the task in our own manner. The full time employees were also very helpful and welcoming. The recruiters in charge of the program also do an above and beyond job of setting up fun activities inside and outside of the office and are very easy to communicate with about the intern roles. DocuSign also provided opportunities to meet with C level executives within the company to gain more insight about all parts of the organization.
cons: Because DocuSign is still a growing company you have to be comfortable with a somewhat shifting program, shifting roles, and sometimes being the first to ever attempt to tackle a task.

headline: Heavy workload - Weak compensation package
pros: Super fun people.  Kitchen stocked with free food.  Nice office space and amenities.  Great holiday parties.  Get to work with a lot of big name companies.
cons: Most processes are a mess...nothing seemed to be streamlined.  Constant change with little or no notice.  Very high expectations with little assistance from Management.  Pay is considerably less than comparable companies/positions.  Zero flexibility to work from home and actually require you to be in the office at 7am even if you cover an East Coast territory.

headline: Fantastic
pros:
Docusign has the benefits of top tech companies as well as the benefits of a smaller companies.

There is the challenging and stimulating nature of the work that comes with a strong technical company. There is also very good compensation, with high base salary, all medical/dental/vision premiums paid, 4 weeks vacation, RSUs, free stocked kitchens, and more.

But why work for Docusign over one of the larger tech giants like Google or Facebook? The answer is that Docusign is still a young company. There's room for much more impact on the growth of the company. There's more freedom, and quite simply a fantastic work-life balance that seems to have escaped tech giants.
cons: Docusigns future is not necessarily as stable, considering how there is currently no CEO, and there is a desire to go public. The company could be bought out and changed, which can be scary to some. However, since most of the current investors seem to be quite reputable companies like Google and Apple, I would argue that Docusign is still quite a safe bet.

headline: Sales Manager
pros: Very disruptive business techology with smart people and good environment
cons: be global is difficult when you have to change local culture

headline: Great oppurtunity
pros:
Fast growing company and leader in its field.
Great people.
Work life balance.
Opportunity for advancement 
Global Workforce
cons:
Growing Pains can get in the way.
Dynamic environment is  difficult to get used to.
Complicated organizational structure can be difficult to navigate.
Not all benefits and company Culture can filter down to the branch offices

headline: First 30 days @ DS
pros: Incredibly bright and driven organization with a clear sense of purpose. The energy is infectious!
cons: Typical of many companies, lots of fire drills and too many opportunities to chase with too few people to achieve them.

headline: Liking it so far
pros: Product gets catered lunches twice a week. Constantly learning new things. Coworkers are always willing to help. Very excited for the company's future.
cons: For the sake of our sanity, HipChat needs to be replaced with Slack..there should be no reason why we can't do this. Jabber is also not the answer.

headline: An innovative, engaging company with very talented engineers
pros:
DocuSign provides very innovative products that improve business and personal transactions substantially by enabling electronic signatures and providing a vast assortment of associated electronic document management options. The growth of the company provides a delightful array of technical challenges and opportunities, allowing engineers to grow in many directions and remain versatile and leverage multiple stacks (.NET, Node.js, etc.) in interesting combinations.

The company is poised for a great deal of continued growth and employs a number of very intelligent engineers, making it a delight to work here as a software engineer. The benefits offered to employees are also quite substantial.
cons:
While DocuSign is growing quickly, it is also working through normal growing pains, including how to organize and manage teams and priorities. There is also a tendency within the Engineering organization to form cliques amongst employees that worked together in other large companies; while not an outright problem, it does complicate making clear evaluations of software / technology as they apply to DocuSign, rather than the company at which that clique previously worked (e.g. "we tried this at X and it didn't work out so well, so we will avoid that here.").

There are also limited opportunities for advancement as the company is still growing and has not yet established a clear track for career growth. Additionally, compensation - while the overall package is quite substantial - is lower in terms of raw salary than others. These issues are not uncommon for a growing company, but are still present.

headline: "Anonymous"
pros: The Business is growing fast and it is exciting to be part of the change.
cons: Communication can be improved between teams and different offices.

headline: Impressive Technology AND Company
pros: I'm impressed with their onboarding and training processes -- very thorough and gets you ramped up quickly.  I'm also hugely impressed with the technology, the company's philanthropic efforts, and the enthusiasm and caliber of their employees.  Super excited to be a part of this great company.
cons: I am not yet seeing any cons.

headline: Over a year in and still great
pros:
- Location of San Francisco office is central to several types of public transportation = commute options
- New floors are well laid out and functional
- My immediate team has been growing/developing rapidly, yet still maintaining a good balance between professionalism and fun
- Company path, minus some bumps in the road, seems to be realistic and well thought out
- Product is solid and the engineering/development teams seem to be focusing on worthwhile features/updates (see recent "best API" award)
- Work and life balance is actually great - we work hard, but I'm encouraged to take vacation, and rarely have to work overtime (only during certain downtimes or projects)
- Opportunities to grow and switch groups are very real - several people in the past year have either moved on within the team, or to other teams, and it was handled as a good/positive thing (versus my last company which actively worked to prevent promotions/team moves)
- Snacks, drinks, and monthly happy hours are nice
- Benefits are solid, and continue to get better - medical, dental, vision, commuting, 401k, etc. (my last company was scaling back benefits, so it's nice to have them added on)
- The list goes on!
cons:
- Growth pains are very real
- Redundant teams or internal products and resolving them across departments (doable, just have some active friction, which is to be expected)
- Addressing global support issues/requirements while in production (goes back to growth pains)
- Conference room squatters! You know who you are (seriously, check the calendar)
- I know I'm biased, but not much else from my perspective - I feel like we have a great product and a very real chance to dominate in the future as this market grows

headline: Solutions Engineer
pros:
- Decent Pay
- Pre IPO benefits
- Offices offer nice snacks/break room on each floor
- Casual work environment
cons:
- No Matching 401k yet
- Most positions are required to be in office most day regardless of need

headline: Fun Place To Work, Great Product
pros:
- Love my team, we have a lot of fun while at the same time pushing each other to succeed
- Product is great, and people on the phones tell us so every day
- Management is very transparent and accessible for questions/concerns. 
- We often have conference calls with our Directors and VP's to voice any and all questions about processes and what's in store for us in the future.
cons:
- Better commuter benefits? More Happy Hours? 
- Haven't seen any cons so far more critical than the above.

headline: Was a good company to work for, not so much anymore
pros: The product is good and the companies attempt to give back to the community is nice to see. Good place for young college grads to learn and then take their skills on to a higher paying roles.  You'll see lots of glowing reviews from those recent college grads, mostly in sales roles as this is a sales driven company.
cons:
I'll keep my comments here specific to the accounting dept where I worked for 8 years.  

The company was great to grow with however that ended a few years ago with a change in management. Any advancement means moving to San Francisco, there is no opportunities for career growth in Seattle office, it is viewed as a "shared services" group now. The Chief of Accounting has a very cold demeanor and makes employees feel unappreciated. Work/Life balance was not good due to years of under staffing in depts except sales.

headline: Growing Extremely Fast!
pros: A fast growing company with young and motivated talent.  This allows for new ideas, collaboration and innovation. New experienced leadership has come on board to help take the company public.  The company is in such a great spot that it makes it extremely excited to work here every day.
cons: growing so fast that processes and structure is lacking.

headline: Great place to work!
pros:
I work with fantastic people - responsive, responsible and always amazing.
Management is great - they listen to your needs and respond to them with the appropriate amount of urgency.
My  job feels like it is important and treated with respect.
Great snacks!
cons: I would like to see more opportunities to work virtually or see a more flexible schedule.

headline: Very good company with talented and friendly co-workers
pros: DocuSign has the industry leading product and treats it employees very well in all facets.  Good compensation and good benefits (4 weeks of vacation right from the beginning).  DocuSign also has a good work life balance environment.
cons: No significant cons, except wish the 401k has company matching, but no big deal.

headline: MDR
pros: great place to work, friendly people
cons: Changing goals, really works well for competitive natured people

headline: Great place to work
pros:
- Surrounded by happy and motivated individuals
- Management is very well organized and wants to see you succeed
- Great workplace environment with the ability to have a life outside of the office
- Great office location and facilities
cons:
- Growing pains to start with getting the proper equipment and technology on time 
- Not currently offering 401 k match.

headline: Great place to work and have fun
pros: Great product, great company, and most importantly - Great People
cons: Needs to go IPO already

headline: Great Company
pros:
-Smart and motivated people. This created a great environment.
-Improvement is always on the radar for the company
-There was a culture of letting you do your work and solve problems in the best way for you
-They were serious in caring about employees having a good work/life balance
cons:
-The bureaucracy could make things slow
-Related, as the company has grown I think there is more of a struggle to stay flexible and agile

headline: Customer Success Architect
pros: One of the most important companies in the SaaS space.  The product saves time, money, natural resources, and reduces risk in almost any workflow.  The people are dynamic, motivated, and sharp.  Glad to be here.
cons: No handholding.  Be ready to go, and ready to figure out where and how you can make the most impact.

headline: Amazing company!
pros: Just started and thoroughly impressed - great culture, high caliber people, and huge upside potential. The company is growing quickly and there is a lot of excitement all around. Looking forward to an incredible career journey with DocuSign!
cons: Growing pains typical of a late stage pre-ipo startup. Not for the faint of heart. Things are moving quickly - adaptability and flexibility are necessary for survival.

headline: Talented colleagues + Challenging work = A Great Place
pros:
Smart people that I can learn from and enjoy hanging out with.
Great product that customers love.
Get to build new things and have a real impact on the company.
cons:
Not all new product ideas pan out, so that can be discouraging.
Not enough customer contact in engineering on some projects.

headline: Exciting Future!
pros:
First and foremost, DocuSign's work life balance is hard to beat. Flexibility in working schedules allows employees to accommodate their outside-of-work needs accordingly and remain productive and focused. This is all based on trust relationships between employees and supervisors, and those who were not able to accommodate to this culture and value set have been managed out of the company.
Work is usually very interesting and challenging, I have never felt bored with the tasks at hand and there is always a ton of work in many other areas waiting for somebody to take on, in case you ever feel in need of a change. 
DocuSign also supports employee's mobility in order to retain good talent and foster employees growth. I have witnessed many people moving between offices, roles and teams without much of an issue.
There is also a wealth of opportunities to bond and interact with your team and people in other roles by participating in many of the social activities being organized throughout the year, including Friday Happy Hours, team off-sites, picnics, sporting events, etc.
Overall, DocuSign is a great place to work.
cons:
It is very well known that DocuSign's compensation is lower than other companies in the area of the same size and maturity leve, but for many of us a good work/life balance kind of evens it out. Also, although DocuSign offers a good amount of PTO and 100% paid premiums in health coverage for employees, the company is falling behind in other benefits like 401K matching, reasonably priced health premiums for family members and their parental leave is very sub par compared to the rest of the companies in the Bay Area.
Finally, our hiring processes are all over the place and range very widely between teams, so we are in desperate need of more standardized and purified processes.

headline: Commercial Account Manager
pros:
Great team and love working with customers
Management listens to needs of the org and make adjustments
Quarterly Team Meetings to update any changes and review stats
cons: Variable Compensation is somewhat fixed

headline: Great Company
pros: It is a great sales role if you are coming right out of college. Great product and great people you get to work with every day.
cons: The pay is not as competitive as other companies in the Seattle area for this role.

headline: Great company but growing pains show
pros:
-Hard working team
-Great product
-Fun office spaces
-Good management/leadership transparency
-Many career/promotion opportunities within the company
cons:
-Compensation tends to be under market
-Organization is top heavy (too many directors and VPs, many with no direct reports)
-Restrictive Travel Policy
-Growing pains are quite evident, many processes are still in place for a smaller company and do not scale well.

headline: Excellent Company, Exciting Product - Just keeps getting better
pros:
Fun, challenging, exciting culture filled with people who raise the level of play in taking on this new market. Employees are passionate about the product and the impact it has on users' lives. Work with single users to Enterprises - everyone is a potential customer. Leadership is approachable and shares strategy and direction - also very open to ideas and improvements. Employees genuinely enjoy hanging out together - in and out of the office. Market leader. People truly love our product - have people share their "DocuStories" all the time when you share where you work and what you do. 

Lots of opportunity for career progression and career growth.
cons:
Fast growing doesn't mean there aren't any speedbumps - but for the most part, I've found it to be a rather smooth ride considering how much we've grown (have been with company as it grew from ~400 to over 2,000.) The challenge of the speedbumps can be part of the fun. 

As for sales - we're often dealing with status quo - can be a little harder to sell into, but that changes monthly as we only continue to grow and get recognition.

headline: Team focused, empowering to employees
pros:
I've worked for a lot of companies, but DocuSign is the first place that I've felt like they actually WANT people to stay here for a long time. They aren't trying to burn you out and then toss you aside like many tech startups. There is a proven track-record of promoting from within, investing in employees (For example - just started a masters level leadership program through the University of Washington as a free benefit to leaders within the company).
Leadership is thoughtful, caring, and respectful of their employees and truly committed to seeing them succeed, and not only succeed, but be happy and fulfilled. 
The pay is fair and they do what they can to add perks throughout the quarter, but they're not throwing money into stupid things like bean bags and razor scooters just to make it seem like this is a cool place to work. It's just a good place to work and people want to come and give their best.
Plus, it's a pre-IPO company that is poised to have a great public launch.
cons: There is getting to be a bit more corporate feel (more levels of approval to get a deal done). Comes with the territory as a company gets bigger and more successful, but it does slow things down a bit.

headline: Mid-Level Manager
pros:
DocuSign's greatest asset is its product. I think most of us that work here agree that we're proud to work for a company who produces such a powerful, easy to use tool.

People here are fun and friendly. Lots of food. Good office locations and nice working environment.
cons: As mentioned in  other reviews, DocuSign's internal processes are in dire need of improvement. Although "process" comes up a lot in the hallway in frustration laced conversations but upper management is taking no action to improve them. This inaction is evidence of either a general apathy on management's part, ignorance regarding how nimble companies manage process, or a lack of executive leadership which should be clearing barriers to enable sales and administrative execution opposed to spinning around in an attempt to get through internal processes.

headline: Just getting started
pros:
- Amazing market opportunity.  eSignatures are inevitable.  This is the future of signing documents, coming to agreement, etc
- Strong market lead.  Solving eSignature problems around the world - legality, compliance, local cultural preference etc - is not easy.  We are making the investments to stay ahead of the smaller players
- Experienced management team.  Our leaders have created and run successful public companies before.  No first-timers here.
cons:
- Commoditization.  We are working day and night to avoid being perceived as a Feature (versus being a Platform / Product).  So far we are doing a great job
- Competition.  The market is hot, so competition is fierce (and growing).  That's largely a positive, but we need to continue selling value to fend off the low-end market pressure we get from vendors giving away low-value eSignature offerings at low prices.  This is a solve-able problem.  
- Change.  Growing a company at this pace, with this type of unique product offering (Consumer, Enterprise, Global, etc), is tricky.  Getting the right people in at the right time is a very nuanced exercise.  We have had leadership changes - positive ones - but they still take time to process and adjust to.  The current leadership team is settling in and doing a great job.

headline: Anonymous
pros:
Great company to work for, great atmosphere and benefits!
The Business is growing and it is exciting to be part of the change.
cons: Communication can be improved between Teams and different offices

headline: Innovative and Exciting Company with tons of potential
pros:
- The people working here are very talented, and really good at what they do. Everyone possesses the right type of energy, and is excited about coming to work. 
- Stable company with a revenue-flow. This company definitely feels young and exciting (characteristics you would apply to start-ups) but actually has a good product that has a huge customer base. DocuSign is industry leading and setting the standard in the E-Signature world.
- Electronic desks that can move up and down. Awesome all-around for your health and alertness
- Location of the office. Whether you are in Seattle, or SF, the location is pretty hard to beat. And the View in SF of the bay bridge is just breath-taking.
cons: - Not sure why the company is cheap on the food catering. Lunch is only catered twice a week for the Product team. Why not every day, like other big reputable companies?

headline: Rockin place to work!
pros: Docusign is the best company I have ever worked for. The people have passion for their work which fosters a sense of teamwork. I feel inspired by those around me. As an individual contributor, I feel like management has got my back and is looking out for me. Great benefits. Good product. High morale. Lots of fun. Etc.
cons: Sometimes there are not enough bagels on bagel Friday. Seriously though, I don't have any complaints.

headline: Almost my dream job
pros:
Leadership team is top notch.
Creative and collaborative work environment.
Great work spaces to suit your mood/needs.
My colleagues are talented, fun, and hard-working.
cons:
Business processes are way too cumbersome and slow.
Can be difficult getting the tools and services I need to do my job.
HR can be a little too heavy handed.

headline: Sales Development Rep
pros: Training and on boarding program. Fully stocked kitchen. stock options. PTO and VTO. Exciting atmosphere. Great company moral. $2k referral program. Fun team events and outings.
cons: Teams are always changing from people getting promoted or leaving. Its such a young company, people that have been here 6 months are considered seasoned or vets.

headline: Good people, challenging work
pros:
Fun office environment with good people
A lot of smart people doing challenging work everyday
Fairly easy to switch teams if you find other work that is interesting to you
cons:
No 401k match.  There are a lot of management levels
Seems like various engineering teams are not driving in the same direction; sometimes competing priorities

headline: GOOD
pros: fast paced cool vibe allows for a fun atmosphere
cons: competition lacks integrity at times

headline: Great on-boarding & employee engagement
pros:
A seamless, collaborative and professional interview experience that is a reflection of the great culture here. The discussion and transparency around career paths at interview stage was very refreshing.

My first week on-boarding in Seattle was not just about on-boarding but also focussed on employee engagement, with the right balance of work and getting to know your colleagues.

Excited for both DocuSign's future and my future at DocuSign.
cons: None that I have experienced thus far

headline: A Huge Lie! Not a Serious Company
pros: Reasonable product that can have a good fit with the market, but it can be subject for legal validation in some regions.
cons: Extremely unstable environment, senior management and board behave like amateurs, zero business sustainability mindset, no respect for market professionals or commitment with those once they are hired, no respect for clients and internal marketing campaigns to send good reviews about the company.

headline: Great Opportunity to Impact a Company
pros: Talented people at a growing company.  Great opportunity to make a significant contribution that will impact the future of the company.  Added bonus that our product helps save the environment and simplifies business processes.
cons: Some internal frustration about future of company and pending IPO talk.  So much room to continue to grow, need additional resources to help focus.

headline: Continued opportunity
pros: This is a once in a career opportunity to work for a rapidly growing and evolving business.
cons: There is constant and rapid change, if you're coming from a big stable company be ready to have your hair put on fire.

headline: Youthful energetic company
pros: Efficient internal processes, smart people, good product.   Nice office, abundant free food.
cons: 401k, but no match.   Downtown location means that parking costs a lot of money.

headline: A great place to grow a career!
pros: I Love the product and the people, very smart and well focused with a strong commitment to the customer and to win in the esign category.  DS hires the best folks to fit the brand.  It's a great place to work, minimum drama, maximum snacks and a relaxed atmosphere. I feel apart of something that is getting bigger everyday. Professionalism without pretension. You're given every chance to not only succeed and make a ton of cash.  Managers/Directors very approachable, low ego and go to bat for you!! I really enjoy coming to work everyday.  My life has never been more balanced than at Docusign!!
cons:
Consistency with process getting from point A-B  definement/refinement is needed. 
Spend more time on-boarding within your team and promote more team bonding. We have a lot of successes to celebrate.

headline: Like riding a rollercoaster.
pros:
The leader of eSignature with strongest brand around and an exellent product that keeps getting better and better. 
A team of very good people with loads of enthusiasm constantly thinking how to make the company even better. 
Proven to be agile and flexible enough to go through massive changes and challenges and still keep the momentum.
cons:
An ever changing and ever growing environment is naturally a challenge. 
Entering Europe and the far east creates cultural differences that the company is coping with for the first time so being on the non American side of the company could be a for frustrating sometimes. 
A lot of rummers around IPO and leadership changes can disturb the need to keep focus on company's sucssus.

headline: Sales Development Representative
pros: I absolutely love working for DocuSign. We receive extensive formal training so that we can thrive in our positions, and the environment is extremely welcoming and positive. I could ask anyone in the office for help or guidance and I would receive it. The SDR position is full of people in their 20s, and are all friends outside of the office as well. The management is amazing and extremely encouraging.
cons: Tons of little details to the position- with our company growing so quickly, sometimes those in charge of training can't even keep up with the specifics. Nothing too detrimental though.

headline: Recruit process
pros: Professional and quick recruit process. The recruiter was direct and practical. The position was described well. The people are very social and make sure you have a smooth landing...
cons: The building in Tel Aviv is very Old. Hard to Park your car. No Car Leasing services. You have a 3 months probation period which you get partial social payments.

headline: Company with great potential
pros:
Fast growing company who sets global standard in its field 
Very dynamic working environment 
Great technology with a clear value to customers
cons:
Too many changes (people and processes), unstable working environment 
Complex processes, responsibility is spread into too many departments and sometimes can be very frustrating 
Too much focus on revenues and less on people

headline: 3 years in and still loving it
pros:
The product is amazing and the global opportunity is massive.  NPS scores of DocuSign rival Amazon and Apple..almost unheard of for a company who's main focus is Enterprise.
The people are smart, results driven but respectful.  Everyone is rowing in the same direction and the culture is one of collaboration vs sharp elbows.
We are growing aggressively (lots of opportunity to advance) and great to be the market leader.
We have upgraded the talent across the board from the earlier days and have some amazing leaders who can take us to a $1B plus company.
The CEO and the leaders genuinely care about the employees.
Work/life balance.  My experience here is that I have the flexibility I want as long as I deliver.  I think this is true across the company.  It is not a culture of "butt in seat" 14 hours a day. You can feel comfortable leaving early if you need to catch your child's play or sporting event and it's encouraged.
cons: Hyper growth is not easy.  We have offices in SF, SEA, Dublin, London, Tokyo, Sydney, Paris, Tel Aviv and Sao Paulo. Systems, process and training are all playing catch up to the growth of the company.  We have invested in the right tools and systems but need to implement globally to make it easier to do the actual work.

headline: Great place to work, continued growth and opportunity
pros: DocuSign is continuing to grow at a rapid pace. There are my opportunities for growth and strong leadership in place right now. Team culture is really strong and customers love the product.
cons: As with any hyper-growth company, we struggle with scaling our internal processes. Internal policies and procedures are often unclear.

headline: Sales Development Representative
pros: DocuSign has been an amazing company to work for. The SDR position is a great place to launch your career and have fun doing it. Company culture is always a big factor in choosing a job and they have created something special here. In fact, I am proud to say I have made life-long friends at Docusign. You will learn an incredible amount in this role.
cons: We recently moved buildings and the new view isn't as good as the old one.  I'll get over it though ;)

headline: Sales Development Representative
pros: DocuSign and the Sales Development Representative team is an awesome environment with an amazing opportunity to learn sales.  The culture is what makes going to work everyday so exciting.  This position opens the door to great opportunities within the company and the management team really sets you up for success.
cons: I can't think of anything negative to say about my experience with DocuSign.

headline: Working with DocuSign for 12 months - EMEA
pros:
Market leader in DTM space, strong customer base, Tier 1 partners (Microsoft / SAP / Salesforce etc), great ROI stories for customers, leading security in Cloud Services, the list goes on.

DocuSign are a great company to work for with a management team that lead by example.  The various teams - Sales / Professional Services / Solution Engineers / Marketing etc all work well together and deliver to the customers.

The company is growing fast, with new opportunities arising for both new and existing staff.

Fast paced environment, needs individuals that can think and act on their own.
cons: fast growth = growing pains

headline: So happy to have the opportunity to work for a #1 market leader
pros:
endless challenges we still have to maintain our leadership in the market
great people that although they come from different disciplines and geographies share the same goals
leadership is very much accessible
cons: as an employee of one of DocuSign's subsidiaries I can tell that the conditions in SF/Seattle are way better than the ones we have, although they are now better than what we had before we were acquired

headline: Excellent, but always room to improve.
pros:
DocuSign has been an excellent environment to work in, especially in an "entry level" position such as the SDR. The amount of time and energy invested into each individual during the onboarding process is a great indicator toward how the company values its employees.

The process is respected, and consistent, quality work is rewarded.
cons:
DocuSign is a great place to work and grow in your career, to be sure. At times, though, one looks around and tends to see the same types of people.

Diversity (or lack thereof) plagues the industry, and DocuSign seems to be no exception. The only prohibition I have against a 5 star review is the lack of workplace diversity.

headline: Great company, even better people
pros: There is a collective motivation felt throughout all the work here.  As we move from a start up to a strong and substantial company, the employees have the same hunger and excitement as day 1.  Leadership has a close ear to the ground in hopes to making sure their employees are happy and have the tools needed.  The culture is great.  Much like your typical "tech environment" with a creative work spaces, stocked kitchens and beers when needed, DocuSign has a refreshing mature feel to it unlike past tech companies i have worked for.  While the demographic is relatively young, for the large majority of employees have worked in tech for many years which leads to a stable and professional work environment.
cons: The only con revolves around your typical growing pains.  Setting up of new processes (software, requests, etc.) and getting used to them.

headline: SDR Position From a Fresh Perspective
pros: I am one of the newest members on the SDR team. From day 1, the SDR team and managers were welcoming and encouraging. The environment is fun, lively and always changing. As a young professional, DocuSign is the perfect place to boost your career. The SDR role allows for a variety of career paths upon promotion time. I would highly recommend this position to anyone who is hardworking, outgoing and wanting to grow with a fast paced tech company.
cons: Spending your entire workday calling customers is never anyone's idea of a dream job. However, the moments between the calls are what make the job fun.

headline: Best career decision I have made
pros:
I have learned more from this role and this company than I have in any other job. The leadership is amazing, and I learn something every day that I know I can take with me. Everyone seems to have each others back and you get a sense of family while working here. We spend 8-10 hours a day at work with our co workers, and I am happy to say I enjoy every minute of it. 

The amenities are amazing, great perks and excellent benefits.
cons: I wish the parking was a bit less but that is a building issue not a DocuSign issue.

headline: DocuSign is Awesome!
pros: Working at DocuSign has been an absolutely amazing experience. From legal team to the developers, everyone who works at DocuSign is both friendly and helpful. The company culture is relaxed, yet employees are self-motivated and hardworking. Most importantly for me, I've received a range of projects and regularly receive feedback on my work. Overall, working at DocuSign has been an extremely positive experience.
cons: Thus far my experience has been completely positive.

headline: Sales Development Representative
pros: Career opportunities, excellent leadership from the VP level on down, training, Salesforce experience, great product to sell, collaborative environment (not cut throat at all like you can see in other sales environments), outside-of-the-office team events,  recognition for achievements.
cons: While there are an enormous amount of free snacks available, there are no tortilla chips to go along with the guacamole ;)

headline: Market Development
pros: Thorough and comprehensive training prior to starting on your own. Culture is very motivating with a go-getter attitude. Team very close. Base + uncapped commissions is very enticing. Work hard, play hard. Lots of room to grow.
cons: Not a lot of cons! Early morning meetings that are required make it difficult for people who have previous obligations, i.e. taking kids to school, work outs, appointments, etc. They kind of set the work hours for you, which is not as flexible as other companies. Minimum # of calls/ day which isn't advertised as much when hiring.

headline: Fun
pros:
Awesome product, massive customer base, and great vision for the future & trying to go public. You can really feel the energy and there's an incredibly strategic way DocuSign is approaching the next two years with the impending tech bubble. We don't spend money on extravagant things, but have covered benefits, free snacks & lunch meat/sandwich food, happy hours each Friday, standing/moving desks, etc. It doesn't feel like we're missing out on some of the startup "perks" that seem frivolous when becoming profitable is SO much more important. Company focused on longevity (13+ years already!) and really digging into vertical markets. 

Sales is a great group of people, mostly referrals from other employees. Lots of ex- Salesforce & Oracle people looking for a change of pace but not too startup-like... SMB group is younger (mostly <30) and growing quickly, with excellent management.
cons: There is a bit of competition between the Sales team and the Website / Self Service team, which is kind of unheard of -- almost a bit of cannibalization competition internally. Just something to be aware of for the Sales team. Also, the team isn't nearly as drinking-heavy happy hour all the time as a lot of other companies, which honestly can be a good thing. Everyone works their 8-9 hours and goes home, really good work life balance and people keep it professional.

headline: One of the best!
pros: Great work environment, great people, great opportunities, great perks! Of all the companies I have worked for DocuSign is by far the best place. I wake up every morning thinking that I can hardly wait to get to the office to make a difference!
cons: We are growing so fast and expanding across the globe so quickly that there just isn't enough time in the day to get it all done.

headline: Working at a global SaaS Leader
pros:
DocuSign motto could be "We can only succeed as a team!". Here everyone is willing to help whenever you ask for ! 

Virtual teams are very common so you can work simultaneously with people from the US, Ireland, UK, Germany, Israel and partners from everywhere in your geography. That's truly inspiring! 

Furthermore you are stuffed with everything you need to succeed, and if it's not enough, you just have to ask and someone will a solution for you! 

Management has a real long term vision and shares it frequently with all the employees. 

Internally we say we are part of the DocuFamily and that's really how it feels!
cons: DocuSign is moving really fast on every aspect of the business so you have to keep focus on what is important or you may get lost in all the information, documentation and tools you are provided with.

headline: Vice President
pros: Fun to work at a company that has customers that love you ("You work at DocuSign? I LOVE DocuSign.  I started using DocuSign when...").  Clear industry leader with lots of product innovation.  Great group of people.  Executives have significant industry experience.
cons: Never enough time to do everything we need to do; there are just so many opportunities.

headline: DocuSign
pros:
Competitive pay. 
Excellent work culture. 
Knowledgeable staff.
cons: Since we're a growing company a lot of tools and resources are still in development. This is being worked on but difficult. It makes effective interdepartmental communication essential to success

headline: Perfect time to be here
pros:
- Excellent product and market leader.
- Hyper growth opening up lots of opportunities for progression.
- Very ambitious in its aspirations to be the best.
- Excellent leadership at both executive and local level. Everyone is approachable no matter what their position.
- Great culture and feeling of community. 
- You can really have an impact and success is recognised.
- Opportunity to travel to other offices in US and London.
cons:
- Collaboration between US and EMEA teams needs work to become more cohesive.
- Would like personal learning, fitness benefits.
- Some internal processes struggle to keep up with the pace of growth.

headline: Huge potential in Europe
pros:
- Huge investment in Europe building on US success
- Customers love us - have genuinely had a 'Docuhug' in a Costa
- Great culture and working with committed professionals 
- DocuSign Advisory Board - huge who's who list of influencers
cons: - Some key resource is still out of the US so time zone challenges although that's quickly changing

headline: Grat place to work
pros: The  "WHERE CAN I HELP YOU"  attitude that exists across anyone in the company. it's very real. I believe it's based on the fact that a big chunk of the compensation for everyone is based on exactly the same company wide KPIs. the company is very nimble and the goal is to support the incredible growth it's having. Lot of fun working at DocuSign. Salary is good enough and  total compensation has a big bet on a liquidity event.
cons: benefits could be better. some randomization around the tactics

headline: Worldwide leadership with broad market vision
pros: Being at DocuSign is a worldwide adventure with many challenging career opportunities in all fields. Top management is outstanding and charismatic with a clear and broad vision of the market target. Relationships are friendly, direct and transparent and everyone is acting in sync with the others to drive our worldwide business to escape velocity.
cons: The only disadvantages of working in such a great company are time shift and jetlag... So we really take care when it comes to schedule worldwide meetings.

headline: A solid company
pros: There is a lot of engineering talent at DocuSign.
cons: We have over a decade of cruft.

headline: Fast growing established SaaS company
pros:
I've been working at DocuSign just shy of a year and I can honestly say it's one of the better companies I've worked for. The culture around here is very collaborative with highly intelligent,  driven employees looking to make a difference in the SaaS world. Management allows you to take on more and make your impact on the company.

Whenever I tell people I work at DocuSign, I always get a positive response about the product and how it's made peoples lives so much easier.
cons: I wouldn't say this is DocuSign's fault but the company is definitely a well established company and lost a lot of the start-up feel.

headline: Great Product - Great Atmosphere - Great People
pros: DocuSign is a product to stand behind and the incredible people that work here continue to make it better and better. The atmosphere is amazing and the company invests in its people to drive success.
cons: Fast growth and changes often (which is also super exciting, but definitely has challenges).

headline: Great Start to Sales Development
pros:
great training program and company to learn how to sell tech
great snacks
cons:
growing pains 
management needs leadership training 
no performance reviews

headline: Great Fast Paced Environment
pros:
- things are always changing here! 
- great benefits
- supportive management
- fast paced, startup feel without the instability 
- great SF location
- always challenging and rewarding work, you know you're making a real difference here
- amazing product, saving money, time and the environment
cons:
- lower than average pay
- things are always changing (this is also a pro)
- still light on creating and establishing processes
- career trajectory not very clear for many roles

headline: Docusign is a great place to evolve
pros:
We always have opportunities  to evolve our skills. Always being motivated .
Awesome package, not much clarity (no HR) on how to set it up and which plans offer what..
As long as you meet the objectives set for you, you own and manage your work time. This flexibility brings out the best in those who are driven.
cons: Screening with HR, call with Director (30 mins each). The recruiter really harped on how much they researched and paid attention to the answers. She seemed interested in what I had to offer and I was passed on to the next round. The next call with a higher up was a bit of a mess - no showed at first, then rescheduled our 2nd time around and was late when…

headline: Simple Truth
pros:
People are nice and genuine
The team I work with and report to are smart, well-educated and have solid previous experience
The employees care about what they are doing and are passionate about the product/company
cons: Fast growth generates a lot of ambiguity in process and structure—in time this will work itself out as they continue to hire the right people for the right positions.

headline: SMB AE
pros: Energetic work environment.  People show up early and work hard.  The productivity is contagious and teams are very collaborative.  Additional pros include a beautiful office space with amazing views of San Francisco and an awesome kitchen with coffee, drinks, snacks.
cons: None that I can think of

headline: Sr. Account Executive
pros: We have a world class product that truly transforms the way companies do business.  Regardless of the business unit, DocuSign can streamline processes and drive operational efficiency.  Product aside, we have an amazing leadership team and awesome corporate culture.  Love this place
cons: None so far on my end, but in any growing company, the only constant is change.  This is a place where you need to be able to roll with the change that comes.  Its not a bad thing because change can be good.

headline: Account Executive
pros: The autonomy to run my accounts here is better than I've experienced anywhere else. I feel strong support by management in regards to in-territory travel, account help and deal support/sponsorship.
cons: The workload is heavy. Prioritization in your day is key. The space is highly competitive as well, you'll need to be able to clearly articulate value to close a sale.

headline: Sales
pros: As an AE, I feel I really own my book of business without micromanagement. I feel like I have options are far as my promotion path. The work ethic of my teammates, management, and beyond is collaborative and hard working. However, the hard work pays off in compensation and team building activities
cons: Not a ton of cons, but I feel sometimes I'm not well informed in decisions that will effect my compensation and promotion paths. However, management has an open door policy so I'm able to voice my opinion. Work/Life balance is there but not as great as my previous organizations.

headline: Sales
pros: Great culture in a fun office, awesome food and snacks available, and very talented co workers are some of the things that make this job so great.
cons: The quotas are high in sales(although that pretty normal for SaaS), and the internal IT team can be some what slow to get back to you.

headline: Work is truly pleasurable and meaningful!
pros:
Work-life balance
Employee contributions are valued and encouraged
Comfortable work space with everything you need to be successful
Genuinely passionate, smart and innovative people
cons: Changes and challenges with scaling - like with any rapidly growing company. Employees have to function with that understanding and conform to change easily. No 401k matching yet.

headline: MDR Role
pros: DocuSign is a great place to work! The culture is like a second family and the company really cares about you as an individual and your long-term success. Our benefits are fabulous and the opportunity here for growth professionally is huge! Overall an amazing place to work.
cons: No cons in my opinion.

headline: Best Company I've ever worked for
pros: Competitive wages, open door policy, management actually cares, everyone is happy and upbeat! You can actually talk to the senior management without getting buffered through your direct management first.
cons: No 401K match yet, no education reimbursement yet

headline: Best Company I've Ever Worked For!
pros: Leading edge products leading the way in global digital transformation.  Strong leadership, awesome CEO, fun and collaborative start-up culture, Exciting growth track primed for IPO.  It's a perfect moment to look at DocuSign!
cons: You have to embrace change, it's embedded in our culture.  We move fast and you have to wear many hats.  While exciting, it can prove challenging at times.

headline: Leader in their field
pros: Hyper growth, fast moving and changing the way business gets done.
cons: Growing hyper fast and can be a challenge to keep up to product, pricing, personnel changes

headline: "You work for DocuSign? I love what you guys do!"
pros: What powerful brand awareness and the best swag. It didn't take much prompting to make a move to DocuSign. Awesome company culture, great opportunities for whatever direction your career takes you and a very strong company outlook. I truly enjoy working at DocuSign!
cons: The company is hot! More words of caution. Keep up! Compensation could use some review to make sure we stay competitive in the marketplace.

headline: Administrative Assistant
pros:
Good work life balance
Competitive Pay 
Pre-IPO benefits
Growing company with numerous opportunities for career growth
Health and commuter benefits
cons:
Growing pains 
Hiring moving faster than scaling can happen
Right hand doesn't always match what the left hand is doing
Trickle down communication

headline: Product Manager
pros: This is by far the best place I have worked yet in my career. The culture is awesome and you really feel part of a team. Everyone is very willing to collaborate, work hard, and also have fun. I am challenged and appreciated every day. It is a fantastic place to be!
cons: We are growing so quickly and changing just as rapidly which can be a tough adjustment sometimes, but overall people get on board and we do move fast.

headline: Awesome Product - fast growing Company
pros: Great product, fast moving, fantastic market opportunity. Snacks are plentiful and offices are centrally located. Smart coworkers and decent work environment.
cons: No 401k match. As we are so fast moving, it is hard to stay ahead of the curve, which is constantly moving.

headline: Great place to work - recommended!
pros: Great working environment, Company is going places, lots of opportunity due to high growth, great people and good career options.  Positioned well to dominate the eSignature space.
cons: The commute is a bit long for me, but the company provides some benefits in this area.  Fast growth means employee programs are still catching up with employee needs

headline: Enterprise Account Executive
pros: The team is absolutely wonderful to work with and the product is second to none. DocuSign has a solution that is catered to any and all businesses and consumers and is the best in the industry.
cons: The products that we have are the best in the industry.  We need more products like this to sell.

headline: Building a better culture for a great product!
pros: I love being part of a company which goal is to change human behavior for the better. Over the last centuries, we have reached agreements using pen and paper. Now, we are at point in time, where we can do this in a secure digital format that allows us to save time and money.
cons: I think DocuSign is like a teenager and is still trying to figure out its identity as a company. Most of the problems I hear about and have experienced first hand are cultural ones. Some important changes are being made to improve this, however, I think there are still some more to come, before these cultural issues are resolved.

headline: A great place to work
pros: Smart people, great product, free food, lots of vacation
cons: Difficult to align on goals from time to time, no 401k match...

headline: Great company!
pros: Intelligent leadership who set challenging, yet attainable goals. Well-run organization overall, especially considering how quickly the company is growing. Good benefits. Clear promotion path for anyone willing to put in the work and effort.
cons: Would love to see a 401k match added to the benefit plan. A bit more transparency would be great as well.

headline: A Growing Company With a Startup Heart
pros: The people who work here really do care about their jobs, and the product / service they are building.  You get to work with super smart people who want to succeed.  The location off the office in downtown SF, and close to public transportation is a huge plus!
cons: Priorities can change from time to time, and for some people that is hard.  We are losing Keith Krach as our CEO and he will be very hard to replace.

headline: Right time Right place to be in
pros: Culture, dynamic environment, exciting growth
cons: Dependency on U.S. based resources

headline: Account Executive- Commercial Sales
pros: Great product, amazing co-workers and managers, they give us a lot of tools to get the job done, lots of room for advancement, you feel like they actually care about your career and want to see you do well, agile, still feels like a start-up, endless opportunity
cons: Lots of ambiguity, sales cycle takes a while because the technology is so new to people, sometimes it is hard to find an answer to an urgent customer question, lead flow can be a bit slow some months

headline: Sales Development Representative
pros:
- Great leadership and managers 
- A lot of continued sales training 
- Culture is super fun - you work with your friends!
cons: - Great entry level sales jobs but must be willing to put in the hours to succeed

headline: Silicon Valley's hidden gem
pros: Very dynamic and talented team. It has great drive and some amazing senior execs. In full pre-IPO mode, you're looking at enterprise quality in full startup mode. Very challenging and amazing place to work. A hidden gem indeed.
cons: Though some reorganization has occurred to clear up senior management, there is still room for improvement. Pre-IPO means some budgets are really tight.

headline: Great Onboarding and Smooth Sailing so far
pros:
* Company culture is good, and work ethics are top-notch
* Everyone seems open and very relaxed
* Excellent teams with good skills across the board
* Had the best onboarding into the company that I ever had
* Good office perks
cons: * Benefits package in EMEA is a bit disappointing

headline: great culture
pros: Fast paced, fun and collaborative culture.
cons: Still building structure and functions.

headline: Great company, great product, amazing people, awesome leadership
pros:
First for me is that I BELIEVE in what we do, which makes so much easier to go the extra mile - our product helps our customers transact anywhere, anytime, on any device, securely. It's transformational and we're saving them millions along the way. That's powerful.

We have amazing leadership. Extremely experienced people that are taking this company to new heights. 

The company is growing and there's a feeling of excitement - we're creating a category and racing to claim global leadership in the space. which also means there's a ton of growth ahead an an opportunity to grow with the company.

People here are smart and excited to come to work and crush it. which makes for a great environment. It's a very collaborative environment and I feel I can speak my mind and will be taken seriously.

Our product is both consumer facing and enterprise facing, so you get to learn both sides of this business, which is great. 

We're still private. That means some upside as well as more flexibility in how we go to market.
cons:
While we're still private, we're not really a "startup" anymore. The company is growing at a rapid pace and we just crossed the 2,000 employee mark. That means we have some pains as we look to bring structure without loosing nimbleness.
One area that needs to catch up with our growth is Development. I work in a pretty unique part of the company, so can only speak from my own experience, but I feel the company needs to do a better job at making the career path clear, and offer training to help people be ready for their next step in their career in the company.

headline: Great Place to work
pros:
Great environment and very smart people !! 
Everyone is willing to help and focused on company's goals !!
cons: Recruiting process a little too long and slow.

headline: Fast-growing VC-Backed Company
pros: I enjoy the ability to work with a team of highly talented individuals who take the success of the company in changing the world personally.  It's every person's mission to create automation and efficiency for our customers, with a clear definition of our success based on how much value our customers get from our products.
cons: Investor backed companies often times result in the company being very focused on growth and leadership who can take it there.  As a result, the finer details of personnel management isn't always of highest priority.  Once the investors exit, often times companies begin to mature into a cadence that focuses on making each team member successful, with more investments on personnel.  So long as folks accept we are in the early stages of such a cycle, they will enjoy working at DocuSign.

headline: At DocuSign we know that - “the little things matter”.
pros: DocuSign is an amazing company to work for, great product with huge further growth potential. The company has a strategic vision and growing its strategic partners globally. DocuSign recognize the value that diversity brings to its product, operations and people. DocuSign are very supportive of career goals and aspirations. We all work together and enjoy our team successes :>)
cons: DocuSign is a dynamic fast paced organization which may be less attractive to those who have worked in mature static cultural environments, however that been said for those who want to change working environment and up for a challenge DocuSign is ideal to revamp your career.

headline: Great place to work and grow
pros:
Great career move!

- Great onboarding
- Career opportunities
- Great management
- Constant improvement
- High potential market
- Great culture
cons: You just have to be able to deal with constant change because the company is growing really fast and constantly evolve.

headline: Sales development representative
pros:
Great onboarding and training (all employees are jet in Seattle HQ)
Fast growing environment
Many opportunities to learn and to grow
Good compensation and benefits
cons: I don't have cons for this company

headline: If You Don't Join Now, You'll Wish You Has Later
pros: The management at DocuSign actually listens to their team. Not only that, but managemenr at various levels (manager, director, VP) interact with the team regularly. They're open to our ideas, suggestions, and concerns. Our teammates are an amazing group of people. Each person adds their own flavor and we each care deeply about the success of one another. Yes, you are in charge of your own quota, but everyone wants to see you get there too. The company has invested SIGNIFICANTLY into our growth as sellers. As someone near the very beginning of my career, being invested in ways other than monetary (believe me, that happens too) was hugely important. I wanted to be taught good habits early, so 10 years down the line I don't have to spend time fixing bad habits. DocuSign was the best decision I made for that. I'm mentored by individuals in house and hired 3rd parties. My account executive helps me to learn, besides management, and in conjunction with my peers. I'm learning 'sales' from a number of angles, styles, and personalities and I couldn't be happier.
cons: Our team is exploding. That's a great thing! But it also can make it hard on new members because it can be challenging to understand where and who your resources are. The 'veterans' help as much as possible, but many of us have only been around 6-9 months longer than the new hires so we also have a lot we're still learning. The company is exploding - also a great thing! People are moving up quickly and often! But, with that growth, our company and team have to adjust to help keep this big ship movin' in the right direction and sometimes that adjustment is challenging initially.

headline: Nice Place to Work
pros: It's a great company that is currently gaining a huge market share in a short period of time, people here help each other in order to achieve company and personal goals, which creates a nice place to work.
cons: High experienced people are most targeted for spots in the company. Few positions are filled with medium and low experienced people.

headline: Just shy of two years - my perspective
pros:
Amazing main office location and work environment in San Francisco
Great social and art team
Lots of partners and integration with the product
Developer marketing and evangelizing of APIs is strong
Good reputation and established customer base
cons:
Blindsides happen - if things aren't going well for you (even though you may think they are) be warned, there is no formal process for termination or performance plan to turn things around.  I received an exit note in my email one day without warning with no recourse or reason in writing.
Slowing down - new security review processes have been put in place to reduce risk over the past year - most without prior warning.  The problem is that simple things like a simple read-only partner integration between cloud apps has to go through a multi-part and prolonged process to be approved and implemented.  If you like to move fast and get things done quickly in the environment anticipate long wait times and due process.
One dimensional - The product is focused on e-signature and the workflow associated with it.  While the best in the industry, the challenge is that since its not a multi-product company or platform you will be doing your work around the signing event.  
Product innovation slow - Since I was hired nearly two years ago the product was being transitioned to the "new experience".  Nearly two years later the product is still in transition and a lot of core things still need to be done on aged classic platform.
Budget cuts - the road to profitability has led to a lot more scrutiny of budgets and sometimes employee perks.
Leadership stagnant - leadership showing its age for a pre-ipo company

headline: Unbelievable Company
pros: This company is amazing full of great perks.  The product is fantastic, and is the best that's out there by a mile.  Have an extensive training program to get everyone up and running and feeling comfortable.  It's an honor to be a part of DocuSign
cons: It's fast growing, so there are some pains with that. Going from 300 people a couple years ago to just a shade under 2000 will do that; however, this growth is necessary, so it's exciting.

headline: Software Engineer
pros: There are many good things about DocuSign like a full stocked kitchen, great parties for christmas etc.
cons: Manager was very passive aggressive. They are a very top heavy company with too much management and people with poor social skills are put into management positions. They are growing so fast and not compensating at a rate that is accepted in Silicon Valley, so a lot of the talent that they are hiring isn't really qualified for the roles they are putting them into.

headline: Smart and fun
pros: Lots of smart talented people, communication is clear and company goals are talked about often. Exec staff is mature, culture is dynamic and fun
cons: The exec staff could really use some diversity

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Full of really smart people who care about the success of the company
Fun work atmosphere
Respects work-life balance
Owns a growing market, with lots more upward potential - very bright future
cons:
Lots of meetings
Dev team should be bigger

headline: Amazing opportunity to launch your sales career at a growing company
pros:
Lots of energy. The team works very hard, but knows how to have fun.
Very transparent path for promotion. Top reps can earn their way to the next role as fast as 9-12 months.
Training is impressive right off the bat, with loads of resources and one-on-one coaching throughout your tenure.
Exciting time to join the company - it's growing, still pre-IPO, and continues to be recognized as the standard in the industry.
cons: No cons. This job isn't for everyone, but anyone can be successful here if they are coachable, willing to put in the hard work, and ask for help when needed.

headline: Marketing
pros: Talented had working people across the board
cons: Going through a change, becoming more conservative on spend to prepare for being a public company.

headline: MDR
pros: There is an incredible amount of support amongst colleagues on the team. Knowledge is shared daily, and you learn a lot from your peers. Management also works hard to provide campaigns for the team to supplement your own prospecting efforts.
cons:
You only learn from your peers and personal experience. Management does very little to provide training and development. The xDR teams are growing so fast that it extinguishes the culture that once was. Rapid growth looks great from the top, but really hurts morale when you're down at the bottom fighting to hit your monthly goals in a shrinking territory.

Additionally, there are incredibly successful email sales tools out there for teams like this, yet they don't exist at DocuSign. At least one person complained about the email tool every day for six months. Nothing changed, so we were forced to continue down a path ridden with resistance. What's funny is that almost every day, we heard from management suggestions on how to be more efficient.

headline: Account Manager
pros: Great product. Great team members. Many happy customers that are very invested in the success of the implementation.
cons: Product group disconnected with customers. Account Managers manage too many accounts. Senior management is so focused on growth that they do not realize a storm is brewing.

headline: Exciting Hyper Growth
pros:
There are lots of opportunities to take on responsibility, get involved in other areas or become the SME in something new. 
Everyone is super-approachable. 
There is a great atmosphere in the office. 
Local leadership are excellent. 
People are recognized for success. 
There are great benefits (pension, life insurance, health and dental, free snacks, drinks on Fridays, bonuses for referring friends etc). 
Generous holidays!
cons: Growing fast brings its own problems and uncertainties globally and locally, especially in this climate for startups, but there is a strong management team which will take the company to the next level. There are also a lot of Chiefs!

headline: DocuSign Engineering Rocks!!
pros:
DocuSign is leader and pioneer in digital transaction management (DTM) space. Working for a engineering team that is leading and creating a new market segment is humbling....

Awesome product and projects, very impactful work, great coworkers, good work-life balance, free lunchs, snacks, drinks, every Friday - bagels/donut, dinner, drinks, music (happy hour).

As an engineer you are working on industry leading technology (proven and loved) and work with brilliant talent.
cons: Growing pains - DocuSign is growing rapidly and need more resources…

headline: Love working for DocuSign Engineering
pros: Great culture, smart co-workers, challenging problems, great perks like free lunches, breakfast, mini-kitchens, snacks, drinks, fun happy hour.
cons: Salaries could be higher. RSU grants could be better for pre-ipo startup.

headline: Had to weigh in - Enterprise sales at DocuSign is a nightmare
pros: About half of the senior leadership team is good. The actual product and technical side of the house is amazing. Not afraid to spend money to achieve their goals.
cons: I usually do not bother writing reviews, but after reading the two (fake?) reviews raving about the great opportunity in Enterprise Sales, I had to weigh in. Stay away! Incompetent management, cronyism and sub-par compensation. This team is struggling.

headline: Fantastic place to work
pros:
fantastic product and company to work for. There is a clear direction about where they want to be and I've no doubt they will get there.
Great environment to work in, everyone works hard but this is a relaxed and open atmosphere at the same time.
cons: fast growing company, so will be a challenge to keep the small company feel

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: Good atmosphere, nice environment, lots of people helping you, really good benefits and many career opportunities.
cons: No cons so far... I'm quite happy with my adventure at DocuSign

headline: Lacking Engineering Innovation
