pros: Very good work/life balance. Market leader. Financial outlook is good. If cons of the sort described below don't bother you, you can have a very successful, stable, stress-free 9-5 job.
cons:
Management (in San Francisco at least) has a systemic inability to recognize and correct bad decisions. It seems like they spend most of their time in meetings making excuses so they don't have to take a perceived political hit for making a bad choice, instead of owning it and doing something better.

This influence from the top has made its way into individual hiring decisions, where hiring managers make excuses for candidates and look down on anyone who gives negative interview feedback. This has created an engineering culture where people either blindly do what they're told and code exactly to spec (even if it's the wrong thing for customers and the company), or get frozen out, badmouthed, and belittled for speaking their minds and raising valid concerns.

Add to this a total lack of technical mentorship or career growth opportunities, and I guess what I'm saying is that it's definitely not an engineering-driven culture.

headline: The Futures Bright
pros: Dynamic, fast paced, fast growing and fun place to work.
cons: Growth strategy can leave some employees overlooked.

headline: Good first corporate job
pros: The people are great! Lots of great social events to network.
cons: Management picks favorites. Hiring so many new people makes it a lot more competitive and harder to succeed.

headline: Account Executive
pros: Many opportinties for promotion and a very yung enviorment.
cons: The company is growing to fast

headline: Docusign is growing but still immature in many ways
pros: The company is growing and there is a lot of excitement around an eventual IPO. They have snacks that are decent and started offering lunches a couple days a week. Can't beat the location.
cons: The management and processes at Docusign are behind the industry standard. The managers appear to make hiring decisions on a whim, technical interviews are haphazard, and the middle management spends most of their day on politics and don't even know how to code. Also, although most tech companies lack diversity, Docusign hasn't released numbers because they are probably much worse than most--I have yet to see a woman speak at an all hands, for example. At the holiday party this year, they chose to have dancers in see through lace lingerie and thongs--how is this supposed to help women feel more included as equals in tech roles at this company?

headline: Good place to work, room for improvement
pros:
- My work-life balance is very good here, probably better than any other tech company I've worked at in the Bay Area. 
- I have been given the opportunity to move around within the engineering organization when I've asked to do so, even to roles in which I had little prior experience. I have found DocuSign to be very willing to invest in my growth and success; the company seems to really see it as investing in its own success, which is rare and refreshing. 
- I get to work on and help build software that facilitates commerce, and positively impacts the lives of many people. This is a big deal to me personally; there are plenty of companies looking to make a quick buck by building trivial, derivative garbage and then getting acquired; Docusign is not one of those companies in my view. 
- When I tell people where I work, the reaction is almost always positive toward the product. I take pride in that.
cons:
- From where I sit, it is a very top-heavy organization. There are executives who were added in the last 2-3 years whose actual roles and contributions I couldn't even hazard a guess at. Their titles seem to be a handful of important-sounding business words randomly thrown together, and I presume their actual contributions to be of similar depth and necessity. 
- I still feel that DocuSign is more a sales-focused organization than an engineering-focused one. Some may not see this as a negative, but I certainly do.
- The anticipated IPO was used as a carrot to entice potential employees as long as three and a half years ago, and still is not imminent, AFAIK. Lots of pre-IPO companies do this, especially in tech, but that doesn't make it any less distasteful. Additionally, there is a fair amount of secrecy and even duplicity around it, which I find to be both unnecessary and counterproductive.

headline: DocuSign - Right time, right place
pros: I love coming to work!   People have a sense of humor, sense of responsibility and work collaboratively.  Passion about what we do is evidenced at every level.
cons: Scaling processes to meet growth can be challenging.  Some processes are time consuming and cumbersome.  Bonus plan in place for certain levels.

headline: First week at docusign as sales development rep
pros:
Eveybody is awesome and have great stories behind them.
Docusign do everything they can to help you move over to dublin.
The recruitment process is great and hr are really looking to get to know you. They follow up regularly.
Inside Docusign, a lot of great perks (food, drinks, events...)
The management is awesome. They tell you where to go but let you choose your path.
cons: The reference checking process is heavy and can be annoying (lot of documents to send, lot of people to ask for references and on their side a lot of time spent filling the reference form).

headline: Great place to grow career!
pros:
I have had a blast since joining Docusign nearly 2 years ago.  Being part of the Enterprise sales team, I have seen the significant growth in the business and it is fun to be a part of something that is seeing so much success!

The company allows a lot of opportunity for upward growth for the people who work hard and go above and beyond what is expected of them.  Docusign is a great place to grow your career!  I have learned more in my 2 years at Docusign than I have in my past 10 years of work experience.
cons: Can't think of anything negative about my experience at Docusign thus far.

headline: First Class Market Development Team
pros: The leadership team is unmatched! As a current rep on the team, I trust the expertise and intentions my leaders. Quotas are challenging, but not impossible. Environment is high energy and collaborative. Resources and tools provided to succeed are the best in the market. As a shareholder of the company- I fully believe in this team! DocuSign's rapid growth owes a lot to the leaders and rep of the Market Development Team
cons: This team is the fastest growing team in the company. Growing pains will happen, and sustainability and adaptation will be key.

headline: Enterprise Sales - Now is the time!
pros:
Great time to be an Enterprise Account Exec!   Multiple reps over two commas and deal size is increasing annually.   Some massively exciting transactions took place this past year.  

New leadership from the last few years has brought proven discipline and process and the overall deal support is better than anywhere I've been.  Talent exists in every department and they are all eager to help.   

The market is maturing  to the point where enterprise wide deployments are becoming the norm.  F500 is increasingly aware of our impact and we are quickly becoming a "must-have".  Chief Digital Officers starting to pop up everywhere.   

Still very early innings.  Huge upside for the right Enterprise Execs.  If you've done your homework and know your territory, you will be successful.
cons: Not a con but an observation.....DocuSign is a rocket ship.  Not many companies have our YoY growth the last 5 to 10 years.   Expect turbulence.  In fact, embrace it.    Stay focused and prioritize your time wisely.   Adaptability and focus are fundamental to any sales job...perhaps a bit more here than others.

headline: Enterprise Sales is Exploding!!
pros: 7 out of 10 reps who were on full quota beat their number.  Top reps are making over $1M.  Average sales price has more than doubled.  Sales leadership is very experienced and is executing on a playbook that has a strong track record for success.  80% YoY growth after 10 years in business is pretty amazing.  The culture is very supportive and positive.  The ROI is insane.  By far the best place I have ever worked!
cons: There is a lot of change with a company that is growing this fast.  This is not a negative, but it does require adaptability and focus.  There is so much opportunity to chase, so you have to really learn how focus on a few key accounts and manage your time appropriately.

headline: DocuSign brings the DocuLove!
pros: DocuSign has one of the best work cultures I have ever been apart of! Everyone works together to help one another be successful.  More than being successful is the opportunity to hone and refine your skills as well as continued career development growth. DocuSign is a company to be proud to work for and talks the talk and walks the walk. Great product and company to stand behind that truly is changing the game!
cons: As we grow there are a lot of new hires, new policies and things of that nature which are great in the long run, small pain for the brief moment. Nothing really to complain about!

headline: Fast moving team with GREAT people!
pros: Great team! Company has an awesome culture and good values. MDR role sets your up for  career grow within the company. Team is fast moving but also really fun. Leadership team is great and super supportive. I wake up excited to come to work everyday!
cons: Team is growing so quickly hard for everyone to adjust, but even with everything moving so quickly the team is still great!

headline: I love DocuSign!
pros: Besides being one of the most disruptive products on the market, making it easy to sell, DocuSign is also the best place to work.  The management team has an open door policy, the training is top notch, and there is tons of upward mobility. I love working here and cant wait to see where my journey with DocuSign takes me.
cons: We are growing rapidly... DocuSign is doing their best to keep the amazing culture we have here the same...but with any company, the larger you become, the harder it is to keep that culture.

headline: The BEST choice I ever made
pros:
I’ve been at DocuSign for over 1.5 years now, and couldn’t be happier with this opportunity. I started as an intern in their sales program, and have worked my way up to this current MDR position. 

The atmosphere at DocuSign is very fun and motivating. People not only care about the company and job that they have, but they also share a lot of compassion for one another. I literally wake up excited to come to work every day… As an MDR, I am able to continue to build my foundation of sales skills, join an encouraging team, grow as a leader, and have a variety of promotional paths available. The MDR management is also SUPER supportive, and helpful with ensuring that you are successful and happy within your role.
cons: With such a successful and fast-growing company, one can occasionally feel overwhelmed. This is also part of what I find to be exciting and inspiring about DocuSign, but I just need to make sure I am proactive about asking for help or meeting with managers.

headline: DocuSign - An amazing place to work!
pros:
DocuSign is fantastic place to work with passionate people, excellent benefits and a fabulous atmosphere. The company is expanding extremely quickly and it's literally the ideal place for anyone with ambition, and a hard working attitude. 
If you're prepared to work hard, I can't recommend the DocuSign enough.
cons: If I'm 100%, I wouldn't say there are many downsides to the office but if I were to choose one, I'd say some processes are still a work in progress. This isn't a lack of effort on the company's behalf, it's literally expanding too fast for the processes to catch up.

headline: SDR-Nowhere to go but up
pros: First off, the environment is incredible. Regardless of who you talk with, you can tell that the people here genuinely care about you. Management is awesome and it makes work exciting to be at day in and day out.
cons: I haven't noticed any real cons. We are growing so fast things keep on changing so everything is moving at a pretty fast pace. Being able to hit the ground running will help a lot.

headline: Thinking abount Enterprise Sales at DocuSign? Think Again!
pros: Interesting technology. Offices are beautiful.  Cafeteria is filled with free, healthy snacks.  There is even a Coffee Room where you can create your own free custom coffee drinks. People are mostly friendly and competent.
cons: Where is the IPO?  Unreasonable, unattainable quotas have sent many good reps and managers packing.  Bottom line:  Enjoy the free coffee and snacks because unless you are one of the very few, that is all you'll be able to afford while working at DocuSign.

headline: Enterprise Account Execs - you DON'T want to work at DocuSign
pros: The product is good and continuing to improve.
cons: Enterprise management is a messy snake pit of politics and incompetence.  Less than 5% of enterprise reps are at or over quota in any given year of the last 5.  The compensation plan is the worst in the industry, both in structure (incomprehensible) and earnings.  It has continued to decline each and every year.  DocuSign has had to raise base salaries to $150k and at-plan to $300k + non-recoverable draw for 6 months and 15k-20k stock options just to get anyone to work here during the past year after the previous mass quittings.  As you can see by the replies of DocuSign to every slightly critical review on this site, DocuSign cares more about arguing with people than fixing their own problems.  This is a churn-and-burn shop.  Work-life balance is nonexistent for any rep who gets past 50% of their quota, and in 2015, that was fewer than 1/4 of all reps.  Run, run, run to you next interview...DocuSign's executives are.  DocuSign has lost their CEO, founder, and Chief Legal officer in just the past few months.  The much-advertised IPO is further away than ever with our executives and sales managers (3 gone in 2015) leaving this sinking ship.  DocuSign enterprise sales resumes are flooding the market right now.

headline: Just joined the ride...
pros: Great team. great products and wonderful future ahead of us...
cons: Sometimes the company seems to be growing too fast, creating some confusion and shifts of responsibilities.

headline: Thoughts from a new MDR
pros: After working at DocuSign for just over a month, it is clear that the market development team is a great place to start your career within the organization. The team, full of high-energy, motivated, and helpful co-workers, is growing rapidly and the role provides a tangible, and high-visibility, way to impact the company. As a whole, DocuSign has a great training/onboarding program and seems truly committed to ensuring the success of their new hires. On the practical side, DocuSign offers great benefits and a fair compensation package for the role. Pros: peers, team mentality, growth opportunities, ability to function autonomously, leadership.
cons: The MDR team is growing so quickly, leadership is still figuring out how to get all the new hires assimilated and up to speed. They have taken great strides towards creating more structure both within the team and the training program, but those who are not willing to advocate for themselves when they need help may find this challenging.

headline: Unicorn of the decade
pros:
I have been at the company a little over 5 months and my personal development continues on a daily basis.

- Management is phenomenal - they truly care about your personal development and provide the tools for you to develop your own success.
- Your input counts! Changes are implemented quickly, effectively, and most importantly in a positive environment.
- Exposure to decision makers, processes, and different verticals (healthcare, tech, etc.)
- Learning is done with peers rather than data bases full of information.
cons: - Processes change frequently and you must be adaptable to change

headline: Finally, progress. New CFO rocks!!!
pros: Still feeling the burn... rate. But a lot more optimistic that reality is making a comeback to DocuSign. Nothing personal, but you can't have a 10:1 deadwood ratio among execs without killing the tree.
cons: Much dysfunction and deadwood remains. You can trim 2/3 of the execs, especially the "tired old legacies" without anyone noticing or drop in revenues. Go back and read Lean Startup.

headline: Couldn't be more excited to be along for the ride
pros: Docusign is one of the most promising and exciting tech companies in the northwest, It is full of opportunities for advancement, management that is dedicated to your success, constantly new initiatives and plenty of perks
cons: As the company grows and evolves, policy must change along with it, as long you are open to growing and changing though you won't have any problems keeping up.

headline: Sales Development Representative
pros: The SDR pits are always so full of life. I love being a part of such a fantastic atmosphere where I look forward to seeing my coworkers every day. The culture is absolutely incredible filled with young individuals who like to have fun, but also know when to buckle down and work extremely hard. So happy to be part of such a great company as it is growing so quickly.
cons: Only con would be slight growing pains. With the company expanding so rapidly things are constantly changing. But the constant change is exciting because of the direction the company is going.

headline: What is design?
pros: Lets see....cafe on the 8th floor offers a wide selection of coffee and snacks for free. The office also provides some beautiful views of the Bay.
cons: Not a design centric company at all. Speed is always valued over quality, which is ultimately at the cost of the user. I got out of there as soon as I realized what was going on!

headline: SDR
pros: DocuSign is an incredible company to work for.  I could not be happier here and could say endless good things about this company.  The best part of working at DocuSign is the culture and the people.  There is a work-hard play-hard mentality, and the energy here is contagious.  The people are kind and fun, and also hardworking and incredibly motivated.  DocuSign provides a very good work/life balance and gives you more vacation time than any other company I have heard of.  The hours are somewhat flexible and they make it easy to do whatever you need to do outside of work while maintaining a full time, demanding, career.  You cannot go wrong with working at a company like DocuSign!
cons: Only con would be that since it is a newer company, things are constantly getting modified and changed.  This is a good thing, but only if you are adaptable to change.

headline: Sales Development Representative
pros: I have been working as a Sales Development Representative for over a year. Management is great, sales training is top notch. I have grown tremendously since I first started working here, and plan to be here for a long time. There is still a lot of room to grow within the organization to grow, and learn. All around, employees are treated great. The Break room has great snacks, and beverages ranging from tea to many types of juices and Sodas. DocuSign has a great product and is a leader in the market. Its an exciting place to be.
cons: Growing as quick as it has, there are changes that come along and you have to be adaptable.

headline: Sales Development Representative (SDR)
pros: The SDR role is definitely the best place to start your sales career.  I moved from the east coast all the way to Seattle, WA just to work for this company and my experience here has been nothing short of amazing. Everyone is always willing to extend a helping hand and you are constantly rewarded for your success & accomplishments. I am beyond proud to be apart of this DocuSign family.
cons: I do not have any negatives to talk about working here at DocuSign. Sales in general will always have its ups and downs but it is important to stay positive in order to be successful.

headline: Awesome Company and Culture
pros: Overall DocuSign is an amazing company. I was at Amazon before this and the environment here actually makes me passionate about coming to work every day. Management is insanely receptive and helpful. Work is challenging yet very rewarding. There are happy hours, superb benefits, rewards for blowing your quota out (i.e. dinner at Daniels Broiler) etc. etc. Also all of my coworkers are great. It is very hard to think of anything negative about this job.
cons:
-With high growth/expansion there is a lot of hiring and this may create fewer opportunities in the future for promotion
-Pay could be a little bit more competiive

headline: Sales Development Representative
pros:
Honestly everything about this company and role is phenomenal. Hence the the title, it is a sales role but don't let that scare anybody looking to jump into a role at a tech company that is absolutely on top. on top of the market and on top of tech "start ups". Sales Development is a great introductory role to selling and to DocuSign. Start as an SDR and you can go anywhere in the company, and yes, it is a sales role, but selling for this company is unlike any sales role out there as the product and technology basically sells itself.

Aside from the work being fun, the company culture is that of a mature startup. Its full of energy, games, beers, and employees who are very smart and into the tech industry. I would HIGHLY recommend this role and this company to anyone who is reading this review.
cons: I have been with the company for about 9 months and honestly ask anybody who works at DocuSign and they will tell you there are no cons to consider when looking at this SDR role or the company as a whole.

headline: Best Company I Can Ever Imagine
pros:
Incredible work environment with happy, friendly, and smart people. People are at DocuSign for the long-haul, and everyone here knows that we are at the beginning of something very special. Because of that, building long-lasting relationships with incredible people is easy and happens fast. 

Beyond that, the company hires smart, motivated, big-thinkers, so processes are constantly improving and results growing. The VPs are accessible for feedback and coaching, and they make changes as a result of that feedback. The infrastructure for growth is in place and now we all get to experience the rocket ship taking off. 

Lastly, the product is changing the world. A lot of companies claim that their product is a gamechanger, but DocuSign is truly changing a process that hasn't evolved more than a ballpoint pen for over a millennium. As part of sales, I love how easy and translatable the value proposition is to everyone with whom you speak. Whether you are explaining the company to one of your grandparents or speaking with a C-suite prospect, everyone knows that the world is only becoming more digital, and DocuSign is the way most people will get there.
cons: If only the Seattle office had avocados in the breakroom like the SF office does, this company would be perfect. Guacamole every day!

headline: Time to jump onboard!!
pros: New leadership is pathing the way to new growth heights! More sales (internal) support, better marketing initiatives, more events. etc. If you are a sales person looking to blow out your number, my advice is to jump onboard now!
cons: Some pieces of operations are still ramping up to support the growth pace.

headline: Unbelievable company and Fantastic Product!! DocuSign EMEA.
pros: Experienced management team running the show in EMEA that are dedicated to the company s and employees success, combined with a team of peers that are super friendly, motivated and dedicated.  Fantastic product to sell that really helps companies and touches ever industry. Perks and training are excellent, the opportunity that is in front of this company is extremely exciting. Super happy to be along for the ride.
cons: This is not a con for me but others may think different. DocuSign is a hyper growth company and growing at this speed is not for everyone, be prepared to roll up our sleeves if you are lucky enough to be offered a position.

headline: Sign anything
pros: Startup feel, up and coming excitement
cons: Alot of change very quickly

headline: Fun environment, but growth needed
pros: Great colleagues, awesome modern offices, exciting times at a growing global company.
cons: Needs to strengthen management and personal development opportunities. Growing pains from moving from a small to medium-sized company, needs to embrace more process + transparency to succeed.

headline: Making an impact and building something incredible in Dublin!
pros:
* Fast growing company with a bright future
* Career progression - structured career plan in place
* Fun environment with like minded ambitious people
* Management open to ideas and creativity
* Product that I believe in
cons: * We need more great people to join the DocuSign adventure

headline: Good Contract
pros: Fun team to work with
cons: Lots of turnover, hard to get an understanding on process

headline: Happy Camper!
pros: Great Product that almost sells itself! Fast-paced environment, where you get a lot of input to shape the company. Great team who are really kind and helpful. Great place for career acceleration.
cons: Because the company is growing so fast, you need to be the type of person who is comfortable with change and ambiguity. This is not for everyone!

headline: 5 stars
pros:
Great people to work with. Nice mix of talented experienced people who will take some time out of their day to help you out. Requires a drive to be a self-starter, don't just look and point out bottlenecks. Have the balls to fix them yourself. Find your responsibilities within the bigger picture and own them, no matter how junior you are. The company provides the tools to succeed, go out yourself to make it happen. Failing is allowed, not trying is frowned upon of course. 

Amazing platform. Great future prospects. Good benefits.
cons:
Can be a bit chaotic, with a rapid expanding office and ever increasing responsibilities.

Not very well known in continental Europe, a general awareness campaign would be helpful. mostly from a legal stand-point.   

No relocation package offered. (at this point of expansion is expected though)

headline: Docusign - Growing fast and feeling the growing pains
pros: Docusign is a fast growing company, and they will very likely become a multi-national powerhouse despite all the problems engineering has. They have a good work life balance. Even this late in the companies growth cycle, stock options are likely to be fairly valuable.
cons:
Despite the pros, DocuSign is a terrible place to work, with  very little management involvement until something goes wrong. Parts of engineering are allowed to be abusive and offensive simply because they deliver quality work, and 'brogrammers' are everywhere. Office politics is present, and there is a very real 'old boys network' in place. If you want to succeed, you better hitch your boat to one of the established cliques, and be very careful how you tread. Upper management is sometimes completely clueless about what is actually going on at an operational level. (Or perhaps they have a little of the 'Steve Jobs reality distortion field' in effect, it can be hard to tell the difference)

Ultimately, stay away from Docusign, because your career there will be like a trip through a mine field: You wont know if you made a misstep until its too late.

headline: Starting a career in Sales
pros:
I am convinced that in the Sales Development Rep role in Docusign, I am getting far more responsibility and exposure than I would be receiving in another company for the same role.

Typically, the scope of this role is tightly defined and restricted, giving limited exposure and learning opportunities. In Docusign however, I am regularly dealing with companies and stakeholders of all sizes, and given a real opportunity to learn and carve out my own role in the organisation

Everyone has been so supportive, and happy to share their knowledge, allowing me to better understand how each role ties into the other roles in the organisation, and how I can contribute.

So far I have been receiving direct recognition for the work I have been doing, and people are genuinely interested in our development

So far I've been flown out to Seattle twice and also brought over to London - this demonstrates the company's commitment to getting everyone involved in the culture and development of the organisation 

Every other day we have different members of the larger executive team passing by the Dublin office to share their wisdom and get to know the new people joining the organisation. It's a great opportunity to rub shoulders with the VPs and C-level staff, which is very rare for most global companies
cons:
The sweets and chocolate are too tempting - I'm getting fat : (
All the free beer on Friday isn't helping with that either

headline: Brilliant future-oriented company with great people
pros:
If you love to build something up - countries, markets, new business - you'll really love it here.
It's quickly moving, you can/have to be flexible, creative and pro-active, very customer centered, a solution finder and business enabler (for your customer). 
With freedom comes responsibility.
cons: For people with the character settings mentioned above - none.

headline: Big aspirations...lack luster execution
pros: Easily the best product I've sold with some of the brightest people making it happen from a product perspective. Some decent perks and not a ton of red tape you see at other larger organizations. Still pre-IPO and equity is still pretty generous.
cons: Pay and benefits aren't competitive. Almost zero process followed by lack of communication across different departments make it feel the right hand has no idea what the left hand is doing. The sales organization is cut-throat..you either produce or you're gone. And don't expect anyone to help you as there is a lack of good training and mentoring. And the company direction is misguided as all the money goes to sales instead of infrastructure and support. Product isn't able to keep up demand as a result of very little investment to create new SKUs.

headline: Employee, Dublin
pros:
- Product: life changing product that streamlines everyone's workflow in everu business
- People: Genuine leaders with great experience, great peers who are full of energy and ideas
- Personal Touch: constant contact throughout recruitment process with updates and important information
- Vision: Clear vision and mission shared constantly so employees know what direction the comapny is going in.
cons: It can be difficult to explain the company to prospects and candidates outside the US. It is not as widely known nor as trusted and that can be a challenge. It is improving everyday!

headline: Unlimited Opportunities
pros: DocuSign has experienced phenomenal growth and has unlimited opportunities to advance your career. You'll be working with exceptionally smart, creative people who love what the do.
cons: The rapid growth means there's lots of change and ambiguity - but if you like a challenge you'll find the environment invigorating.

headline: Corporate Marketing Intern
pros: Very smart, humble people. Flexible hours, no face time.
cons: Internships can last for more than a a year sometimes

headline: Sales Development Intern
pros:
-Super fun environment
-Great pay, mentors, and colleagues 
-Awesome internship IF YOURE INTO SALES
cons:
-Cold calling
-For an intern, at times there was nothing for us to do.

headline: Horrible company
pros: Are not worth it. Great view and snacks I guess, and initial salary at first.
cons: They hire you, then change their mind on where they are going, and boom you are without a job. High politics here, don't go. They don't grow with the people, even when they are smart and over achieve on what is wanted.

headline: Why Wouldn't You Work Here
pros:
Employees are open, friendly, approachable, even across departments
Free snacks
Fantastic Work Environment 
Product is solid
cons: High turnover, which sometimes causes disorganization

headline: Great technology avoid enterprise sales
pros: Spent a few years at DocuSign and it is a great technology.  There are some great people in the organization who are very talented. The technical team is very strong.
cons: Way too top heavy and turn over is very high for a company with this much promise.  They haven't been able to crack the enterprise sales model which has resulted in a revolving door of enterprise sales leadership and go to market approaches.  Only a few reps make their number and everyone else is sucking wind.  Product, while really good, has not evolved too much.  A lot of the best people have left already.

headline: Intern
pros: Everyone is very excited about the company and product. Fun to be a part of!
cons: A bit bureaucratic a times so it can be hard to get things done.

headline: Way to grwo your professional dream
pros: Free and open environment to excel in your current position or move to another group. Freedom is the key at DocuSign.
cons: becoming more like government type and not startup anymore...from teen to maturity

headline: Huge Market Opportunity and Great Company To Work For
pros: It is in an elite group of companies where people really love the product--which is super rewarding if you work here.  The company is solving a problem that makes people's lives easier.  Culture is fun, yet professional.  Business and technical problems are extremely interesting and intellectually challenging.
cons: The company is growing exceptionally fast, and processes and priorities change rapidly to accommodate that growth.

headline: Account Executive
pros: Great people and culture. Everyone has a works hard and play hard attitude. Commission structure is competitive nice you get into kickers.
cons: Base salary is low. Commission are paid quarterly rather than monthly. Expected to work 10 or more hours at the end of each quarter.

headline: Concern
pros: Marketing machine has done well but is running out of gas.
cons: Company has never made a profit - a startup who missed their chance and the technology has become available from other vendors everywhere.  Meantime top-heavy executives have multi-million expense accounts while employees barely make a marketable wage. Uncomfortable internal sexual relationship by executive with employee continues to exist as marriages and friendships were ruined.

headline: Growing Fast!
pros:
This is a company with huge opportunity in the marketplace and exponential growth.  There's plenty of opportunity to take on new roles and grow your skills as the company scales and has a larger global footprint. Hang on for the ride!

Other - great office location, amenities and good people
cons: The enormous opportunities without adequate resources results in lack of clear direction.  The politics and constant pivoting to maximize the few people who are available to execute can be frustrating at times.  This is all part of growing pains and the balance of keeping our numbers looking good for an IPO and hopefully will be sorted out in the next year.

headline: Fantastic place to work
pros: I love working at DocuSign - the company has been growing fast and there's always new and interesting engineering projects!     The technical team is filled with exceptionally smart people who are scaling a high volume system really quickly - it's just never boring.   From what I've seen, people who are passionate about tech, no BS and love to ship do great here...those big talker, time waster types don't last long.
cons: Sometimes a few too many projects happening at once, but i think that's pretty normal for a fast growing company...

headline: A promising product, but incompetent, top-heavy leadership and office politics ruin it
pros: Smart people on the ground. A nice view from the office. Reasonably good life balance for some. A decent stop along the way if you're not looking for career growth.
cons:
I would not recommend DocuSign for anyone not already friendly with the leadership (Director or above), unless you are ready to play some very cutthroat office politics to get into that position. Delivering value for the company and making awesome contributions are straight up not valued (or, often, even noticed) here. The company currently has far too many Director. C-level and VP employees soaking up all the credit and rewards, but either contributing very little or (in many cases) negative value to the company. You will be fed some line about loading up the top of the company so it can be built downwards, but none of that has happened in the last 2+ years. The people on the ground actually creating value are kept down (with below-market compensation and benefits) so friends can be brought in to reap the rewards at the top.

If you can navigate a treacherous political landscape to get yourself into the buddy circle, or are there already, Docusign is great. But if you want to do actual work and be valued for it, look somewhere else. If you do decide to come in (the business outlook would stay positive for the near future regardless of what the leadership does due to the market position and lack of serious competition), make sure at least 50% of your time and effort is spent playing politics. Any time spent on other work will be wasted otherwise.

headline: Automation Tests are really valued
pros: Get place to work, my contribution is really valued.
cons: Large workload can sometimes lead to conflicting priorities.

headline: Great Company to work for
pros: Great people to work with. Challenging role.
cons: None at present. Hire more folks

headline: Great Product; Culture Needs Work
pros: The product is super compelling in how it improves efficiency inside companies and with their customers.
cons: The company is very top heavy and appears to be overinvesting in its C-level structure.  Oddly, Keith Krach seems unable to fire executives.  He merely moves them into new C-level spots that they appear to create on a whim.  This has shifted the culture in a negative direction, and it now feels more big-company.  That was not what I wanted when I joined, and made it easy to leave for another company this year.

headline: Good experience
pros:
- Company is growing so quickly, that there are tons of career opportunities.
- Positive work environment.
- Great work environment/offices/facilities.
cons:
- Company is growing quickly, and is experiencing growing pains. 
- Unless you're in a management position, forget having any sort of serious influence in the company. They make the decisions, and any advice coming from lower level employees isn't really taken into account.

headline: Great Growing Company
pros:
Many Pros.
Great culture, values.
Good benefits.
Challenging work.
Great people.
cons:
Poor communication between different locations. 
Lack of middle management level employees.
Weak sales enablement internationally

headline: Hold on Tight...
pros:
DocuSign is a company that is changing the way people work. Many tech companies define themselves as disruptive, but few are. DocuSign is one of the few.

Change is a constant. Self motivation, focus and responsibility are rewarded, but to be clear, success here will be determined by an individual's ability to make success happen for themselves. 

Though DocuSign as a whole is moving towards becoming a large organisation, the EMEA and APAC markets represent huge opportunities for those who want to take ownership of their role and build a business.

The commitment to social impact programmes, allowing team members to engage in charitable work on company time is very welcome.
cons:
It's a bumpy ride. Any fast-growing company experiences pain, and as the company develops, employees may not have the support structures they're used to or feel that they need. It really is a question of sink or swim.

This isn't the place for individuals needing close management or supervision.

The work life balance can suffer occasionally, but this is par for the course in any organisation that is defining and building a market.

headline: Unrealistic Quotas
pros: Great product and the leader in the market.
cons: Expect not to make quota.  DocuSign pays under market value for sales roles and unless you get that one big "whale" of a sale every year, you will be living mostly off of your base salary.  Account Executives are stressed out, tanking their careers for Execs to make all the money.

headline: Growth is Strong
pros: Growth is strong, the market presents great opportunities to expand. There is focus in many of the right places in terms of how we extend our products globally. Teams have positive attitudes and peers are collaborative.
cons: Leadership is far too VP, SVP, and C-title heavy. Certain leaders have unrealistic expectations of their teams and provide little context for their asks, while other leaders seem to be just a long for the ride. Sales is far over staffed while other departments are struggling to keep up.

headline: Hyper growth, but company needs to improve internally
pros: Great view of the city in the Seattle and San Francisco offices, lots of snacks, and smart coworkers
cons: It's disappointing that a company that is growing so fast, super successful, and hiring every day does not promote from within. Many full time employees have been here for a few years and have yet to be promoted. Other contractors who work hard and would like to become a full time employee are not offered the position or opportunity because of a "lack of budget" in their particular department.

headline: If you're in Sales, look elsewhere for opportunity....
pros: Great product, without a doubt, and some really great people to work with and learn from.  Perfect location in Downtown Seattle, steps from the market, SAM and other city highlights.
cons:
So many to list, but I'll stick to the ones that are most relevant to Salespeople, I have many friends and acquaintances in the field and would not recommend DocuSign to any of them because:

Base salaries are comically low and non-negotiable, if you are a good sales person with a solid track record you will be taking a pay cut of seriously undervaluing your skills.

Quotas are (seemingly) made-up and not based on either actual market projects or past performance.  They are also exceedingly unrealistic in most departments but also wildly inconsistent, in terms of ability to exceed quota and resources available, from team to team. Don't bet on making up your lost salary with commissions, it's highly unlikely at DocuSign.

Management/Leadership: Lots of managers, very few quality leaders or managers that even display competent leadership qualities.  

Sr. Leaderships: Keith Krach is an inspirational guy and, from what I've seen, has done great things for the company, he will likely continue to do so as the business grows globally.  Beneath him are a multitude of C-level exec's, SVP's and VP's, many of whom have dubious roles and are, seemingly, redundant.  They are weighing down the company and creating a bureaucratic mess.

headline: Mixed Bag
pros: They are the leader in space. They use amazing technology, and have some great people to work with. The opportunities to learn and grow are definitely present. This company is on the up swing.
cons: The culture is a sham unfortunately. Bagels and beer, but it only goes that deep. A few good managers / senior staff cant compensate for the lack of consideration and compassion displayed to the employees.

headline: Exciting times!
pros: DocuSign is a great organisation to work at.  We have an incredibly strong leadership team, are experiencing incredible growth and the opportunities for progression are fantastic for the right people.  It is very exciting being part of the company as it becomes a truly global organisation.
cons: DocuSign's pace of growth can mean that internal processes and supporting resources become stretched.  This isn't the place to work if you need formal structures and bureaucracy!

headline: Great Company
pros: Lots of room for growth, constant encouragement from Account Executives
cons: Had to do too many cold calls

headline: The Future is so exciting -Loving the Docu-Journey
pros: You have a level of autonomy and empowerment that I haven't experienced before at other companies. The core cultural values of Customer Focus, Passion, Innovation, Integrity and Executional Excellence are alive and well - the current employees in Dublin and London operations certainly embrace these values. It's fast, fun and energetic -   a place where teamwork is valued and where everyone's input is listened to and considered. The company strives to hire the very best Talent in the market across all disciplines. Great to be working with the best brains in the market.
cons: Running fast is not for everyone - due to the hyper growth of the company, it's key to take a breath and celebrate successes.

headline: Great Place to work
pros: It's a good company to work.
cons: No have problems in this company.

headline: DocuSign
pros: Great culture, and amazing people that are willing to go out of their way to help.
cons: No cons to share at the moment

headline: Better for some than others
pros: It's a friendly, comfortable atmosphere to work in, and it's great to work for the industry leader and a company you can respect.  DocuSign is definitely going places.  Benefits are very good.
cons: Salary issues are ever-present.  Be aware that employees who stay with the company a while fall behind market rates because DocuSign is very poor about giving raises.  Rather than hearing another response such as "Thank you for sharing your thoughts," I'd like to hear a real commitment to change this and see results.  This is a big contributor to turnover, as is hiring from the outside instead of promoting qualified, proven employees.

headline: The best place that I could be working nowadays
pros: The company is determined to achieve your goal and all employees work together for this. The company and employees grow up together.
cons: Last year was intense growth. Some acquisitions need to be finalized, as well as some systems integrations.

headline: A good overall
pros:
A good place to meet new cultures,new ways to work, new thoughts.
It's also a good place to work (have good customer + good team mates and managers).
Everyone is accessible here, so if you need anyone help, you could get it easily.
cons: This is a company that is growing yet. So a few process still needs to be set.

headline: Head of Sales
pros: Company leader with fast increasing, great place to work and environment; big addressable market and good opportunities to growth; incredible investors and customers around the world; and to end, amazing products with best ROI for all executives and companies
cons: The cons points are the same time, opportunities: keep the company at the same page about knowledge, products, speech, model, system is our great challenge

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Nice work/ life balance. Everybody here is so talented and friendly. Great place to work.
cons: Working downtown. Taking the bus and or paying for parking is not fun. It would be nice to have a work from home option after being with the company for a set amount of time.

headline: A promising company to work
pros: A Big company in word and a promising company in Brazil.
cons: Restructuring continues to go growing.

headline: A company that is truly going places
pros:
Incredible growth trajectory: the year-over-year numbers are outstanding and there is still lots of room for growth. 
Market leadership and true differentiation.
Smart acquisitions and real business strategy.
The senior leadership is very experienced. Not their first rodeo, not making it up as they go along. There's a playbook.
Good culture. Work hard, play hard, lots of emphasis on fun. Strong values and integrity.
cons:
There are some entrenched ways of working that need to be fixed for the company to achieve its true potential -- lack of processes, silos, etc. Management is aware but some of these are complex problems that won't be fixed overnight.
And not a con but an observation: you need to be extremely comfortable with ambiguity and figuring things out on your own-- at all levels. Little hand-holding, minimal on-boarding. Have to do a lot with a little.

headline: Great place to work, bright future!
pros: The people and the energy are great, simple and compelling vision, amazing product that sells itself (who wouldn't use DocuSign???) and very bright future ahead.   The on-boarding experience was excellent, career opportunities abound, and global expansion happening fast.  THE place to be right now!
cons: Growing pains typical of mid-size companies that are expanding.

headline: The next Visa!
pros:
We are making the market - what's not to love about helping a company digitally transform
Awesome approachable senior management that know how to get a deal done. Twice Keith has picked up the phone to the CEO of one of my customers and moved the deal forward
Customer success number one metric
Market leading product - with benefits and savings that customers love.
Great culture with a mix between start up and enterprise
Tons of career development opportunity
cons:
Rate of growth and change is exceptional so if you don't enjoy this not the place for you.
Be prepared to muck in and do things outside of your role, again I like this but not for every one.

headline: Company with best features of a startup and an established company
pros: 12 years old but still maintains startup culture. Hiring a lot of smart people with senior leadership have incredible track record of experience. Almost unlimited opportunities for those willing to put the work in.
cons: Crazy growth and agility means it's easy to get pulled in different directions if you're not laser-focussed.

headline: Great to be part of this amazing fast paced company!
pros: Growing extremely fast, Incredibly talented people have joined our EMEA team in Dublin, every day you learn something new, you will never get bored! The culture and the willing to help attitude is what makes the difference! Perfect time to progress, learn and have fun at the same time.
cons: Some fast growing pains, but that's normal in any organization that is growing at this rhythm. I personally enjoy seeing growing pains because that means you are doing and bringing to DocuSign your talent and experience, to keep growing- fast and strong!

headline: Great Place to Work Keeps Getting Better
pros:
- Incredible opportunity to change the way business gets done
- Visionary leadership with a focused strategy
- Values-based culture that puts the customer and their success as the top priority
cons:
- Rapid pace
- Process not always in place, has to be built as we go

headline: Commercial Sales Executive
pros: the company culture is great and and the team i work on his great. there are no clear guidelines in place to get promoted which can be a good or bad thing. its a very fluid environment that has its growing pains, so there are some operation issues that I deal with but its not too bad. location is great, young environment, fun happy hours, and culturally not bad. they pay for benefits which is awesome!
cons:
i personally preference is not to be micro managed so sometimes it very irritating. there is no clear understanding how quotas are set and not many people are hitting quota. after so long it doesn't pay enough. the base salary is decent but many other jobs pay more. if you don't deal well with stress then sales is not for you. 

CEO, COO, CIO are great guys! Keith is hilarious! 

they promote C levels alot while the lower positions struggle. its very top heavy.

headline: Good Environmen
pros: I like docusign because we have a good environment. It's an innovative company that can grow a lot.
cons: I would like the company has more benefits like partnership with language schools.

headline: Disappointing Sales Experience
pros: I will say that despite the terrible pay in the bay area, it is a solid product. Customers like it. Good name brand awareness.
cons:
I wasn't going to add a review until I saw A response from one of the members of the management team regarding compensation and being paid for deals. While I have no experience in not getting paid for things that I have worked on, the compensation at Docusign is far below what you would expect in the bay area and has been for a long time.The reality is how much you make is a matter of which tribe you're associated with. Frankly the money stinks and it's a shame because the culture is good. If you're in technology sales and you have any level of experience, there's simply no reason to work at Docusign.

The response I saw was coming from someone who is either clueless or doesn't understand what motivates sales people especially good ones.

headline: Focus on delivery
pros: Company focused on and rewards people who deliver. Upper management gets out of the way so we can get our jobs done. What more can a dev ask for?
cons: Love it here. Nothing to add.

headline: HR Director
pros: Great product, smart people, and high performing culture!
cons: Constantly changing environment.  If you don't like change, this is not for you.

headline: A Full Potential Company
pros: DocuSign it's a company that is growing everyday and we can see it. That's important for the current employee because the company make us be part of that and we feel motivated to continue to grow with more and more. It's a great place to work and I feel very excited to be part of it and work with so good people!
cons: We still have somethings to reorganize at the company's office in Brazil, but nothing that could harm our work.

headline: Global Trust Network......maybe the trust should start on the inside....Customers, Partners and employees - BEWARE.
pros: Company on a rapid rise, real potential to make some money, but is it worth it?
cons:
Unfortunately the core values when it comes to the DocuSign are just words written on a website. Snr Management including HR Leaders are purely looking after each other.  I've been subject to deplorable behaviour by a "leader" in the business and snr management have failed to act, despite the clear and overwhelming evidence.  Lying, cheating and manipulation seem to be acceptable at DocuSign.

This behaviour has effectively destroyed my ability to be successful within this organisation.

headline: Great team and fantastic work culture
pros:
Love the open and frank culture where one can experiment new ideas. 
The company encourages team players. This is the place where everyone helps the team be successful. 
Not to mention that DocuSign has a smart business strategy backed by seasoned and mature top management.
cons: It's a extremely fast paced culture.

headline: Doculover
pros: DocuSign is an amazing company to work for. Great culture and great people.
cons: As all start ups companies, DocuSign is not well organized yet

headline: A Game Changing, Innovative Company  - Way more than e-Signature Industry Leader
pros:
+Great technology
+Smart people
+Industry creator & Leader
+Innovative
+Fun
+Challenging problems to solve
cons: Nothing aside from the typical growing pains I've seen in 20 years in Bay Area High Tech, but, that open all kinds of opportunities to make a huge impact.

headline: Great Company!
pros: Great managers and a great team to work with.
cons: I can't think of any.

headline: Dynamic & quick-paced environment, great talent
pros: I've seen a ton of growth at the company, and the leadership has done an excellent job of maintaining company vision through these changes—I feel very clear on DocuSign's strategic direction and what success means in the context of the company. I'm constantly inspired by the vision of the company, and feel very excited to work with so many  bright and experienced people who are self-starters interested in making the company a success.
cons: DocuSign's culture can be a little fragmented—culture, work-life balance, etc are different team to team.

headline: One of the Best...
pros: Bright, incredible people, unbelievable market opportunity, who's who of investors...companies like DocuSign don't come around very often.
cons: Not for the faint of heart, you better be ready to work.

headline: Solid growing company
author_position: Senior Software Design Engineer In Test
pros:
Great people to work with and enjoyable team dynamics
Challenging, fast-paced work on interesting problems
Lots of opportunity to influence technology stack and processes
Basically the opportunity and fun of a startup with the stability of a more established company
cons:
Growing pains. If you are accustomed to a workspace where processes are set and you always know what to expect, you might have difficulty adjusting.
Lower on the pay scale compared to the larger companies in the area. Still plenty as far as I'm concerned though.

headline: Awesome Place To Start A Career
pros:
DocuSign is an amazing to launch a sales & marketing career. This company is taking off right now.  The budgets are large, so there are plenty of trade shows, company events, training, and demand gen to help you build sales fundamentals.

I learned more about B2B sales here than any job i've had before or since. This company will provide you exposure to working with some of the leading technology partners and enterprise accounts in the world in a low-risk sales environment. It was fun to come into the office every day.
cons:
Sometimes there isn't a whole lot of structure or process, but that was part of the fun. Figure it out, and leadership will take notice. 

Biggest gripe: The pay. DocuSign consistently underpays its line employees, because they know they can get away with it. Leave here with a good track record and you can expect your OTE to bump 50% or more.

headline: Good team, challenging, good development opp
pros: Company growing fast and expanding.  Good benefits and decent perks. Smart colleagues. Reasonable work-life balance. Some travel, esp to Seattle and San Francisco.
cons: Larger now (over 1000 people), makes it sometimes hard to know what other teams are doing and why they're doing it (communicating across company is not always great).  New industry, still being figured out so convincing customers can be a lot of basics.  Lots of bureucrats in some functions like finance, expenses (very hard to work with & not reasonable).

headline: Great Product, The VPs/C-level run it like a good 'ol boy network
pros:
There are smart coworkers and you tackle big challenges. 
There are people with a get it done attitude.
The teams with true cohesion have built a great culture.
cons: There recently has been lot of changes and restructuring and loss of critical and amazing individuals that should have been kept due to their work ethic, experience and knowledge. This is challenging for managers, employees and customers. The new focus on SF being the headquarters has caused other offices to be sidelined and therefore the career paths are not there for individuals outside of SF, in the US. The work life balance is not good in some places but it really depends on your role.

headline: Death of a Salesman - do NOT go here if in sales
pros: CEO is energetic, likable and knows what he's doing. Product is prolific and can be introduced to lots of buyer personas in a prospect account.
cons: I did a lot of due diligence before going to DocuSign, but I was not given access to a variety of sales people to ask about deal size. In the interview process they gave me 2 "poster children" who'd earned a ton of money in sales.  But like kings and peasants, a small few were making any money and EVERYONE else starved. When I first arrived I was shocked by how little my installed customers were paying us. I was concerned about hitting quota, let alone surpassing it.  It was important to me that I surpass quota b/c the DocuSign comp plan (OTE) is below market. For the first 6 months I kept wondering how we sold bigger deals. But they were all very small and tactical.  I set out to ask a smattering of other Account Executives how they were doing, and the 10 other people I spoke to that had been there for a while confirmed my fears. While some did indeed close a large deal for the year, it still barely put them at quota and the OTE was sub-market. People who had been there for 3 years were still not doing well compared to how they had done in the past. I gave it my best effort to see if I could overcome the small deal size by increasing volume. And although the deal volume was there I was working on transactions that were smaller than I did in my twenties. I don't recommend this job to anyone in Enterprise sales who is looking to sustain their earnings track record. There is a new SVP of Sales who knows what he's doing, however, I would give it a full year of him fixing things before even entertaining a sales job there. I'd be concerned that if he was not successful he may not stay either. The root of the problem is the DocuSign although the best product in this class, is a point solution that is not considered to solve a broad series of business processes, and it's just hard to yield the kind of deal size that true enterprise applications can.

headline: Glad I made the decision to join the team
pros:
Dynamic fast paced environment
Smart driven coworkers
Experienced and professional leadership team
Great product that consumers love
cons: Lots of changes but that is natural for a late stage start up

headline: One of the few unicorns in the valley
pros: Great vision, great senior leadership, fantastic growth and opportunities
cons: It is fast paced and rapid growth

headline: Great place to be!
pros: Fast moving and exciting time to be apart of this company.  You are constantly surrounded by very smart individuals.  You'll never be bored working for DocuSign.
cons: Hard to maintain a work-life balance

headline: This Company is taking off, happy to be on the ride
pros: I have worked on the market development team for about a year. This is one of the most collaborative environments I have ever worked in. The management does a good job of empowering employees to make an impact, which makes it fun to go to work. There is also a ton of room for growth and upward mobility. All around, employees are treated well and DocuSign sells a great product that we can all get behind.
cons: Growing so quickly can mean some aches and pains along the way. There are some procedural issues that can get cleaned up, but really nothing too bad.

headline: Super exciting company that is changing how business is conducted around the world
pros:
Clear market leader in a fast growing market that still has massive headroom; the market for Electronic and Digital signatures are still in its early phase. 

Amazing line-up of partners (Microsoft, Salesforce, SAP, Accenture, Nintex and many others).

Very experienced management team and great talent across the organisation.

Fast growth around the world is creating lots of opportunities for career growth including working internationally.
cons:
All the 'normal' growth pains associated with hyper growth. 

Still having to 'evangelise' in markets where E-Signature is in its early stage.

headline: Great experience
pros: Great experience starting my sales career. Received some of the best training in the industry
cons: growing extremely fast, need to be able to juggle a lot

headline: DocuSign is a fantastic company to work and I'm very proud to work there.
pros:
1. The chance to work with some of the smartest, most innovative and most energized people in the world 
2. Great work/life balance and the chance to work from home 
3. Lots of great company events
cons: 1. A bit disorganized at times but improving as we mature

headline: Unlimited opportunity and cool people
pros: -Growth -Awesome product -sells itself -People -Location (Seattle)
cons: Disorganized -hard to change -Sales staff doesn't know product

headline: Growing fast and potential is unlimited but not perfect
pros: One of the best working experiences that I've ever had.  The company is growing fast, and the culture is very positive.  Whenever someone has a problem or doesn't know an answer, there are multiple people willing to help out.  The other thing I really like is everyone largely believes in the product.  We use it internally for tons of use cases.
cons:
With fast growth comes some growing pains, but that's natural.  Also, would like to see more employee development and training.  

Also there are some challenges if you are a remote employee and not in one of the big offices.

headline: Just awesome.
pros: Every day brings new challenges and problems to solve for my clients.
cons: For new remote employees it could be challenging to ramp up and stay in the know.

headline: Fabulous place to be, for many reasons....
pros: You get to be immersed in energetic environment, with great leadership and direction.  In engineering, there are great problems to solve with a fun, seasoned team.  You get to ship software at a rate that is aggressive but not too aggressive and without the red tape.
cons: There's certainly no shortage of things to do.  That can be overwhelming.  And, the culture can be too aggressive for some and the energy can be over the top for some, I suppose.  I like both aspects, though.

headline: Growing, Challenging, Fun experience at a great point in its life cycle.
pros: Smart people focused on a great problem that helps our customers improve their business processes.   As long as we stay targeted on helping electronic signature and digital transaction management grow, this will continue to be a great company.  There's room to be creative, and try something new, but we're also focused on pragmatic results, not just good ideas.
cons: We've been hiring a lot of people from other larger companies that expect to have a lot of things done for them, and avoid getting hands on with customers.

headline: Great culture, fast-growing company
pros: Collaborative approach to problem solving, very focused on results, supportive team structure, well connected and successful leaders running the company, great office culture
cons: Feels like we're going too fast, not enough advancement within the company, still developing internal processes

headline: Rare opportunity to be in middle of hyper-growth and transformation from current to digital
pros:
It's as-advertised.  I had my pick of hot companies to work for but truly believed in DocuSign's vision for a digital world.  Not just signing things electronically, it's the next 2-3 steps that I'm interested in.  I was not disappointed to find that the company is full of like-minded people.  

There's really no need to point out that people are sharp - every self respecting SV/SF/Seattle/hot-bed-of-technology tech darling is full of sharp people - but it's the hunger and excitement people exude because they know we're on the brink of doing something truly transformative.  Cliches like 'changing the game' and 'transformative' was common among recruiting pitches I heard during last job hunt, and I'm sure some companies do mean it, but I'm satisfied with how DocuSign walks the walk.
cons:
Some would rate lower stars because of the lack of structure, and it is a challenge, but anyone that did their homework knows DocuSign is going through hyper growth and a lot of process and structure is being defined as a work in progress.  I'd like to think the company makes up for this by hiring very individually strong people.  At the mid level (Senior Manager/Directors/Sr. Directors), I see a lot of peers who has been here done that and can adapt fast to changing priorities that is somewhat expected at this pace.

The work-life balance and hours isn't great almost by definition of being a tech start-up.  But again, to expect otherwise would be odd.  Besides, people that track stock options in secondary markets knows the work is worth it.

headline: Good Company Culture
pros: great people to work with, innovative product, fast pace
cons: growing pains, scaling very quickly, split teams between offices

headline: Great Internship Experience
pros:
Company culture was amazing, very cool young people that I could relate to as a college student.

Fantastic mentoring by management, interpersonal relationships with higher ups that I probably wouldn't have had access to at other large companies.

Incredible office looking over Bainbridge Island and the Puget Sound

Growing company, very exciting to be a part of.
cons:
Pay for interns is fairly low

Internship was entirely based around Sales which is not what I'm necessarily interested in

headline: Great people - mixed leadership competencies - promising future
pros: The people at DocuSign are amazingly smart, collaborative and fun.  The product is great and will be a standard app in the not too distant future.  Innovation is also very good here.
cons: CEO is inspiring and a hard worker.  Most of his direct reports are solid and smart.  Sales leadership is immature and lacks sophistication - all the way up to the CRO.  Needs an upgrade to keep the company moving forward in the right direction.

headline: Fast moving startup building the killer app-IF you can make it here, you'll have a great experience.
pros: Great product, great strategic vision, internal relationships are fairly good.
cons: Challenging priduct to sell. Cuatomers don't know how to buy electronic sigbature, so you'll need to quickly figure out how to guide them. Quotas are aggressive and lots of people with success selling other software don't do well here.

headline: Changing the way business is done
pros: Blue Ocean - nothing but opportunity for growth
cons: a lot of companies are slow to adopt - still viewed as a "nice to have" technology even though it's inevitably a business critical solution.

headline: Great technology, awful sales org
pros: The product is amazing and the people, sans management, are great.
cons:
I can only speak for the sales department but within that group, the company failed miserably. In less than a year on the job, I had 3 management changes, 2 changes in vertical and 4 changes to my geo. Top that off with an INCREASE in quota and you have an extremely disgruntled worker. While the rest of the company seems to coast by with a good product and competent management (albeit grossly underpaid), the sales department is as dysfunctional as they come. 

Don't take my word on it - do a bit of digging yourself and it's plain to see that there are the old guards (4+ years there) and then there's the new (>2 years). Reason? The "senior" sales guys have literally plucked all the business into their funnels and have sat themselves in verticals that pay extremely well. Health care, finance, insurance - all of those reps kill it. Leads pour in, marketing dollars get spent, the entire staff there is jubilant. The rest? Well, if you've started in the last 2 years, the likelihood is that you'll get shoved into a geo and fail miserably. 

But let's ignore the fact that you're set up to fail as a geo rep. Let's couple that with a micro management strategy to top all micro management strategies. It's seems as though every sales manager in the company has been trained to treat their team the same exact way: dissect and grill each and every deal you don't close. I had 2 managers there - one which was socially a terrible fit and the other who initially started off as a very nice guy. Even the nice guy manager was molded into the slacks-wearing, button down frat boy that is seen only on Wall St, minus the 6-figure salary. Had enough? Not so fast. I'd be remiss if I didn't mention that regardless of moving to a hourly compensation model, you are still "required" to be in before 7 and out no earlier than 4.

It's honestly extremely difficult to get beyond the first year at this place, at least in sales. You get paid a measly base salary, won't make any commissions worth noting until year 2 (at the earliest) and by that time, you're so burnt out at the lack of work/life balance that your personal life will suffer. While there are some great people that work there, the majority of people I know have either moved departments (if you can imagine taking a salary cut), or left before their year is done. Not that it means anything but they like to keep you there with the notion of this big payout WHEN the company goes public. We all know that this is no guarantee and in full disclosure, they've been "planning" this massive IPO for 2+ years now. The idea that people are agonizing at their job over the slim likelihood that their stock options will make them millionaires is sad and quite frankly false hope. Think very long and hard before taking a sales job here.

headline: Stay Clear if in Sales
pros: Interesting Technology, good coworkers, nice offices.
cons: Unrealistic Sales goals, high rates of turnover in Sales, management only interested in saving their own skin with no staff development. Too few people are making their number quarter after quarter.

headline: Sales at DocuSign
pros: great culture, great opportunity moving forward, leadership is very approachable.
cons: Must be vocal about desire to get a promotion, huge growth often translates to many changes on the fly, some good, some bad

headline: No Middle ground here... some amazing people and some absolutely horrendous roll over anyone to get theirs type of folk.
pros: Energy everywhere, best marketers in the SaaS space, opportunity abounds as the market is just learning how to leverage the DocuSign platform,  amazing software engineers building the product.  Some (but few) amazing people working here.
cons: Absolutely NO long term plan.  SLT won't go on record for anything beyond the end of the quarter, product is not being built to support the Enterprise Customers which is where the value of the company is derived.  Can't figure out how to do business outside of Financial Services, Wealth Mgt., and Insurance with the exception of a Telecommunications company here or there.  The Company has wasted Millions hiring and firing sales teams that were amazing talent evangelizing a market that is still yet to see the value this platform brings.  Surprisingly there's an old school premised base ERP method / approach to the whole business which is about as ironic as you can imagine. You won't find more expensive benefit package for a family and no 401k match.

headline: Customer Success Architect
pros: Absolutely poised to take over the world.  Unrivaled passion in the employees, accessible and dynamic leadership, great business model and a product that has applications in any company.
cons: Must be a self starter as fast growth leaves little time for coddling.

headline: Account Manager
pros: Work hard, play hard mentality.  Great leadership, management and employees.
cons: Excelling is extremely difficult - once you take a position, you'll be in that position for at least 2 years.  Also, the pay could be a lot more competitive.

headline: Hyper Growth is a unique opportunity
pros: Team is working together to build a company to last.  Customers love what we do and it feels great to assist them in changing their businesses.  Very exciting to be part of the team now as we continue to grow our organization with some of the best talent in the world
cons: The company is growing fast and it wasn't that long ago we were a small company.  We are still developing the processes we need to scale the company while we ensure our customers are being successful.  The work-life balance is a challenge - but as we grow it seems less taxing

headline: Great entry level sales training
pros:
- Fantastic quality of entry level sales training
- excellent location/office space
- work with motivated, intelligent, friendly people
- DocuSign is a HOT company to work for so it's great on a resume when it's time to move on
cons:
- relatively low pay
- relatively slow promotion timeline for entry level position

headline: Super awesome people, great product, a few rough edges
pros:
DocuSign has done well to hire lots of smart, passionate people. There are zero ROJs ("retired on the job") and a general desire to collaborate, share, and grow together. Sure, the company doesn't always know the best way to do that but they care enough to want to figure it out. 

Plus, you get to contribute to a pretty interesting product with an enormous road ahead of it.
cons: A little bit too much bureaucracy for a company of this size and stage. A little more sharing of vision past the near term would help the folks on the ground understand where we're going.

headline: Disorganized, and dishonest
pros: The technology stacks and problem space are very enjoyable.  The work hours are good, though that is often due to the lack of passion in the engineering department.  Many engineers are very very smart, though their hard work and input is rarely recognized.
cons:
The whole organization is top heavy.  Despite having around 650 salaried workers (a few more contractors and temps), there are over 40 VPs and over 100 Senior managers or Directors.  This doesn't stop DocuSign from continuing to hire an additional VP every month, though, at the cost of withholding compensation from any employee under director level. 
It seems like the shift towards an IPO plan has really been a move to get all of the current executives friends in on the cheap-stock-option action before the official public offering - Just another way for rich friends to get richer.

Promotions within the company are avoided (by regular employees) at all cost, as they come with 0% compensation change, a shiny new title, and a 300% increase in workload.  That's it.  No additional influence in architecture or product decisions, no added stock options.  Just another move to see how much can be piled on an engineer before they burn out.

The employees who work the hardest and the ones who do just enough not to get fired are recognized as equals from the eyes of the executives, with hard work often being rewarded with nothing other than MORE hard work.

There are a lot of managers and directors who try to do right by their engineers, but they are completely powerless against the growing executive boys club.

headline: Senior Software Engineer
pros: very fun culture. work environment is lay back. work-life balance is good. compensation is alright, i'd expect either a little more considering this space is very competitive right now.
cons:
compensation can be improved to stay competitive or the company will lose the competitiveness on hiring talent people and lose existing talent engineers. 
perks can be improved too, free lunch would be nice.

headline: I was not happy working for this company.
pros: Some of the people are very nice, but constantly over-worked.  The same small pool of people seem to do all the work.
cons: Lack of respect for employees, too many undeserving VPs, no diversity, low pay, inappropriate derogatory & personal comments made to employees by management.

headline: Worst company I have ever worked for
pros: There are honestly some good people who work here and they make it worth it.
cons: Read the early reviews, they are true.  I feel like the most recent and current reviews are written by the HR department.  This company only cares about themselves and not the employees that work for it.  The people who care will be jaded fast.
